question_text: A patient has chronic cough with occasional blood in the sputum. He has a history of significant weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following media cannot be used to culture the organism causing his symptoms?
explanation: This patient with chronic cough and hemoptysis with a concurrent history of significant weight loss and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. McLeod's medium is not used to culture M. tuberculosis. It is a selective medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis include: Solid- Loeffler's medium is a serum-containing solid medium used for the culture of M. tuberculosis. Other solid media used include Lowenstein- Jensen medium, Dorset medium, Tarshis medium, and Pawlowsky's medium. Liquid- Middlebrook’s media are used for the preparation of antigens and vaccines and i sensitivity testing. Other examples of liquid mycobacterial culture media include Dubos' medium, Sula's medium and Sauton's medium. Automated culture methods: BACTEC 460- uses radioisotopes for detection BacT alert- colorimetric method of detectio BACTEC MGIT- fluorometric detection method.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A microbiology resident is performing liquid automated culture on the sputum sample of a TB suspect patient. Which of the following culture media would he not use for the same?
explanation: Tarshis medium is a solid growth medium used for culturing mycobacterium species. Versatrek, BactiAlert, and BACTEC MGIT 960 are liquid automated cultures used for tuberculosis. The diagnostic tools for TB are as follows: Sputum microscopy for AFB Ziehl Neelson staining Fluorescence staining Culture Solid media– Lowenstein-Jensen (most common), Petragnini and Dorset, Tarshis, Loeffler, Pawlowsky. Liquid automated culture – Versatrek, BactiAlert, BACTEC MGIT 960 (MGIT stands for Mycobacteria Growth Indicator Tube) Drug Sensitivity Testing / Proportionate Sensitivity Testing: Using MGIT, LJ medium Rapid molecular diagnostic testing Line probe assay CB-NAAT- Nucleic acid amplification test using GeneXpert system Other diagnostic tools are as follows: Chest X-ray Tuberculin sensitivity testing

question_text: Which of the following tests can simultaneously detect TB and rifampicin resistance in <2 hours?
explanation: Xpert MTB/RIF detects tuberculosis (TB) and rifampicin resistance simultaneously within 2 hours. It is a fully automated, real-time nucleic acid amplification technology, with high specificity and sensitivity. The WHO recommends its use worldwide as the initial diagnostic test in adults and children who are presumed to have multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) or HIV-associated TB. Xpert MTB/RIF should also be the first test applied to the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of patients in whom tubercular meningitis is suspected as well as a replacement test (over conventional microscopy, culture, and histopathology) for gastric lavage, pleural and other biopsies, and fine-needle aspiration specimens. The image below shows the Xpert MTB/RIF system.

question_text: Which of the following is not a method of testing drug susceptibility in Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
explanation: Disc diffusion method is used for drug susceptibility testing for most bacteria; however, it is not used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The disc diffusion technique is not suitable for testing Mycobacterium tuberculosis because the organism grows so slowly that the drug has time to diffuse throughout the medium, and sharp zones of inhibition are not seen. Methods used in the drug susceptibility testing of M.tb include: For agar-based methods, ‹H10 or ‹H11 Middlebrook media are used and only the proportion method can be applied. Radiometric techniques measure the metabolic activity of the bacteria. Based on changes in these values, drug susceptibility can be estimated. question_text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is .
explanation: TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV(who frequently have a negative Mantoux test). Interferon-gamma release assays include: QuantiFERON-TB Gold T-SPOT.TB QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IFN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CDù+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens. T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-. The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample. (Option A and B)
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A urine LAM (Lipoarabinomannan) assay was performed in an HIV +ve patient with a CD4+ count of 40/L. Infection with which of the following organisms can be diagnosed using this test?
explanation: Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in the mycobacterial cell wall, released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis. Urine LAM is a useful tool in diagnosing tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV and low CD4+ T cell count. Most diagnostic tests for tuberculosis rely on sputum samples, which are difficult to obtain and have low sensitivity in immunocompromised patients, patients with disseminated TB, and children, delaying treatment initiation. Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) is the only WHO-endorsed TB biomarker that can be detected in urine, an easily collected sample.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A middle-aged man came with a history of fever and night sweats for the past 2 weeks. He has had noticeable weight loss. Bronchoalveolar lavage was done, but Mycobacterium tuberculosis was not detected. Extra-pulmonary TB is suspected. Which site is most likely affected?
explanation: Lymph nodes are the most common site of extrapulmonary TB. The diagnosis is established by fine needle aspiration biopsy. In descending order of frequency, the extrapulmonary sites most commonly involved in TB are: lymph nodes pleura genitourinary tract bones and joints meninges, peritoneum and pericardium. In less than 50% of these cases, there is associated pulmonary disease.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Your neighbour is worried about a scar on her 5-month-old daughter's arm that is show below. She tells you the child has received all vaccines on time. Which of the following statements is true about the vaccine that caused this finding?
options: Distilled water is used as diluent for this vaccine
The route of administration is subcutaneous
WHO recommends Danish 1331 strain for vaccine
explanation: The scar shown in the image results from the BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine. The WHO recommends Danish 1331 strain for BCG vaccine production. Normal saline is recommended as the diluent for the BCG vaccine as distilled water is an irritant. The dose administered is 0.1ml containing 0.1mg. It is administered intradermally by using 26 gauge tuberculin syringe on the left deltoid.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
You are performing the pre-employment check up of a young man. You need to perform a tuberculin skin test as a part of this process. Which of the following tests would you not use for this purpose?
Pirquet test
explanation: QuantiFERON-TB gold is not a type of tuberculin skin test. It is a type of interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), a whole-blood test that can aid in diagnosing Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. There are 3 described methods for tuberculin skin testing (TST): Mantoux test, also known as the Pirquet test (preferred method) Heaf test Tine test In contrast, IGRAs that have been approved by the FDA are: QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT) T-SPOT.TB test (T-Spot) QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) IGRA is not used in India due to a higher probability of a false positive due to universal BCG vaccination. It can also lead to a diagnosis of active TB in a patient with latent TB and may lead to overtreatment. This test is banned in India after the WHO advised against it in low and middle-income countries. Other Mycobacteria
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is a pigment-producing species of mycobacteria?
explanation: Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a pigment-producing species of mycobacteria. M. scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen which produces yellow or orange colored pigments, even in the dark. It belongs to group II of Runyon's classification. It can cause scrofula or cervical adenitis in children. M.ulcerans, M.avium intracellulare complex (MAC), and M. xenopi belong to group III-non photochromogens as they do not form pigment even on exposure to light.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A microbiologist working with mycobacteria notes moist, smooth, flat, white colonies growing on Lowenstein-Jensen media. Which species of mycobacteria is she likely studying?
explanation: The species of mycobacteria being studied here is Mycobacterium bovis. It forms moist, smooth, flat, white colonies on Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) media that break-up easily when touched. Mycobacterium bovis belongs to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex. It causes tuberculosis-like disease in humans. Lowenstein–Jensen medium is a commonly used, egg-based, selective media for mycobacteria. It contains: Egg- Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism Malachite green- Prevents the growth of contaminants. Makes it a selective medium. Mineral salt solution- Buffer Glycerol- Source of carbon, favors growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis. LJ medium without glycerol, which contains pyruvate, is used for culture of M. bovis. L-asparagine- Nitrogen source The image below shows M.bovis colonies on LJ media. Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised and irregular with a wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious and difficult to emulsify(rough, tough, buff).

question_text: A 54-year-old male presents with an ulcer on his hand. On swab culture, growth of M. ulcerans is seen. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: Mycobacterium ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer. M. ulcerans produces a toxin called mycolactone which leads to formation of Buruli ulcer. This is a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue which is characterized by the formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated. The ulcers heal with disfiguring scars. The image below shows a Buruli ulcer. Option A: Hunner's ulcers are seen in a subset of patients with interstitial cystitis. These are areas of inflammation on the bladder wall. The image below shows a cystoscopic image of a Hunner's ulcer. Option B: Meleney's ulcer or post-operative synergistic bacterial gangrene occurs in immuno-compromised individuals following abdominal surgery. It is caused by a synergistic interaction between microaerophilic nonhemolytic Streptococcus and hemolytic aerobic Staphylococcus aureus. Option D: Marjolin ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. The image below shows a Marjolin's ulcer in a burn scar.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 42-year-old man who works at an aquarium and handles the fish without protective equipment presents to the OPD with the following finding. Infection with which of the following bacteria led to his condition?
explanation: The image shows a fish tank granuloma that is caused by M. marinum. The typical clinical presentation is as a single, small violet papule or nodule confined to one extremity, developing 2-3 weeks after trauma. The nodule may break down to form an indolent ulcer. M. marinarum is a natural pathogen of fish and amphibians, which spreads to humans who come in contact with contaminated swimming pools or fish tanks. Other non-tuberculous mycobacteria causing disease in humans include: M. kansasii: Disease resembles pulmonary TB M. scrofulaceum: Cervical lymphadenitis M. avium complex: Pulmonary, disseminated TB, especially in AIDS patients M. fortuitum: Nail salon furunculosis M. paratuberculosis (aka Johne’s bacillus) causes Johne’s disease in cattle. It is associated with Crohn’s disease in humans.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about the microbiological diagnosis of the disease afflicting the patient shown below?
options: Acid fast staining is done by Ziehl-Neelsen technique, using 25% sulphuric acid
Sample should be collected from the centre of the lesion
The number of samples to be collected is 3-4
It is cultivated in nine banded armadillos and foot pads of mice
explanation: The image depicts leonine facies in a patient suffering from leprosy or Hansen's disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It is cultivated in nine-banded armadillos and footpads of mice. M. leprae is a Gram-positive, weakly acid fast bacillus. Thus, 5% sulphuric acid (option A) is used for decolourisation to demonstrate M.leprae's acid-fastness. On microscopy, the bacilli appear bound together in masses called globi, within which they are arranged in a 'cigar bundle' appearance. For leprosy diagnosis, specimens are collected from the nasal mucosa, skin lesions and earlobes. Nasal smears are collected from the internal septum of the nose. Skin smears are collected from the edges of the lesions (option B) rather than from the centre. Slit skin smears are taken as well. The skin is pinched up tight to minimise bleeding and a cut is made with a scalpel, deep enough to get into the infiltrated layers. This is done over the buttocks, forehead, chin, cheek, and ears (at least 5-6 different areas) (option C).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the generation time of lepra bacilli?
explanation: The generation time of lepra bacilli is 12-13 days. Generation time, also known as doubling time, is the time it takes for the bacterial population to double. It can also be measured as the time between two cell divisions under optimum conditions. The generation time of different bacilli are given below: Lepra bacilli- 12-13 days average (may vary from 8-42 days) Tubercle bacilli- 15-20 hours Coliform bacilli- 20 minutes
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What are the bacteria present in Virchow's cells?
explanation: The bacteria present in Virchow’s cells is M. leprae. Lepromatous leprosy lesions contain large aggregates of lipid laden macrophages (lepra cells/Virchow cells) which are often filled with globi (masses) of acid fast bacilli. The image below shows a high-power Fite-Faraco stain of a skin lesion showing globi of M.leprae.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You counsel a patient with leprosy about lepra reactions before starting her on multidrug therapy. Which among these is correct regarding these reactions?
explanation: Statements 2, 4, and 5 regarding lepra reactions are correct. Type 2 lepra reactions are unrelated to drug therapy, whereas type 1 reactions may occur within a year of starting treatment. New lesions typically appear in type 2 lepra reactions. They are tender and erythematous subcutaneous and dermal nodules. Existing lesions show no changes.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient diagnosed with leprosy was undergoing further evaluation for classification of type and immune response. Which of the following statements is false regarding the intradermal test used in such evaluation?
options: It has no value in prognostication of leprosy
BCG vaccine may convert a negative test to positive
explanation: The lepromin test has value as a prognostic test for leprosy. The lepromin, or Mitsuda test, is a method to measure cellular immunity in leprosy. It is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just under the skin and the induration reaction is measured 3–4 weeks after. It is used to classify leprosy. A negative lepromin test is seen in lepromatous and borderline leprosy. It is negative in children <6 months of age, it may be positive at the end of 1st year. BCG vaccine is capable of converting a negative lepromin test to a positive.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You are performing the test shown in the image on a patient. How many days later do you ask the patient to return so that you get an accurate read on the Mitsuda reaction?
explanation: Mitsuda's reaction is read in the 3rd week, i.e., on the 21st day or 20 days after the day of injection. Lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. It is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just under the skin. The first reaction to occur is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours. It usually remains for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance. The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. On the 21st day, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. Note: The 21st day is 20 days after the day of injection which is counted as the 1st day.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A leprosy vaccine is being introduced on a pilot basis in India. Which of the following mycobacterial species is the basis for its development?
M. vaccae
explanation: Mycobacterium indicus pranii is the basis for the development of a leprosy vaccine. The leprosy vaccine species was originally called Mycobacterium W (M.w) but was later renamed Mycobacterium indicus pranii. The vaccine is administered via intradermal route. The dose is 0.1 ml. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms. Booster doses will be given to maintain the immunity level. These are given only in one arm. Escherichia, Proteus and Klebsiella
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells, and culture on MacConkey agar showed the following. Which organism is involved here?
explanation: This patient who presented with dysuria and frequent micturition with urinalysis showing pus cells, and growth of lactose-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar suggests a diagnosis of urinary tract infection by Escherichia coli. Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as: Lactose fermenters - Escherichia, Klebsiella Late lactose fermenters - Shigella sonnei Non-lactose fermenters- Salmonella species, Shigella species The image below shows lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. Mnemonic to remember non-lactose fermenters: (SPY PSM) Salmonella Proteus Yersinia Providencia- late fermenter Shigella (except S.sonnei which is a late lactose fermenter) Morganella
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The stool culture of a patient with suspected food poisoning produced hemolytic colonies on blood agar. The isolated organism gave a positive indole test and a positive MUG test. You observe the following colonies on eosin methylene blue agar. Identify the organism.
explanation: The given scenario of a patient with suspected food poisoning with stool culture growing hemolytic colony on blood agar with a positive indole test and MUG test with a iridescent green colony growth on eosin methylene blue agar is characteristic of Escherichia coli. E. coli produces the enzyme -glucuronidase which is tested using the MUG test. In it, the substrate MUG (4-methylumbelliferyl--glucuronide) is reduced by the enzyme to produce a fluorescent color which indicates a positive MUG test.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the cut-off for bacteriuria beyond which a diagnosis of catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) can be made?
explanation: The cut-off value for bacteriuria to diagnose catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) is >103 CFU/mL. The minimum criterion for catheter-associated asymptomatic bacteriuria (CA-ASB) is >102 CFU/mL.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A tourist came to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. Which of the following strains of E. coli is most commonly implicated in this case?
explanation: This patient with watery diarrhea most likely has traveller’s diarrhea caused by Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC). Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism that causes diarrhea in travelers. It produces the following toxins: < (heat-labile toxin) - acts by cAMP ST (heat-stable toxin) - two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II) ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by  cGMP in the intestine. ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known. Other options: Option A: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using E. coli adherent factor (EAF) and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) and causes effacement of microvilli. Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome. Option D: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, which can be detected as a diagnostic test.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Identify the organism below that causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
explanation: Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC). E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes watery diarrhea which is self-limiting. EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells. Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors: Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF). Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island. The image below shows an electron microscopy image of E Coli.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You are investigating an outbreak of diarrhea. You find out that the etiological agent causes stacked-brick formation on hep-2 cells as shown below. What is the likely organism?
explanation: The stacked-brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells is caused by enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC). Enteroaggregative E. coli has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF). EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) is considered to be a major virulence factor for EAEC. The given image shows the stacked-brick pattern of adherence on microscopy at 600x magnification.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 29-year-old woman presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. She was diagnosed with hemolytic uremic syndrome and treated with plasmapheresis and dialysis. What is false about the infectious causative agent?
options: It does not produce a Shiga like toxin
There is person to person transmission.
explanation: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) is caused by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) serotype O157:H7. It produces a Shiga like toxin, therefore EHEC is also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). Other options: Option A - Strains of E. coli producing verocytotoxin or Shiga toxin (stx2a-g) can cause diarrheal disease ranging from mild diarrhea to fatal hemorrhagic colitis and HUS. The most common EHEC belongs to serotype O157:H7. Option C - In EHEC diarrhea, fecal leukocytes are commonly seen (70%) but although it is an infectious condition, fever is not seen. The absence of fever can lead to its misdiagnosis as a non-infectious condition such as intussusception or ischemic bowel disease. Option D - The disease is transmitted through contaminated feces. Person-to-person transmission can occur if infected persons do not wash their hands after using the toilet or after changing diapers. Note: Shiga toxin produced by S. dysenteriae is referred to as Stx.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Sereny test was employed for laboratory diagnosis of which of the following organisms?
explanation: The Sereny test is an animal pathogenicity test that used to be employed for laboratory diagnosis of enteroinvasive E. coli and Shigella. Freshly isolated suspension of bacteria is instilled into the eyes of guinea pigs which leads to mucopurulent conjunctivitis and severe keratitis. It is not in use anymore as we have better methods of detecting toxigenicity now like molecular methods.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the culture media used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli?
options: Thiosulphate citrate Bile salt sucrose medium
explanation: Sorbitol-MacConkey agar is used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli. E. coli O157:H7 does not ferment sorbitol and produces pale colonies on Sorbitol-MacConkey agar. All other strains of E. coli ferment sorbitol. Thus they produce pink colonies on Sorbitol-MacConkey agar. O157:H7 strains do not contain -glucuronidase and so are unable to use the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl--glucuronide(MUG). Thus, they give a negative MUG test.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false?
options: E.coli is an aerobe and facultative anaerobe.
Proteus infection increases risk of uric acid stones.
E.coli is motile by peritrichous flagella.
Proteus can metabolise phenylalanine to phenylpyruvic acid.
explanation: Proteus increases the risk of struvite stones in the bladder as it leads to the alkalinisation of urine. Struvite stones are magnesium-ammonium phosphate stones that appear as rectangular/coffin-lid crystals shaped on urine microscopy. Uric acid stones are precipitated in acidic urine. Proteus produces enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. This property is the basis for the phenylalanine deaminase test. The test is performed by inoculating the organism in phenylalanine agar. After incubation, 10% ferric chloride is added to the media. If phenyl pyruvic acid was produced, it will react with the ferric chloride and turn dark green. If the medium remains a straw colour, the organism is negative for phenylalanine deaminase production. E. coli is an aerobe and facultative anaerobe. Its motility is due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is the most common cause of urinary tract infections.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following shows Dienes phenomenon?
explanation: Dienes phenomenon is exhibited by Proteus mirabilis. When two identical strains of Proteus are inoculated at different places of the same culture plate, the resulting swarms of growth coalesce and no line is formed between swarming cultures of the same strain. However, if they are from two different strains, the spreading films of growth fail to coalesce and remain separated by a narrow but easily visible furrow (known as Dienes line). This is known as Dienes phenomenon. The image below shows Dienes phenomenon.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Blood culture of the sputum sample taken from a patient diagnosed with hospital-acquired pneumonia, showed a characteristic phenomenon as shown in the image. Identify the bacteria that exhibit this phenomenon.
explanation: The given image of the blood culture finding shows the characteristic bull's eye swarming pattern exhibited by Proteus. Proteus species move very actively with the help of peritrichous flagella, resulting in swarming on solid media. It can be suppressed by the addition of: henyl ethyl alcohol chloral hydrate sulphonamides sodium azide boric acid increasing the concentration of agar to 6%. Swarming does not occur on MacConkey medium and cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient (CLED) medium. Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus seen as a normal gastrointestinal flora. The two most common species causing infection in humans are P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris, which can be differentiated by spot indole test. P. mirabilis is indole negative while P. vulgaris is indole positive. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones. P. mirabilis is associated with urinary tract infections while P. vulgaris is usually associated with wound and soft tissue infections. Other organisms that show swarming include: Clostridium tetani Vibrio parahaemolyticus Serratia
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A middle-aged man from north India presents with a deformity as shown in the image below. He gives a history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge before this nodule appeared.
Which of the following organisms is responsible for his condition?
explanation: The above image and clinical scenario are suggestive of rhinoscleroma and it is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. K. rhinoscleromatis is a gram-negative bacillus also known as Frisch bacillus. It is endemic in north India. Rhinoscleroma is characterized by chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of the nose. Biopsy of the lesion shows: Mikulicz cells- large foamy cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated, cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies- eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. These are also observed in multiple myeloma. Other options: Option A: Rhinosporidium seeberi causes rhinosporidiosis. Option C: K. ozaenae causes atrophic rhinitis. Option D: K. oxytoca is associated with hemorrhagic colitis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You notice a sputum sample of a patient suspected of having ventilator-associated pneumonia turns progressively redder over time. Microscopic examination of the sample reveals an absence of red blood cells. Which of the following organisms could have caused this?
explanation: The given condition of sputum sample turning redder over time can be caused by Serratia marcescens. Serratia marcescens are pleomorphic coccobacilli that can grow in sputum after collection and can mimic hemoptysis because they produce a red pigment called prodigiosin. S. macescens mainly cause healthcare-associated infections such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, meningitis, endocarditis, septicemia and peritonitis. They can contaminate IV fluids, surgical instruments, and antiseptic solutions.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A 19-year-old boy presented with a single painless papule on his penis with no enlarged lymph nodes. A smear was made from the lesion and stained with Wright- Giemsa stain which showed the finding as shown in the following picture. Identify the organism.

Treponema pallidum
explanation: The given clinical vignette and the image showing Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears indicate a diagnosis of donovanosis caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells (called Pund cells). Klebsiella granulomatis shows bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a safety pin appearance. Bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) is shown by: H. ducreyi Vibrio parahaemolyticus Klebsiella granulomatis Yersinia pestis Burkholderia pseudomallei Burkholderia mallei Shigella and Salmonella
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A child presents with a high fever, acute abdominal pain, and malaise. The child passes small amounts of bloody mucopurulent stools with increasing tenesmus and cramps. What is the most likely causative organism?
explanation: Acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery (bloody mucopurulent stools) and tenesmus is most likely due to Shigella dysenteriae. Shigella dysenteriae is a Gram-negative bacillus causing bacillary dysentery in humans. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. Other options: Option A: Vibrio cholerae results in watery diarrhea with characteristic rice watery stools. Option B: Viruses such as rotavirus and norovirus causes watery diarrhea through mucosal irritation. Option D: Entamoeba histolytica results in gradual onset of symptoms usually 1-3 weeks with dysentery.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following toxins acts by inhibiting protein synthesis?
explanation: Shiga toxin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Shiga toxin or verotoxin is an exotoxin produced by Shigella species. It consists of two subunits A and B. The B subunit binds to globotriaosylceramide receptors on the target cell, and then, the A subunit gets internalized. The A subunit leads to inhibition of 60S ribosome, leading to shut down of protein synthesis. Its site of action is in the endothelial cells of small blood vessels of GIT.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 4-year-old boy developed bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. The bacteria isolated from the stool specimen did not ferment lactose or mannitol. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
explanation: Shigella dysenteriae does not ferment mannitol and lactose. Shigella species cause bacillary dysentery (bloody diarrhea with abdominal cramps). They do not ferment lactose, except S.sonnei which is a late lactose fermenter. To differentiate between the various Shigella species, mannitol fermentation is noted. question_text: Which of the following salmonellae is non-motile?
explanation: S. gallinarum is non-motile. Salmonellae are aerobic or facultatively anaerobic Gram-negative bacilli. They are motile due to the presence of peritrichous flagella, except S. gallinarum and S. pullorum.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A Greek patient with travel history to India is diagnosed with enteric fever. What is the minimum amount of pathogen required to cause this condition?
explanation: Enteric fever is caused by S. typhi or S. paratyphi. The minimum amount of S. typhi required to cause enteric fever is 103 to 106 organisms. Enteric fever spreads through the feco-oral route. It presents with step-ladder fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10–20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop abdominal distension, diarrhea, splenomegaly and characteristic rose spots on the abdomen due to vasculitis. The amount of pathogen required to cause an infection in the host is known as the infectious dose. The infectious doses of few bacteria are given below: Escherichia coli - 106 – 108 organisms Shigella - 10 – 100 organisms Escherichia coli O157:H7 - <10 organisms
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the incubation period of Salmonella typhi?
explanation: The incubation period for Salmonella typhi is from 5 to 21 days. The incubation period for Salmonella typhi typically averages 10–14 days, but can range from 5 to 21 days. The duration is likely dependant on the inoculum size and the host’s health and immune status.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 25-year-old man presented to the ER with fever, splenomegaly, and a rash as shown in the image below. After admission, he developed intestinal perforation and an exploratory laparotomy revealed several longitudinal ulcers in the small bowel. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows Rose spots. The combination of this with fever, splenomegaly, presence of longitudinal ulcers in the intestine and intestinal perforation is suggestive of enteric fever. The term enteric fever includes typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and paratyphoid fever caused by Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C. Enteric fever presents with step ladder pyrexia. The fever is accompanied by relative bradycardia which is known as the Faget sign. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots that fade on pressure appear on the skin during the second or third week. Since bile is a good culture medium for the bacilli, they multiply abundantly in the gallbladder and are discharged continuously into the intestine. In the intestine, it causes inflammation and necrosis leaving behind the characteristic typhoid ulcers which are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers). Ulceration of the bowel leads to two major complications- intestinal perforation and hemorrhage. Option B: In intestinal tuberculosis, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers). Option C: Flask shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis. Option D: Hemorrhagic colitis is caused by Shigella dysenteriae and some strains of E. coli. It is characterised by bloody diarrhea with tenesmus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: While evaluating a patient suspected to have enteric fever, you order a widely used tube agglutination test in the second week of his illness. Which of the following statements regarding this test is false?
options: H agglutinin titer > 160 and O agglutinin titer > 80 is considered significant
O antibody cannot differentiate between Salmonella types.
O antibody lasts longer and hence is not indicative of recent infection.
High titer value in a single test is not confirmative.
explanation: The tube agglutination test which is widely used for the diagnosis of enteric fever is the Widal test. The O antibodies detected via this test disappear within a few weeks of disease resolution and so are indicative of recent infection. Widal test is a serological test for the measurement of O and H antigens of Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi present in the patient's serum. Four antigens are used- O antigens of S. typhi (TO), H antigens of S. typhi (TH), H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH) and H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH). Paratyphoid O antigens cross-reacts with the typhoid O antigen due to the sharing of factor 12. It is not used in the test and thus, O antibody cannot differentiate between Salmonella types. H agglutinin titer > 160 and O agglutinin titer > 80 is considered significant. However, a 4-fold rise in titers between 1st and 3rd week is more significant compared to a single high titer because of the possibility of an anamnestic reaction - a transient rise of titer due to unrelated infections (malaria, dengue) in persons who had a prior enteric fever. After one week interval, if the titer increases, it indicates true infection. If the titer decreases, it indicates an anamnestic reaction.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young man with fever for 2 weeks has the following serology findings. Which of the given statements is true about the disease he has?
options: Intestinal perforation following infection with S.typhi occurs in the 1st week.
Faget’s sign is seen in enteric fever.
In Widal test, Felix tube is used to detect H antigen.
Blood culture is the gold standard of diagnosis
explanation: Widal results showing titers for O antibody >80 and H antibody for S.typhi to be >160 is suggestive of enteric fever. Faget's sign is seen in enteric fever. Enteric fever, caused by Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C, presents with step ladder pyrexia. The fever rises one day and falls the subsequent morning. It continues to form peaks and troughs. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots that fade on pressure appear on the skin during the second or third week. Faget's sign is the unusual pairing of fever with bradycardia (relative bradycardia) instead of tachycardia. It is also observed in yellow fever, brucellosis, and tularemia. Intestinal perforation (option A) is a complication of enteric fever caused by Salmonella typhi. It occurs in the 3rd week following infection. Widal test is a serological test used for the diagnosis of enteric fever during the 2nd week. It measures the levels of H and O antigens in the patient's serum. Bone marrow culture is the gold standard (option D) for diagnosis of enteric fever. Blood culture is most commonly performed to confirm the diagnosis, however, bone marrow is more sensitive. subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient, suspected to have enteric fever, has been started on ceftriaxone by his local village healer 2 days ago. Which investigation will confirm his diagnosis at this stage?
explanation: Bone marrow culture is preferred at this stage. Bone marrow culture is the most sensitive test (>80% sensitivity) for diagnosis of enteric fever. It remains positive for upto 5 days after starting antibiotics, unlike blood culture. Hence, it is preferred in the patient above who has been on antibiotics for 2 days. Blood culture has a sensitivity of about 60% for diagnosis of enteric fever. Its sensitivity drops with duration of illness, and is thus useful onlyduring the 1st week of enteric fever. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics. Stool culture has a sensitivity of 30% and only yields positive results from the 2nd or 3rd week onwards. Urine culture has low sensitivity and may be positive only after the 2nd week. Note: The sensitivity of diagnostic methods for enteric fever is duodenal content culture > bone marrow culture > blood culture. However, duodenal content culture is rarely done in clinical practice.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You are administering a Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine to a child in Germany before his trip to India. Which of the following is false about the antigen used in this vaccine?
explanation: Vi capsule polysaccharide antigen is a heat-labile antigen used in the Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine (ViCPS) for typhoid. Vi antigen is found in Salmonella typhi, S. paratyphi C and S. dublin. It is a capsular antigen and is a polysaccharide. It acts as a virulence factor by inhibiting phagocytosis and resisting complement activation and bacterial lysis. It envelopes the O antigen, and thus, many S. typhi strains fail to agglutinate with O antiserum. However, it can be destroyed by heat. It is alcohol stable. This antigen is poorly immunogenic. The Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine (Vi CPS) contains purified Vi polysaccharide. It is given as a single dose of 0.5ml intramuscularly to children over 2 years of age. It is recommended for travellers to areas endemic for Salmonella infections.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A man living in the UK is planning to travel to India. His doctor prescribes the necessary vaccines prior to travel including an oral typhoid vaccine. What is the schedule for this vaccine?
explanation: The oral typhoid vaccine is given on days 1, 3, 5, and 7. Typhoral or Ty21a is a live attenuated oral typhoid vaccine. It is given in 4 doses given on days 1, 3, 5, and 7. No antibiotics should be given during this period. < is indicated only in individuals over 6 years of age. Protective immunity starts after 7 days of the last dose and lasts for 4 years. Ty21a can also be administered to HIV-positive, asymptomatic individuals as long as their CD4 count is above 200/mm3. It is contraindicated in immunocompromised patients.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults?
explanation: Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever. Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of Salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual clinical cases. question_text:
A patient developed fever and diarrhoea after consumption of undercooked eggs. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
Gastroenteritis due to non-typhoidal salmonellosis is usually self limited.
options: Stool cultures remain positive for 4-5 weeks after infection.
Most common isolate from stool culture is Salmonella enteritidis.
Non-typhoidal salmonellosis can be acquired from multiple animal reservoirs.
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of non-typhoidal salmonellosis (NTS). The most common organism isolated in NTS from stool culture is Salmonella typhimurium. Nontyphoidal salmonellosis refers to illnesses caused by all serotypes of Salmonella except for Salmonella typhi, Salmonella paratyphi A, B, and C. Transmission of nontyphoidal salmonellosis occurs usually through the consumption of food or water contaminated with animal feces. Transmission may also occur through food products, especially eggs, poultry, undercooked ground meat, and hence multiple animals act as reservoirs for non-typhoidal salmonella. Gastroenteritis is the most common clinical presentation of NTS. The illness usually lasts 4–7 days, and most people recover without treatment. Culturing organisms continues to be the mainstay of clinical diagnostic testing for nontyphoidal salmonella infection. Approximately 90% of isolates are obtained from routine stool culture until 4-5 weeks after infection. Vibrio and Campylobacterales

question_text: A child presents with profuse, painless diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows the following finding. What is this characteristic appearance called?
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae. The image shows the characteristic fish in stream appearance of Vibrio. Other options: Options A and B: School of fish appearance and railroad appearance are shown by Haemophilus ducreyi. Option D: Drumstick appearance is shown by Clostridium tetani due to its spherical and terminal spores.

question_text: While studying the microscopic features of Vibrio cholerae, you observe the following finding. What type of motility can you see here?
explanation: The given microscopic finding shows the darting motility characteristic of Vibrio cholerae. Vibrio cholerae is actively motile with a polar flagellum. The actively motile vibrios appear like a 'swarm of gnats'.

question_text: On the basis of which antigen is Vibrio cholerae classified under the Sakazaki typing scheme?
explanation: Vibrio cholerae are classified based on O antigen, under Sakazaki typing scheme. Based on the presence or absence of O antigen, V. cholerae is classified as O1 which agglutinate with antisera to O1 group (agglutinable vibrios) and non-O1, which do not agglutinate with antisera to O1 group (non-agglutinable vibrios). As per the Gardner and Venkatraman classification, Vibrios are classified into Group A (V. cholerae) and Group B (others) based on H antigen or flagellar antigen. Gardner and Venkatraman classification:

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding non-agglutinable vibrios?
options: They belong to serogroup O2 – O200
They are not agglutinated by O-1 antiserum
These are similar to V. cholera in most cultural and biochemical reactions
explanation: Non-agglutinable vibrios are non-pathogenic (except O139) and hence, they are called non-cholera vibrios. The vibrios which are not agglutinated by O-1 antiserum are called non-agglutinable (NAG) vibrios. They belong to the serogroups O2–O200 of which only serogroup O-139 is known to cause epidemics of cholera. They are similar to Vibrio cholerae in most biochemical reactions and culture characteristics, except that they are hemolytic to sheep erythrocytes and give a positive Voges-Proskauer reaction.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A microbiologist studying Vibrio cholera added sulphuric acid to a 24-hour peptone culture of the organism and a reddish-pink color developed. Which of the following is true about the test he performed?
options: It is known as methyl red test
A nitrosoindole compound is formed giving it the red colour
The red colour is obtained due to pigment production by the bacteria
The red colour is obtained due to acid & gas production by Vibrio
explanation: The test described here is the 'cholera red reaction' given by Vibrio cholera. When few drops of concentrated sulphuric acid are added to a 24-hour peptone water culture, a reddish-pink colour develops due to the formation of nitrosoindole. Vibrio cholerae reduce nitrates to nitrites and convert tryptophan to indole. These two properties contribute to the cholera red reaction. Other options: Option A: The methyl red (MR) test is used to detect the production of sufficient acid during the fermentation of glucose by bacteria. It is used to classify Enterobacteriacae. Option C: Vibrio cholera does not produce any colored pigment. Option D: Vibrio ferments carbohydrates leading to production of acid but no gas.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A 20-year-old woman presents with complaints of passing profuse loose stools which looked like rice water for the past 3 days. There's a history of similar symptoms in the family. Stool samples were sent to the lab for analysis and the test given in the image is performed.
Identify this test.
explanation: The given case scenario of passing profuse rice-water stools with similar complaints in the family suggests a probable diagnosis of cholera. The test shown in the above image is the string test and it is performed to identify Vibrio cholerae. To perform the string test, a loopful of the bacterial culture is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The bacterial cells of Vibrio cholerae are lysed by sodium deoxycholate, causing the suspension to lose its turbidity and become mucoid. A string is formed when the loop is drawn away from the suspension. Note: The duodenal string test refers to the Entero test performed for the diagnosis of giardiasis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following bacteria is not microaerophilic?
explanation: Vibrio cholera is a facultative anaerobe and is not microaerophilic.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio?
explanation: The disruption of zonula occludens is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae. Zonula occludens toxin (Zot) is an enterotoxin elaborated by Vibrio cholerae that increases intestinal permeability by interacting with a mammalian cell receptor with subsequent activation of intracellular signaling leading to the disassembly of the intercellular tight junctions. Mechanism of action of cholera toxin: The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to th GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit, on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit. A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes. This leads to watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate. The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride. All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and lectrolyte depletion thus caused.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young child was brought to the ER with a history of loose stools. On examination, she is tachycardic, appears lethargic and skin goes back slowly after the skin pinch test. She was admitted and started on IV fluids and input-output charting was done. The given image shows stool output from the patient. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for the same?
options: Toxin causes Increased guanyl cyclase activity
The toxin causes continued activation of adenylate cyclas
explanation: The given clinical scenario of dehydration, profuse diarrhea, and rice water stools is suggestive of cholera. Cholera toxin causes continued activation of adenylate cyclase. Mechanism of action of cholera toxin: The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to th GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit, on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit. A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes and th consequent watery diarrhea, that is isotonic with plasma but contains much more of potassium and bicarbonate. The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride. All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and lectrolyte depletion thus caused.

question_text: Which of the following does not play a role in the virulence of Vibrio cholerae?
explanation: Vibrio cholerae possesses lipopolysaccharide (LPS) O antigen but it plays no role in the pathogenesis of cholera. It is responsible for the immunity induced by killed vaccines. Factors involved in virulence of Vibrio cholerae: In the small intestine, vibrios can cross the protective layer of mucus and reach the epithelial cells by using mucinase and other proteolytic enzymes. Toxin co-regulated pilus(TCP), is essential for the adhesion to the epithelial surface and colonization of the bacteria in small intestine. Cholera toxin (also known as choleragen and cholera enterotoxin) causes watery diarrhea through cAMP-mediated pathway.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An El Tor vibrio was identified to be the causative agent of a diarrhea epidemic. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of this organism?
options: Resistant to El Tor phage V
Not susceptible to group IV phag
explanation: El Tor vibrios are susceptible to El Tor phage V.

question_text: You are a medical officer at a district hospital and receive 13 patients with rice-water diarrhea and dehydration. You suspect cholera and want to send the stool samples to the hospital lab. Which of the following media will you not use?
explanation: Nutrient agar is not used to transport Vibrio cholerae. It is a simple media used to grow non-fastidious organisms, but not to transport them. Transport media for Vibrio cholerae: Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan (VR) medium Cary-Blair medium If the specimen can reach the laboratory in a few hours, it may also be transported in enrichment media. Examples include: Alkaline peptone water Monsur's medium. If transport media are not available, strips of blotting paper may be soaked in the watery stool and sent to the laboratory packed in plastic envelopes.

question_text: Which of the following bacteria shows Kanagawa phenomenon?
explanation: Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It refers to hemolysis occuring when the bacteria are inoculated on Wagatsuma agar. Pathogenic strains of V. parahaemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This phenomenon occurs due to a heat-stable hemolysin.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An outbreak of food poisoning in a coastal city is determined to be due to contaminated seafood. The causative bacteria formed the following colonies on TCBS agar and showed hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following statements regarding the organism implicated here is false?
options: It produces peritrichous flagella on solid medium
It gives a positive string test
explanation: The given case scenario of an organism that caused food poisoning due to contaminated seafood in addition to the cultural characteristics is suggestive of food contamination by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It is a capsulated organism. V. parahaemolyticus is an enteropathogenic halophilic vibrio that is an important cause of food poisoning throughout the world. It inhabits the coastal seas, where it is found in shrimps, crabs, and oysters. It forms opaque green colonies with a raised centre and flat translucent periphery on TCBS agar unlike V. cholera which forms yellow colonies. Pathogenic strains show hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar which is known as Kanagawa phenomenon. This can be used as a test for pathogenecity. Other options: Option B: It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency for pleomorphism, especially when grown on 3% salt agar. Option C: Unlike other vibrios, it produces peritrichous flagella when grown on solid media. Polar flagella are formed in liquid cultures. Option D: String test is positive like with V. cholera.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following vibrios has the highest salt tolerance?
explanation: Vibrio with the highest salt tolerance of up to 10% NaCl is Vibrio alginolyticus. The salt tolerances of vibrio species are as follows: V. cholerae optimally grows at 0.5–1% NaCl concentration. Its growth is inhibited by high concentration of >6% NaCl. V. mimicus grows best at low salt concentrations of 0.5-1% like V. cholerae. V. parahaemolyticus grows optimally salt concentration of 2-4 %. It has a salt tolerance up to 8%. V. vulnificus has a salt tolerance similar to V. parahaemolyticus. V. alginolyticus has the highest salt tolerance of up to 10% NaCl.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A fisherman presented to the ER with a wound on his left leg. He tells you he had got a small cut a week back that got worse after his recent fishing trip. On examination, you note vesicles and bullae around the wound. Specimen taken from the bullae revealed lactose-fermenting colonies. What is the causative agent?
explanation: The given case scenario of contact with seawater of an existing wound leading to cellulitis by a lactose-fermenting bacteria suggests infection with Vibrio vulnificus. V. vulnificus ferments lactose but not sucrose. It has a salt tolerance of up to 8%. Infection with V. vulnificus can manifest in 2 ways: Soft-tissue infections can occur after contact with seawater and progress to cellulitis. Primary septicemia can occur in patients, typically with underlying liver disease, who hav acquired the organism through the gastrointestinal tract after recent consumption of raw shellfish. Note: V. cholerae, V. parahaemolyticus, and V. alginolyticus do not ferment lactose although lactose may be split very slowly by V. cholerae.

question_text: All of the following are correctly matched except:
options: Vibrio alginolyticus - Infections of the eyes, ears and wounds
explanation: Vibrio vulnificus causes wound infection following contact of open wounds with sea water. In immunocompromised hosts, and particularly those with liver disease, it penetrates the gut mucosa following ingestion. It may not cause any gastrointestinal manifestations and directly enters the bloodstream, leading to the rapid development of septicemia with high mortality. Other options: Option A: V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning associated with marine food. It also causes acute diarrhea, unassociated with food poisoning. Option B: V. alginolyticus has been associated with infections of the eyes, ears, and wounds in human beings exposed to seawater. Option D: Cholera is caused by V. cholerae via its toxin but it does not cause dysentery which is characterized by bloody diarrhea. It is mainly associated with watery diarrhea.

question_text: A 17-year-old presents to you with complaints of passing loose stools. Given below are the findings of his stool microscopy. Infection with which of the following bacteria would you consider in your differential diagnosis?
explanation: The given clip shows darting motility which is seen in Vibrio cholerae and Campylobacter jejuni. Thus, among the given options, infection with C. jejuni should be considered as a differential diagnosis in this case. Campylobacter jejuni possesses a single polar flagellum, hence it exhibits darting motility. Shigella dysenteriae is a non-motile organism.

question_text: A young man presented with complaints of a tingling sensation in his hands and feet. He also complains of weakness in his legs that is slowly spreading to his upper body. He had an episode of bloody diarrhea 10 days ago. Which of the following organisms is the likely cause of this patient's condition?
explanation: The given case scenario with ascending paralysis is suggestive of the development Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) following diarrhea. The organism that likely caused this patients condition is Campylobacter jejuni, which can cause diarrhea and trigger GBS. Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. Growth occurs under microaerophilic conditions. The organism also shows darting motility. Asymptomatic campylobacter infection also may trigger Guillain-Barré syndrome. Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. In C. jejuni infection, bacterial lipopolysaccharide triggers an autoimmune respons against axons via molecular mimicry, hence causing GBS. Other organisms associated with GBS include cytomegalovirus, M. pneumonia, and Epstein-Barr virus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young man presented with bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and fever. Lab investigations showed leucocytosis and stool microscopy revealed RBCs and leucocytes. Darkfield microscopy showed a bacteria having darting motility. Which of the following is a selective culture medium for this organism?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of fever, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and leucocytosis alongwith microscopy findings of RBCs and WBCs in fecal smear, and organism having darting motility are suggestive of infection with Campylobacter jejuni. The selective culture medium used for Campylobacter is Skirrow’s media. Other selective media for Campylobacter include: Butzler's medium Campy-BAP media The transport medium used for Campylobacter is the Cary-Blair medium.

question_text: Identify the organism & the stain seen in the image given below.
explanation: The given image shows Helicobacter pylori stained using Warthin-Starry stain. H.pylori is a Gram-negative spiral rod that is motile by a unipolar tuft of lophotrichous flagella. The bacteria are present only in the mucus overlying the gastric mucosa and do not actually invade into the mucosa. The given image shows Helicobacter pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

question_text: Which of the following organisms produce urease?
explanation: Helicobacter pylori produces urease. Urease-producing organisms: (Mnemonic-PUNCH) Proteus Ureaplasma urealyticum Nocardia Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum H. pylori

question_text:
You are a surgery resident evaluating a 45-year-old female patient with complaints of burning abdominal pain for the past 2 months that is relieved on taking food. You determine the disease to have a bacterial etiology. Which of the following is the most sensitive test to detect the causative organism here?
Cultur
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a duodenal ulcer caused by Helicobacter pylori. The urea breath test is the most sensitive test for the diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori infection. To perform this test, the patient drinks a urea solution labelled with radioactive carbon-14. The patient then blows into a tube. If H. pylori urease is present, the urea is hydrolyzed, and labelled carbon dioxide is detected in breath samples. The sensitivity of the urea breath test is >90%. Pseudomonas and Burkholderiales
