question_text: A 20 year old male presents with acute onset cough and thick sticky sputum. There is a history of repeated lung infections since childhood. Chest Xray shows evidence of bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis. On evaluation, the chloride concentration in his sweat is >60 mEq/L. What is the organism majorly associated with this patient's respiratory disease?
explanation: Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis with a history of repeated lung infections since childhood and evelated sweat chloride concentration suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common etiological agent associated with chronic airway infection in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). In cystic fibrosis, there is thick inspissated mucus and impaired mucociliary clearance. Due to these factors, lungs are often colonized in infancy and early childhood with Staphylococcus aureus and Haemophilus influenzae. In adulthood, they are replaced by P. aeruginosa. This results in chronic inflammation, which leads to airway modelling and bronchiectasis. Note: Burkholderia cepacia complex is an opportunistic environmental pathogen. It causes fata respiratory distress and septicemia in CF patients. This is termed as 'cepacia syndrome'.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning?
explanation: Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that have not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. There is consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine. A second compound is thought to play a causative role in this intoxication because large doses of oral histamine do not reproduce the affliction. The toxin or toxins involved are heat stable and are not destroyed by cooking or freezing. Symptoms develop within 15–90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8–12 h.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient comes to the dermatology OPD complaining of greenish discoloration of her nails. You diagnose her with green nail syndrome. Production of which of the following helps differentiate the organism implicated here from other members of its genus?
explanation: Green nail syndrome is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Production of pyocyanin helps differentiate it implicated here from other Pseudomonas species. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the only member of the Pseudomonas species that produces pyocyanin which is a bluish-green pigment. Other species of Pseudomonas also produce pigments but they cannot produce pyocyanin. Some of the other pigments produced by Pseudomonas species including P. aeruginosa are pyoverdin/flourescein (greenish-yellow pigment), pyorubin (red pigment) and pyomelanin (brown pigment).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The mechanism of action of exotoxin A of Pseudomonas resembles that of .
explanation: The action of exotoxin A of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is similar to that of the diphtheria toxin. Both exotoxin A and diphtheria toxin cause ADP ribosylation of EF-2 and inhibit protein synthesis. Exotoxin A is a single-chain polypeptide with A and B fragments. The B fragment binds the toxin while the A fragment inactivates EF-2 in the presence of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD). This leads to the inhibition of polypeptide chain elongation and thus, protein synthesis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient with acute onset fever, cough and hemoptysis is diagnosed to have Whitmore's disease. Which of the following organisms causes this condition?
explanation: Burkholderia pseudomallei causes Whitmore's disease. Melioidosis was first described by Whitmore and Krishnaswami. Whitmore isolated the bacillus, and hence, it is known as Whitmore bacillus and melioidosis is called Whitmore's disease. Melioidosis is similar in presentation to glanders disease (caused by Burkholderia mallei). Humans are infected tby contact with contaminated soil via skin abrasions. Types of melioidosis: Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs. The bacillus has a safety-pin appearance on methylene blue staining. Treatment is divided into two stages: an intensive 2 week phase of ceftazidime or a carbapenem followed by at least 12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A horse-groomer was diagnosed with ulcerative tracheobronchitis. Upon enquiry, it was discovered that one of his horses had recently died of pneumonia after developing a fever and subcutaneous nodules. Which of the following statements is false about the likely causative agent?
options: It is the causative agent for Glanders disease.
It induces Strauss reaction on inoculation into guinea pigs.
explanation: The development of ulcerative tracheobronchitis after contact with an infected horse is suggestive of glanders which is caused by Burkholderia mallei. It is an oxidase variable organism. In this case, the horse likely had glanders, which presents with fever, pneumonia, and subcutaneous nodules called Farcy buds. Discharges from the respiratory tract and skin are highly infectious and can be transmitted to humans through close contact (occupational route). The horse-groomer likely contracted the infection by the inhalational route and developed acute glanders, which is characterised by fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge and ulcerative necrosis of upper respiratory tract (ulcerative tracheobronchitis). It may lead to septicemia and has a high fatality rate. Percutaneous exposure causes local suppurative skin lesions with associated regional lymphadenopathy. B. mallei is a non-motile Gram-negative bacillus causing Glanders disease. It is an aerobe and a facultative anaerobe. It is oxidase variable i.e. it is usually oxidase negative but may occasionally show a positive reaction. It is a biosafety level 3 pathogen and so must be handled only in specialised laboratories. When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with suspected infectious material, it causes Strauss reaction. B. mallei sets up a necrotizing inflammation in the scrotal sac within a few days and can be confirmed bacteriologically.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to?
explanation: Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to cefotetan. B. cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides, polymixin, first and second-generation cephalosporins (e.g. cefotetan) and carboxypenicillins. This antimicrobial resistance is mediated by efflux pumps, antimicrobial degradation, modifying enzymes or altered membrane functions. B. cepacia is a Gram-negative bacillus which can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis. Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include meropenem, ceftazidime, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, piperacillin and temocillin.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An organism cultured in Bordet–Gengou medium shows smooth, refractile, glistening colonies resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops'. The organism is most likely .
explanation: The organism showing colonies resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops' on Bordet-Gengou medium most likely is Bordetella pertussis. Bordetella pertussis is a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It causes whooping cough or pertussis in children. It can be isolated on the enriched medium Bordet-Genou medium (potato-blood-glycerol agar). After incubation for 48 to 72 hours, B. pertussis colonies are small, dome-shaped, smooth, opaque, viscid, greyish white, refractile, and glistening resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops' and are surrounded by a hazy zone of hemolysis. If growth is confluent, an 'aluminium paint' appearance is seen. In culture films, Bordetella pertussis bacilli tend to be arranged in loose clumps, with clear spaces in between, giving a 'thumbprint' appearance. B. parapertussis (option A) grows on nutrient agar with the production of a brown, diffusible pigment after two days. It also grows more rapidly than B.pertussis on charcoal blood agar.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An 8-year-old boy with incomplete vaccination history comes with vomiting after bouts of severe, violent cough. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for this child's disease?
options: Activation of phospholipase and degrades cell membrane
explanation: Post-tussive vomiting and bouts of cough in an unimmunized child points to a diagnosis of pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis. It secretes pertussis toxin (PT), which acts by ADP ribosylation and disrupts signal transduction of many cell types. This promotes lymphocytosis. The pertussis toxin disrupts protein synthesis and causes necrosis of parts of the epithelium, leading to pseudomembrane formation. Pertussis toxin also promotes sensitization to histamine and enhances insulin secretion but these effects have not been demonstrable in patients. They are only seen in experimental animals. B. pertussis also produces other toxins like: Adenylate cyclase toxin (ACT)- It acts by catalysing the production of cAMP by various types of cells and inhibiting phagocytosis. Heat labile toxin (HLT)- It is a cytoplasmic protein present in all bordetellae. It is dermonecrotic and lethal in mice. Its pathogenic role is not known. Tracheal cytotoxin (TCT)- It is low molecular weight peptidoglycan which induces ciliary damage in hamster trachea.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about pertussis toxin?
options: It is expressed on the surface of the bacillus.
"A" portion of A-B structure is the enzymatically active moiety.
It is similar to cholera toxin in its structure and function.
explanation: Pertussis toxin (PT) can be toxoided. PT is one of the toxins produced by Bordetella pertussis. It is expressed on the surface of the bacillus and secreted into the surrounding medium. It has an A-B structure, the A portion being the enzymatically active moiety and B, the binding component. PT is similar to cholera toxin in its structure and function. PT has ADP-ribosylating activity and acts on inhibitory Gi  subunit of G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR), whereas cholera toxin acts on stimulatory Gs  subunit of GPCR. Pertussis toxoid is the major component of the acellular pertussis vaccine. A toxoid is a toxin that has lost its toxicity but retains its antigenicity.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 4-year-old unimmunized child presents with whooping cough. Which of the following constituents of the causative organism is responsible for facilitating its adhesion to the respiratory epithelium?
explanation: Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis. Filamentous hemagglutinin (FHA) is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium. Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins: Pertussis toxin (PT), lipid factor and FHA. FHA is a surface protein and is readily shed. Along with fimbrae, it helps in the adhesion of B. pertussis to the cilia of the respiratory epithelium and to erythrocytes. FHA and PT also promote secondary infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci. They then assists their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of adhesins'.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the incubation period of pertussis in humans?
explanation: The incubation period of pertussis in humans is 7-14 days. Pertussis is caused by Bordetella pertussis. After the incubation period, the disease takes a protracted course comprising three stages: Catarrhal: It lasts 1-2 weeks and is characterized by coryza, lacrimation, mild cough, low-grade fever, and malaise. Paroxysmal: It lasts 2-4 weeks with the cough becoming more frequent and spasmodic. The cough comes in repetitive bursts of 5–10 in number, often within a single expiration. Post-tussive vomiting is frequent. The episode may be terminated by an audible whoop, which occurs upon rapid inspiration against a closed glottis at the end of a paroxysm. Convalescent: It lasts 1–3 months and is characterized by gradual resolution of coughing episodes. Whooping cough is also known as '100-day cough'. For 6–12 months following the illness, intercurrent viral infections may be associated with a recrudescence of paroxysmal cough.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You are evaluating a 6-year-old unimmunised girl with cough and abdominal pain. Her mother informs you that her daughter has bouts of violent coughing which frequently ends with a loud whoop and is accompanied by vomiting. She gives history of similar complaints in a classmate 2-3 weeks back. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
explanation: The given case scenario of whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting, and abdominal pain, along with positive history of exposure in an unimmunised child is suggestive of pertussis. Erythromycin or one of the newer macrolides such as azithromycin or clarithromycin is the drug of choice for the treatment of this condition. Antibiotic therapy in pertussis is used to eradicate the bacteria from the nasopharynx. The treatment is beneficial if it is started within 10 days of the disease. Macrolides are the drugs of choice. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is recommended as an alternative for individuals allergic to macrolides. Macrolides may also be used in the chemoprophylaxis of pertussis. Post-exposure prophylaxis is given to household close contacts, and high-risk contacts (infants, immunocompromised, pregnancy).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young child with unknown immunization history is suspected to have whooping cough. Which of the following methods will you prefer to use to collect a specimen for culture?
explanation: Whooping cough is caused by Bordotella pertussis. The most effective method for collecting a specimen for the culture of this organism is the per-nasal or nasopharyngeal swab method. Respiratory specimens may be collected for the culture (gold standard) of Bordetella pertussis by three different methods: Per-nasal swab: A Dacron or rayon tipped swab on a flexible nichrome wire is passed along the floor of the nasal cavity and material is collected from the pharyngeal wall. This specimen is the most effective and best suited for diagnostic procedures. Cough plate method: A culture plate is held about 10 to 15 cms in front of the patient's mouth during a bout of cough. Post-nasal (peroral) method: Secretions from the posterior pharyngeal wall are collected with a cotton swab on a bent wire passed through the mouth. Other diagnostic tests for pertussis include direct fluorescent aantibody test and PCR on nasopharyngeal specimens. Enzyme immunoassays of antibodies after exposure to B. pertussis can also be used for patients between 2-4 weeks of illness.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A pregnant woman comes to the ANC clinic for her 2nd dose of the Tdap vaccine. Which of the following constitutes the acellular component of this vaccine?
Pertactin, filamentous hemaglutinin, and cytotoxin
options: Pertussis toxoid, filamentous hemaglutinin, and fimbrial protein
explanation: Tdap vaccine is the tetanus, diphtheria and acellular pertussis vaccine. The component of the acellular pertussis vaccine is inactivated pertussis toxin (PT) and it may contain one or more bacterial components such as pertactin, filamentous hemagglutinin, and fimbrial protein. Pertussis vaccine is usually administered in combination with the toxoids of diphtheria and tetanus (DTaP). Five doses of pertussis vaccine are recommended - at 2, 4, 6 and 15–18 months of age followed by a booster dose at 4–6 years of age. Tdap is now also recommended for pregnant women in between 27 weeks and 36 weeks of gestation by the ACOG. This is because infants between the age of 0-2 months are vulnerable to pertussis as they do not begin their vaccine schedule before 6 weeks of age. Thus to protect these infants, placental transfer of maternal pertussis antibodies has proven to be the most effective approach. Children under 4 years who are contacts of patients should receive a booster even if they had been previously immunized. Non-immunized contacts should receive full series of vaccination and also chemoprophylaxis with erythromycin for 10 days after contact with the patient has ceased. Haemophilus

question_text: A woman presents with fever with chills and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of lobar pneumonia. She had undergone splenectomy 2 years back. Sputum culture on blood agar shows the following. What is the causative agent?
explanation: The given scenario of bacterial pneumonia in a splenectomised individual along with the image showing satellitism on blood agar points towards an infection due to Hemophilus influenzae. Pneumonia can occur as a part of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). This is a fatal post-splenectomy complication occuring due to infections with encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis. It can be prevented by vaccinating against these organisms within 2 weeks of undergoing splenectomy. Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Factor V is required for the growth of H. influenzae. The given image shows satellitism on blood agar

question_text: A patient presented with fever, seizures, and altered sensorium. Gram stain of the CSF is given below. Satellitism was seen on blood agar. Which of the following statements is false about this disease?
options: This is the most serious disease produced by this organism.
The disease is more common in young adults.
The bacilli reach the meninges from the nasopharynx through the bloodstream.
Cefotaxime is the drug of choic
explanation: The given scenario and the image showing gram-negative coccobacilli in the CSF are suggestive of hemophilus meningitis caused by H.influenzae. Hemophilus meningitis is more common in children between 3 months and 3 years of age and not common in young adults. Other options: Option A: Meningitis is the most serious disease caused by H. influenzae. The case fatality rate is 90% if untreated. Option C: H. influenze is transmitted via respiratory droplets. Thus, it is introduced into the nasopharynx of the contacts of an infected individual. It has to enter the bloodstream to reach the meninges. Option D: Cefotaxime or ceftazidime are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hemophilus meningitis.

question_text: Which of the following is not caused by non-typable H. influenzae?
explanation: Meningitis is caused by typable H. influenzae. Non-typable H. influenzae cause: Otitis media Sinusitis Puerperal sepsis Exacerbations of COPD. H. influenzae is typed into 6 serotypes (a to f) based on the capsular polysaccharide. Serotype b (Hib) is the most virulent and accounts for most of the invasive infections. explanation: Hemophilus parahemolyticus requires only factor V for its growth. It does not require factors X. question_text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency with acute stridor. The mother gives a history of fever, drooling, and breathing difficulty since that morning. An X-ray of her neck appears as given below. What is the most likely causative agent?
explanation: The given clinical vignette and 'thumb sign' on the X-ray are suggestive of acute epiglottitis caused by Hemophilus influenzae. It is an acute inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis and presents with high fever, severe sore throat, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting for ease of breathing. The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (Thumb sign). The below image shows the Thumb sign. In some countries, widespread vaccination against Hib has drastically decreased acute epiglottitis cases in children by over 90%. However, the incidence in adults has remained largely unchanged since the Hib vaccine was introduced. Despite vaccination efforts, many pediatric cases of epiglottitis today are still caused by Hib due to either lack of vaccination or vaccine ineffectiveness. In adults and increasingly in children, other bacterial pathogens, particularly group A Streptococcus, have been linked to cases of epiglottitis. Treatment includes airway management followed by administration of antibiotics like ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, or ceftriaxone.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive is:
explanation: Pneumonia due to a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive is most likely Haemophilus influenza. Haemophilus pneumonia typically occurs in infants and is accompanied by empyema and sometimes meningitis as well. In older children and adults, the picture is of lobar pneumonia. Sputum is collected for the detection and isolation of Hemophilus. As the bacillus is very sensitive to low temperatures, specimens should never be refrigerated before inoculation. H.infiuenzae is a Gram-negative, non-motile, non-sporing bacillus, exhibiting considerable pleomorphism. In sputum, it usually occurs as clusters of coccobacillary forms. The bacillus has fastidious growth requirements. The accessory growth factors, named X and V, present in the blood are essential for growth. Catalase and oxidase reactions are positive. Nitrates are reduced to nitrites. Biotyping has been done on the basis of indole production. Cultures may be preserved for about a month on chocolate agar slopes. Chocolate agar is made by heating blood agar to 80-90°C for 15-20 minutes. This causes the release of V factor from within the erythrocytes. Treatment- Amoxycillin-clavulanate or clarithromycin is more effective in treating respiratory infections by Haemophilus influenzae.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A middle-aged man who is a known case of diabetes and chronic bronchitis presents to the OPD with low-grade fever and productive cough for 5 days. Which of the following is not a
virulence factor of the likely causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical scenario describes an acute exacerbation of COPD characterized by low-grade fever, increased cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath. The most common cause of these are non-typable H. influenzae which lack a capsule and so capsular antigen cannot be a virulence factor. All H. influenzae have the following virulence factors: Outer membrane proteins (OMP) Lipooligosaccharide(LOS) Pili In addition to the above factors, H. influenzae type b also has its capsular polysaccharide as a virulence factor. The differences between Hib and non-typable strains are given below: Feature Type b strains Nontypable strains Capsule Made of Ribosyl-ribitol phos phate Unencapsulated Pathogenesis Invasive infections due to he matogenous spread Mucosal infections due to co ntagious spread Clinical manifestations Meningitis and invasive infec tions incompletely immunize d infants and childrenEpiglot titisCellulitisPneumonia Otitis media in childrenExace rbation of COPD,Puerperal s epsisSinusitis Vaccine Highly effective conjugate va ccines Not available

question_text: Which of the following bacteria does not belong to the HACEK group?
explanation: Escherichia coli does not belong to the HACEK group. The acronym HACEK refers to a group of fastidious slow-growing bacteria, normally residing in the mouth. These can sometimes cause severe infections, particularly culture-negative subacute bacterial endocarditis. The group includes: Haemophilus species (H. parainfluenzae, H. aphrophilus, H. paraphrophilus) Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans (previously called as Actinobacillus) Cardiobacterium hominis Eikenella corrodens Kingella kinga
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 26-year-old man presented with painful, bleeding genital ulcers. On examination, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Scraping from the ulcer base was taken and the microscopic appearance of the Gram-stained smear is shown below. What is the causative organism?
explanation: The image shows the' school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi. This appearance is seen when the bacilli are arranged in small groups, whorls or in chains. The given case scenario is suggestive of chancroid. Chancroid is characterized by non-indurated, tender, irregular ulcers that may bleed on touch. The neighbouring lymph nodes are enlarged, painful, and tender. Other options: Option B - Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, characterised by chancre - a single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border, with painless lymphadenopathy. Persistent or multiple chancres may be seen in HIV-infected or other immunodeficient patients. Options C and D - Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2 and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum, characterised by shallow, painless ulcers that progress to painful lymphadenopathy.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The following are true about chancroid:
explanation: Chancroid is a painful genital ulcer caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, which is a gram-negative coccobacillus. Microscopic appearance of H. ducreyi is called the school of fish appearance or railroad appearance. Chancroid ulcers have a soft base that bleeds easily to touch. They also cause painful lymphadenopathy. The image below shows the 'school-of-fish' appearance characteristic of H. ducreyi. Note: Groove sign is a characteristic sign seen in lymphogranuloma venereum. It refers to the depression created by the inguinal ligament as it passes between the groups of inflamed inguinal lymph nodes.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis?
explanation: Haemophilus ducreyi does not cause urethritis. It causes chancroid (soft chancre), which presents as a genital ulcer. Urethritis is classified into two types: Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhoea. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by: Chlamydia trachomatis (most common) Ureaplasma urealyticum Adenovirus Haemophilus vaginalis Mycoplasma genitalium Tricomonas vaginalis (rare) Herpes simplex virus (rare)
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A 5-year-old girl presents with conjunctivitis, fever, and hemorrhagic skin lesions. There's a history of travel to Brazil. Which of the following etiological agents would you suspect in this case?
Haemophilus influenzae type A
Haemophilus parahaemolyticus
Haemophilus aegypticus
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of Brazilian purpuric fever (BPF) caused by Haemophilus aegypticus (Koch-Weeks bacillus). Recent DNA studies have shown that the bacillus is identical to non-capsulated H.influenzae and it is now named H.influenzae biotype aegypticus. It is worldwide in distribution and causes: A highly contagious form of conjunctivitis ('pink eye') which is especially common in the tropics and subtropics and may lead to epidemics. It responds to local sulphonamide or gentamicin administration. Brazilian purpuric fever characterized by fever, purpura, and conjunctivitis which proceeds to fulminant septicemia in infants and children. It has a high fatality rate. Miscellaneous Bacteria - Yersinia, Brucella, Bartonella, Legionella
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The milk ring test is found to be positive for a sample of milk. Which organism has it most likely been contaminated with?
explanation: Milk ring test (MRT) is positive for Brucella. It is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy farms. A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min. If antibodies are present in the milk, the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the rest of the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the solution remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is an intracellular pathogen?
explanation: Brucella suis is primarily an intracellular pathogen affecting reticuloendothelial system. This accounts for its refractoriness to chemotherapy.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A farmer was diagnosed with brucellosis. Which of the following patterns of fever will be seen in this disease?
explanation: Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by Brucella sp which presents with undulant fever. It is referred to as undulant fever because of the rising and falling of fever like a wave (remittent fever). Patients may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Other options Option A: Pel-Ebstein fever is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is characterized by fever lasting 3–10 days followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days. Option C: Relapsing fever is seen in infection with Borrelia recurrentis in which days of fever are followed by a several-day afebrile period and then relapse into additional days of fever. A similar picture is also seen in malaria. Option D: Saddleback fever is seen in dengue. Saddleback fever is defined as temperature >37.5°C with defervescence of at least one day, followed by a second peak lasting at least one day.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A 56-year-old dairy farmer presented with remittent fever and night sweats for 1 month. On examination, he was hypotensive and pallor was present. Rose Bengal card tests done on milk
samples from his farm were found to be positive. Which blood culture method with a biphasic medium will be used to isolate the organism?
explanation: The given case scenario of remittent fever with anemia with a positive Rose Bengal card test is suggestive of brucellosis. Castaneda method for blood culture is used to isolate Brucella sp. In the Castaneda method, blood is inoculated into a bottle of trypticase soy broth or brucella broth in a biphasic blood culture bottle (with liquid and solid media in the same bottle). This method minimizes materials and manipulation, thus reducing the chances of contamination and risk of infection to laboratory workers. Blood cultures are positive in only 30–50% of cases even when repeated samples are tested. B.melitensis and B.suis are isolated more readily than B.abortus. The below image shows Castaneda's bottle. Lab diagnosis of brucellosis is done using the following methods: Blood culture with Castaneda's method - recommended BACTEC - an automated method. It is faster than Castaneda's method. Serological tests: Standard agglutination test (SAT) ELISA for specific IgG/IgM Dipstick assays Detection in milk and infected cattle is carried out by: Microscopic demonstration by staining or immunofluorescence Milk ring test Rose Bengal card test
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 50-year-old farmer presents with fever, weight loss, and lower backache for three weeks. Blood reports show predominant lymphocytosis. What are the drugs of choice for treating this condition?
explanation: The given scenario of a farmer with fever, weightloss and back pain with a predominant lymphocytosis points towards a diagnosis of acute brucellosis. The drugs of choice for this condition in adults are intramuscular streptomycin with doxycycline. The usual alternative regimen (and the current World Health Organization recommendation) is rifampin plus doxycycline. However, this is associated with a higher relapse rate, possibly because rifampicin increases clearance of doxycycline and reduces serum doxycycline levels. In children, cotrimoxazole along with rifampicin or gentamycin may be used for the treatment of brucellosis. Note: B. melitensis is endemic to the Middle East.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 34-year-old man presents to the hospital with fever, joint pain and a rash on his hands. He gives a history of a rat bite 1 week back. Which of the following can cause this disease?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of rat-bite fever. This can be caused by Streptobacillus moniliformis and Spirillum minus. Rat-bite fever (RBF) is characterized by fever, rash, and arthralgia which usually occurs days or weeks after a bite. The two types of rat-bite fever are: Streptobacillary RBF develops 2–10 days after a rat bite, associated with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia followed by petechial rash and arthritis. It is also called Haverhill fever or Erythema arthrititicum epidemicum. Spirillary RBF is similar to streptobacillary type but it is also associated with regional lymphadenopathy. It is also called Sodoku. Diagnosis is based on demonstration of causative organisms in peripheral blood films. Serology can also be used for diagnosis. RBF is treated with intravenous Penicillin G. Alternative drugs include ampicillin, cefuroxime, and cefotaxime. Note: Pasteurella multocida causes cellulitis and lymphangitis following bites by cats and dogs. Bartonella henselae causes cat sratch disease and bacillary angiomatosis. Borellia burgdorferi causes Lyme disease.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: While evaluating the Pap smear of a patient, you come across the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows clue cells which are seen in bacterial vaginosis. They are epithelial cells with their surface covered by adherent bacilli seen in stained or unstained films. Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterized by a malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge. Causative organisms include: Gardnerella vaginalis Mycoplasma hominis Prevotella Ureaplasma Peptostreptococcus. Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria and Nugent's score: Amsel's Criteria: (any 3 should be present) Thin, white/yellow homogenous vaginal discharge pH of Vaginal fluid>4.5 Fishy odour of discharge accentuated on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) Clue cells seen on microscopy Nugent's score is obtained by counting the number of Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobilincus and lactobacillus in the gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge. A score of 7 is diagnostic Treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg BD for 7 days. The images below show clue cells from microscopy.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient from Kolar, Karnataka presented with fever and hemoptysis. The findings of his peripheral smear examination are given below. Which of the following is the causative organism?
explanation: The given case scenario and the image showing the characteristic "safety-pin appearance" in peripheral smear is suggestive of plague caused by Yersinia pestis. On staining with Giemsa stain or methylene blue (Wayson's stain), the bacteria has bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear. This is the characteristic 'safety-pin appearance' seen in Y. pestis. Bipolar staining is also shown by the following organisms: Haemophilus ducreyi Vibrio parahemolyticus Calymmatobacterium granulomatis Burkholderia mallei Burkholderia pseudomallei. Note: In India, 4 foci of plague are known: Kolar at the trijunction of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, and Karnataka. Beed-Latur belt in Maharashtra Rhoru, Himachal Pradesh Uttarakhand The image given below shows the safety-pin appearance of Yersinia pestis on Wayson's stai

question_text: A child from Uttarakhand suddenly developed fever with chills and malaise. He also developed a tender swelling which is shown in the image. There's a history of similar complaints in the community. What is false about the disease he's likely suffering from?
options: Wild rodents and their infected fleas are the primary reservoir.
The septicemic form cannot be acquired directly.
The pneumonic form is far more contagious than the bubonic form.
The bubonic form may progress to the pneumonic form.
explanation: The given case scenario of sudden-onset fever with painful lymphadenopathy and a history of similar complaints in the community is suggestive of a diagnosis of plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The septicemic form of the disease may be acquired directly if the bacteria enter the bloodstream via infected blood transfusions. Wild rodents and their infected fleas are the primary reservoirs of Yersinia pestis. Infection is transmitted to humans by the bite of infected fleas. Human plague occurs in 3 clinical forms (in increasing order of severity): bubonic plague< pneumonic plague< septicemic plague Bubonic plague- It is the most common variety of the disease. It is named after the buboes meaning swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite. Other clinical features include sudden onset of fever and chills, headache, and fatigue. Pneumonic plague- Bubonic plague can advance and spread to the lungs. It is the most virulent form of plague. Any person with pneumonic plague may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans. The symptoms include dyspnoea, chest pain, cough, fever, and hemoptysis. Septicemic plague- When the bacteria enter the bloodstream directly and multiply there, it is known as septicemic plague. When left untreated, both bubonic and pneumonic plague can lead to septicemic plague.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A sudden epidemic of pneumonic plague has occurred in the Beed-Latur belt of Maharashtra. The primary contact of a suspected case came to you for preventive treatment. What will you prescribe for chemoprophylaxis in this patient?
explanation: The drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of plague is doxycycline. It is given for 7 days to all close contacts of a patient having pneumonic plague. Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin are the other first-line drugs used for antimicrobial prophylaxis. The drug of choice for the treatment of plague is streptomycin. Streptomycin is nephrotoxic and ototoxic and should, therefore be cautiously used. Doxycycline or ciprofloxacin (and other fluoroquinolones) are considered as alternative drugs for the treatment of plague.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms do not cause yersiniosis?
explanation: The term yersiniosis denotes infections with yersiniae other than Y.pestis. Yersiniosis includes zoonotic infections by Y.pseudotuberculosis and Y.enterocolitica.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the OPD with high fever, chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis. The patient also complains of watery diarrhea. The direct fluorescent antibody stained film of his pleural fluid is given below. Identify the most likely etiologic agent.
explanation: The given clinical vignette and the image showing fluorescent organisms in the direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) stained film of pleural fluid suggest the diagnosis of Legionnaire's disease, caused by Legionella pneumophila. Two distinct clinical patterns of legionellosis have been identified: Legionnaires' disease presents with fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea rapidly progressing to pneumonia if left untreated. Patients can also develop a hyponatremia. Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common. It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Atypical pneumonia is also caused by: Chlamydia pneumonia Chlamydia psittaci Mycoplasma pneumonia Coxiella burnetii Viruses such as influenza virus, adenovirus and respiratory syncytial virus Pontiac fever is a milder, non-fatal, influenza-like illness with fever, chills, myalgia, and headache. Other options: Option A: Chlamydia pneumonia causes pharyngitis, sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia. It has also been associated with adult onset asthma. Outbreaks have been reported in closed communities. Real-time PCR is used for its diagnosis. Option C: Haemophilus influenzae typically causes pneumonia in infants. While the primary infections occur due to capsulated strains, bronchopneumonia may occur as a secondary infection due to non-capsulated strains. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis. Option D: Klebsiella pneumonia causes fatal pneumonia, which occurs in middle -aged or older persons with risk factors such as alcoholism, chronic bronchopulmonary disease or diabetes mellitus. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: BCYE medium is used to culture:
explanation: BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila. Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g., polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3–6 days to appear. Other options: Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol–bromothymol blue) agar Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with Legionnaires’ disease. He had recently attended a conference. What is the most likely way he acquired the infection?
options: From the air-conditioned rooms at the conference
From a chronic carrier of the disease
From sharing a towel with a fellow colleague in the conference
From drinking the water provided at the conference
explanation: This patient most likely acquired infection with Legionella pneumophila from inhalation of aerosol in the air-conditioned rooms at the conference. Legionella pneumophila can be found in natural, freshwater environments, but generally is not present in sufficient numbers to cause disease. Infection is typically by inhalation of aerosols produced by cooling towers, air conditioners, and showerheads which act as disseminators No animal reservoirs exist. No evidence of human-to-human transmission has been found and no carrier state is established.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient presented with fever and regional lymphadenopathy, following a scratch from his pet kitten. His lymph node biopsy specimen was examined with Warthin-Starry staining; the findings are shown in the given image. What is the causative organism of this condition?
explanation: This patient presents with fever and lymphadenopathy after a cat scratch and the above image shows the black short rod-shaped bacilli arranged in chains or clumps, suggestive of cat scratch disease, This condition is caused by Bartonella henselae. Cat scratch disease presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch. Patients present with a painless papule or pustule at the site of the scratch and lymph node enlargement and can be suppurative. The disease is usually self resolving. However, it can be treated with azithromycin only in patients who have severe complications.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Choose the correct statement regarding 5-day fever.
options: Treatment is necessary only in the severe cases
explanation: 5-day fever is an exclusively human disease and no animal reservoir is known. 5-day fever is also known as trench fever/quintan fever. It is caused by Bartonella quintana. It is characterized by sudden onset of fever accompanied by headache, malaise, restlessness, and shin pain. Trench fever is transmitted by the body louse. (Option A). It has an incubation period ranging from 14-30 days. Symptoms coincide with the release of B. quintana in blood every 3-5 days with each episode lasting 5 days. Recrudescence and relapses are common. (Option B) All cases are treated using doxycycline. Macrolides and fluoroquinolones can also be used in its treatment. (Option D)
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young man presented to the ER with fever and suppurative lymphadenopathy of his left axilla a few days after he sustained a scratch from his pet cat. Which of the following will most likely be seen on biopsy of the lymph node?
explanation: The given scenario points to a diagnosis of cat-scratch disease caused by B. henselae. Stellate granulomas are characteristically present in this condition. They are granulomas containing central granular debris and neutrophils; giant cells are uncommon. The image below shows a stellate granuloma Other options: Option A: Foreign body granulomas are incited by relatively inert foreign bodies, such as talc, sutures. Epithelioid cells and giant cells are apposed to the surface of the foreign body. The foreign material can usually be identified in the center of the granuloma. The given image shows suture granuloma. The suture material is surrounded by lymphocytic infiltration Option B: Naked granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis. They are non-caseating granulomas minimally surrounded by lymphocytes. The image below shows a naked granuloma Option C: Durck granulomas are seen in cerebral malaria. The image below shows a Durck granuloma
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient who is a known case of AIDS presents to the OPD with fever, chills, weight loss and the cutaneous lesions shown below. The microscopic examination of the lesions revealed predominant neutrophilic infiltration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical vignette of a patient with HIV infections and the violaceous lesions with a neutrophilic infiltrate is suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis. Bacillary angiomatosis is seen in severely immunocompromised patients and is caused by B. henselae or B. quintana. It is characterized by neovascular proliferative lesions involving the skin. It consists of lobular proliferation of small blood vessels lined by enlarged endothelial cells interspersed with mixed infiltrates of neutrophils and lymphocytes, with a predominance of the former. Both bacillary angiomatosis and Kaposi's sarcoma can have the clinical presentation mentioned in the question. However, the major differentiating factor is the microscopic examination: Bacillary angiomatosis predominantly has mixed infiltrate accompanied by neutrophils with clumps of bacilli. Kaposi's sarcoma predominantly has plasma cells and lymphocytic infiltrates.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient has presented with lesions on the dorsum of the hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy. What significant history will you ask for in this case?
options: History of similar complaint in family members
explanation: This scenario of lesions on the hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy is suggestive of cat scratch disease, hence we should ask about the history of exposure to cats. It is caused by Bartonella henselae. Bartonella henselae is an intracellular, pleomorphic, gram-negative bacillus. They can be identified in lymph node biopsy with Warthin-Starry Silver stain. In addition to cat scratch disease, in immunocompromised individuals, it can also cause bacillary angiomatosis and peliosis hepatis. In immunocompetent hosts, cat scratch disease is a self limiting illness. However in patients with severe disease, azithromycin can be used to treat the infection.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
explanation: Parinaud's oculoglandular syndrome is an atypical form of cat scratch disease and is caused by Bartonella henselae . Bartonella henselae also causes bacillary angiomatosis in HIV-infected and other immunodeficient patients. . It presents as vascular nodules or tumours on the skin, mucosa, and other locations. Bartonella bacilliformis causes Oroya fever also known as Carrion's disease. Note: Ehrlichia phagocytophila has been renamed as Anaplasma phagocytophilum.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A patient with fever and hemolytic anemia developed characteristic Peruvian warts 1 month later. What is the causative organism for this disease?
Bartonella hensalae
explanation: The above clinical scenario of fever, hemolytic anemia followed by verruga peruana lesions (Peruvian warts) is suggestive of Oroya fever. It is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis. The vector for Oroya fever is sandfly. Oroya fever or Carrion’s disease is associated with verruga peruana which are cutaneous vascular lesions carrying the bacteria. It presents as fever with progressive anemia due to bacterial invasion of erythrocytes. A late sequela in survivors of Oroya fever or in those with asymptomatic infection is verruga peruana, which is characterized by vascular nodular skin lesions carrying the bacteria that occur in successive crops. An image of verruga peruana is given below. Image shows verruga peruana lesions. Bartonella quintana causes trench fever or 5 day fever. Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease. It also causes bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis in HIV infected people. Gram Negative Cocci
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for Neisseria meningitidis infection?
explanation: Hypogammaglobulinemia is a risk factor for Neisseria meningitidis infection, not hypergammaglobulinemia. Risk factors for meningococcal infection include: Overcrowding Cigarette smoking Mycoplasma infection Hyposplenism Hypogammaglobulinemia History of travel like pilgrimage Recent viral infection Terminal complement pathway deficiency (C5-C9 Deficiency) - increases the risk of disseminated gonococcemia
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 22-year-old student presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
explanation: This patient has a high-grade fever and is a student, so he presumably spends a lot of time in crowded areas. The above image shows a purpuric rash. This patient's features are seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection. Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the most common manifestation of Neisseria meningitidis infection?
explanation: Infection with Neisseria meningitidis is most commonly asymptomatic colonization in the nasopharynx of healthy individuals. Hence, a nasopharyngeal swab is used in the detection of carriers. In some patients, local inflammation ensues with rhinitis and pharyngitis. Ceftriaxone as a single-dose IV/IM injection is highly (97%) effective in the eradication of carrier state and can be used at all ages and also in pregnancy. Ciprofloxacin is also highly effective and can be given orally, but it is not recommended in pregnancy and below 18 years of age.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 5-year-old girl with thalassemia major was prophylactically immunized with a polysaccharide meningococcal vaccine before being taken up for elective splenectomy. Which group of Neisseria meningitidis would she be susceptible to even after immunization?
explanation: Polysaccharide vaccines of Neisseria meningitidis do not offer protection against group B meningococci. This is because the group B capsule is made up of sialic acid residue which is also expressed on the surface of neural cells in the fetus. So, the B polysaccharide is perceived as 'self' and is poorly immunogenic. To overcome this issue and provide protection against group B meningococci, a new vaccine was developed based on the surface protein i.e., non-capsular antigen of serogroup B meningococci. This is the multicomponent meningococcal vaccine - 4CMenB. Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines developed based on capsular antigen can be classified as: Plain polysaccharide vaccines: Bivalent (A and C), Trivalent (A, C and W-135) Tetravalent (A, C, Y, and W-135) Conjugated polysaccharide vaccines: Monovalent (A or C) Quadrivalent (A, C, Y, and W-135) MenQuadfi vaccine
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young man is brought to the ER with complaints of headache and fever. On examination, a maculopapular rash is seen over his trunk & extremities, and the following sign is elicited. Which of the following antibiotics should he be started on empirically?
explanation: The clip given shows a positive Kernig's sign. This in combination with the other clinical features indicates a diagnosis of meningococcal meningitis. Third-generation cephalosporins such as ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, and ceftazidime are used empirically for the initiation of treatment for suspected meningococcal meningitis. These drugs are administered as they also cover the various other potentially penicillin-resistant bacteria that may produce clinical features similar to that of meningococcal meningitis like penicillin-resistant pneumococcus. Also, some instances of reduced meningococcal sensitivity to penicillin have also been reported. Both meningococcal meningitis and meningococcal septicemia are conventionally treated for 7 days, although courses of 3–5 days may be equally effective. Rifampicin can be used for prophylaxis for close contacts. Ceftriaxone can also be used for chemoprophylaxis, especially in pregnant individuals. The image below shows petechial rashes in meningococcal infection
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You have to administer chemoprophylaxis to the contacts of a patient diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following combinations is correct?
explanation: Ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone, and rifampicin can be used for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis. Ciprofloxacin should not be given in pregnancy and to those below 18 years of age. Ceftriaxone is preferred in these cases as a single IM or IV dose. However, reduced susceptibility of isolates to ceftriaxone has occasionally been reported. Recommended chemoprophylaxis for high-risk close contacts of meningococcal meningitis: Age Drug Dose Route and duration Remarks <1 mo nth Rifampicin 5 mg/ kg Oral every 12 hrs for 2 days - >1 mo nth Rifampicin 10 mg /kg Oral every 12 hrs for 2 days Not recommended in pregna ncy <15 yea rs Ceftriaxone 125m g IM single dose Can be given to children and is recommended in pregnanc y >15 yea rs Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose Can be given to children and is recommended in pregnanc y >18 ye ars Ciprofloxac in 500 mg Oral single dose Not recommended in pregna ncyPreferred for mass proph ylaxis

question_text: Which of the following differentiates meningococcus from gonococcus?
explanation: Only meningococcus can ferment maltose, whereas both gonococcus and meningococcus can ferment glucose. Both species are catalase and oxidase positive and neither of them can reduce nitrate. The only Neisseria species that can reduce nitrate is N. mucosa.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 30-year-old man has treatment-resistant gonorrhea. You plan to send a sample of his urethral discharge to the lab for culture and sensitivity testing. What transport media would you use for this purpose?
explanation: Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrheae and Neisseria meningitidis. Stuart’s medium is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium, which prevents microbial proliferation. It ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 25-year old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except?
explanation: The given slide shows gram-negative diplococci within the polymorphs, characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Neisseria is not an obligate intracellular organism, it can also occur extracellularly i.e, it is a facultative intracellular organism. The other neisseria that are found as normal inhabitants of the human respiratory tract occur extracellularly. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative, non-sporulating, non-motile diplococcus that is aerobic but may grow anaerobically also. It is oxidase and catalase-positive. Although Neisseria are non-motile organisms, they show twitching motility. This is a flagella-independent form of bacterial translocation over moist surfaces that occurs by the extension and retraction of polar type IV pili. These pili act as virulence factors by promoting attachment to host cells and inhibiting phagocytosis. Virulence factors for gonococci: Outer Membrane Proteins (OMPs) IgA proteases Pili Lipo-oligosaccharide (LOS) Transferrin Lactoferrin-binding protein
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common manifestation of gonorrhoea in males?
explanation: Gonorrhea in males most commonly manifests as acute urethritis. In males, the disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis. Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation. The infection may also spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum). In females, the initial infection involves the cervix, uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions. Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome) which may also occur following Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient with a history of sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker 3 days back has developed genital discharge resembling 'flow of seed' as shown below. What medium should be used for the culture of the discharge?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of gonococcal urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Thayer-Martin and modified Thayer-Martin media are used for the culture of this organism. Gonorrhoea may manifest as mucopurulent genital discharge which can be described as resembling 'flow of seed' (semen). Thayer-Martin medium contains vancomycin, colistin and nystatin. Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhea. The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria. In the laboratory diagnosis of N. gonorrhea, the discharge on Gram's stain reveals gram■negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's medium is used for transport while Thayer-Martin agar is used as a selective medium used to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium. Charcoal present in the medium neutralizes certain bacterial inhibitors while a reducing agent prevents oxidation.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a content of modified Thayer-Martin medium?
explanation: Modified Thayer-Martin medium does not include polymyxin B. It includes polymyxin E, which is also known as colistin. Modified Thayer–Martin medium is a selective media for Neisseria species. It includes: Vancomycin - to inhibit most gram-positive bacteria. Colistin (Polymyxin E) - to inhibit most gram-negative bacteria other than Neisseria. Nystatin or anisomycin - to inhibit yeast. Trimethoprim - to inhibit proteus. The contents of the Thayer-Martin medium are the same as that of the modified Thayer-Martin medium except for the presence of trimethoprim in the modified version. The image below depicts Thayer-Martin medium.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An unresponsive middle-aged man with fever and petechial rashes was rushed into the ER. You successfully resuscitate him. Abdominal ultrasound shows bilateral adrenal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?
options: Patients who recover may suffer from sloughing of the skin
The implicated organism can be isolated from the petechial rashes
The causative organism is Neisseria gonorrheae
Hypoplastic spleen is a risk factor for this condition
explanation: The above scenario depicts Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome which is a complication seen in infection with meningococci. Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is also known as hemorrhagic adrenalitis or fulminant meningococcemia and is characterized by bilateral adrenal gland hemorrhage. Though Waterhouse-Freiderichsen syndrome is most often associated with meningococcal septicemia, it may complicate sepsis caused by other organisms like certain streptococcal species also. Hypoplastic spleen may also be associated with this condition and the implicated organism can be isolated from the petechial rashes. Complications : Shock, extensive hemorrhage within the skin May fall into a coma Death, usually after a few hours, due to adrenal insufficiency Patients who recover may suffer from extensive sloughing of the skin and loss of digits due to gangrene. Fulminant meningococcemia is a medical emergency and needs to be treated with adequate antibiotics as fast as possible. Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic commonly used nowadays.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease presents to the OPD with fever and right upper abdominal pain. A diagnostic laparoscopy was done and the findings are as given below. Which of the following organisms could be the causative agent?
explanation: The scenario depicted is Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome which is a rare complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) following infection with Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It causes liver capsule inflammation leading to the creation of violin-string adhesions which can be seen on laparoscopy. On CT imaging it appears as perihepatic inflammatory stranding and hepatic capsular enhancement. The major symptom and signs include right upper quadrant pain. It is also associated with minimal pelvic pain, vaginal discharge, or cervical motion tenderness.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which is the true statement regarding gonococcal urethritis?
options: Symptoms are more severe in females than in males
Infection does not involve rectum and prostate
Dysuria is the most common presentation
Single dose of cefixime is the first line of treatment
explanation: Acute urethritis is the most common clinical manifestation of gonorrhea in males and major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. Other options: Option A: The stratified squamous epithelium of the vagina is resistant to gonococcus, so infection is less severe in females. Option B: In males, it can involve rectum, prostate, and epididymitis, but it never involves testes. Option D: Rising minimum inhibitory concentration of cefixime worldwide has led the CDC to discontinue its recommendation of this agent as first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea. Third-generation cephalosporins have remained highly effective as single-dose therapy for gonorrhoea. Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days is given. This also covers treatment for chlamydia (if chlamydial infection is not ruled out).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is not true about Neisseria gonorrhoeae?
options: It is exclusively a human pathogen
Some strains may cause disseminated disease
Vaccination has no role in prevention
Drug resistance is only due to acquisition of plasmids
explanation: Neisseria gonorrheae acquires resistance to antibiotics either by chromosomal mutations or by the acquisition of plasmids (R factors). These resistant strains are also known as: PPNG - penicillinase-producing N. gonorrhoeae (plasmid-borne resistance) TRNG - tetracycline-resistant N. gonorrhoeae (plasmid-borne resistance) CMRNG - chromosomally mediated resistance in N. gonorrhoeae (resistance to both penicillin and tetracycline) QRNG - quinolone resistant N. gonorrhoeae (due to alterations in DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV) Other options: Option A: N. gonorrhea is a fastidious organism and is exclusively a human pathogen. Option B: Some strains of N. gonorrhea can ascend up the genital tract and can lead to many disseminated diseases such as septic arthritis and pelvic inflammatory disease. Option C: Vaccines are not effective against N. gonorrhea due to its antigenic variation and ability to invade neurophils.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
Which of the following is true about Moraxella catarrhalis?
It is DNAse positive
options: An uncommon cause of COPD exacerbation
explanation: Moraxella catarrhalis is a DNAse positive gram-negative diplococcus. It is the second most common bacterial cause of COPD exacerbations (after H. influenzae). It can also cause otitis media, sinusitis, tracheobronchitis, and pneumonia. It differs from pathogenic Neisseria as: It does not ferment any carbohydrates - Asaccharolytic Gives a positive tributyrin hydrolysis test. Shows positive DNAse test. Angular conjunctivitis is caused by Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria. Treatment is with oral amoxicillin and clauvulanic acid. Rickettsia, Chlamydia and Mycoplasma
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Transovarial transmission is a feature of which of the following diseases?
explanation: Transovarial transmission is a feature of Orientia tsutsugamushi which causes scrub typhus. Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. Orientia tsutsugamushi is maintained by transovarial transmission in trombiculid mites. It is also seen in Rickettsia rickettsii, Rickettsia conorii, and Rickettsia akari. The image below shows a trombiculid mite. Trench fever (option D) is caused by Bartonella quintana.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 36-year-old trekker presented with fever, headache, and rashes following a tick bite. He was later diagnosed to have Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following statements is false about the microbe implicated?
explanation: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. A cell wall is present in rickettsial organisms. Rickettsiae are obligate intracellular, gram-negative pleomorphic coccobacilli. They are unable to grow in cell-free media and are thus cultured in yolk sacs of embryonated eggs. They are non-motile, non-capsulated organisms that contain both DNA and RNA. They reproduce by binary fission and are transmitted by arthropods like ticks and lice (except Coxiella burnetii and Bartonella henselae). The rickettsiae are localized in endothelial cells of small blood vessels (except Ehrlichia and Anaplasma) in humans. They cause endothelial cell enlargement and degeneration, predisposing to thrombus formation. Tetracyclines, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones are effective against this group but, beta-lactams are ineffective.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding endemic murine typhus?
explanation: The vector for endemic murine typhus is the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis. Endemic murine typhus is cuased by Rickettsia typhi (option B) while epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The zoonotic reservoir for R. typhi is the rat. Humans are infected when flea feces contaminate pruritic bite lesions. Transmission can also occur via inhalation of aerosols of dried feces of rickettsemic rat flea. No man-to-man transmission occurs. Patients present with fever, chills, vomiting and a maculopapular rash that is more prominent on the trunk. Diagnosis is by serology and treatment is with doxycycline. When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with blood from a case of endemic typhus, they develop fever and a characteristic scrotal inflammation. The scrotum becomes enlarged and the testes cannot be pushed into the abdomen. This is known as the Neil-Mooser reaction. It is positive with Rickettsia typhi (option D) and negative with Rickettsia prowazekii. The image below shows the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Multiple inmates at a prison are suspected to have epidemic typhus following an arthropod infestation. Which of the following vectors is implicated in the spread of this disease?
explanation: Louse (image B), Pediculus humanus corporis, transmits epidemic typhus. Gaol fever/ Jail fever/ epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 45-year-old man from Kashmir presents with fever, chills and rash for 1 week. The rash appeared on the 5th day of the fever starting from the trunk and progressing to the limbs. Epidemic typhus is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the disease?
options: Brill-Zinsser disease is a recrudescent form
Rash is present on palms and soles
explanation: Epidemic typhus rash spares the palms and soles. Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, is transmitted by the louse Pediculus humanus corporis. There is no transovarial transmission of R. prowazekii. The disease spreads through infected louse feces deposited when the louse feeds on the human host. It is commonly seen in poor unhygienic or cold conditions. Epidemic typhus starts with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles. In some patients who recover from epidemic typhus, the rickettsiae may remain latent in the lymphoid tissues or organs for years. Such latent infection may, at times, be reactivated leading to recrudescent typhus (Brill-Zinsser disease). Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. It occurs with Orientia tsutsugamushi, Rickettsia rickettsii, R. conorii and R. akari. Note: Rash on palms and soles is typically described in Rocky Mountain spotted fever, secondary syphilis and hand, foot, and mouth disease The image below shows the rash of epidemic typhus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
explanation: The drug of choice for scrub typhus is doxycycline. To treat scrub typhus, oral doxycycline 100 mg is given twice daily for 7–15 days. In the case of pregnant women, oral azithromycin 500 mg for 3 days may be used as doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy. Scrub typhus is a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is a trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with fever, headache, myalgia, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia. Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction used for diagnosis, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of Proteus strains OX19, OX2, and OXK. OXK alone is agglutinated in scrub typhus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 25-year-old man came with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He gives a history of hiking in scrub forests a week prior, where he suffered an insect bite. On examination, there is regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. Which of the following arthropods is involved in the spread of this disease?
explanation: A history of contact with scrub vegetation with fever, regional lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash, and eschar at the bite site is suggestive of scrub typhus. Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mite. Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of scrub typhus in adults. In case of pregnant women and children, azithromycin or chloramphenicol may be preferred where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A wildlife photographer presents with a blackish lesion at the site of an insect bite from a few days back. He also gives a history of fever. A positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins was observed. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: In the above clinical scenario, a history of insect bite followed by the development of a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite and a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins suggests a diagnosis of scrub typhus. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2, and OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.
