HBeAg is a qualitative marker while HBV DNA is a quantitative marker of the replicative phase.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 30-year-old man with heroin addiction presents with fatigue, palpable purpura, joint pains, and abdominal pain. Urine analysis shows massive proteinuria. Which of the following viruses should be tested for in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mixed cryoglobulinemia, which is strongly associated with hepatitis C. Hence, the patient should be tested for hepatitis C.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which hepatitis virus shows maximum chronicity in adults?
explanation: Maximum chronicity is seen in HCV infection, followed by HBV infection. 5-10% of adults infected with HBV develop chronic infection. The majority of neonates affected with hepatitis B develop chronic hepatitis. HEV is associated with chronic infection only in immunocompromised individuals. HAV is not associated with chronicity. Note: The most common cause of post-transfusion hepatitis in developed countries is hepatitis C
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient with fulminant hepatitis is found to have coinfection with hepatitis B and hepatitis D viruses. Which of the following structures of HBV aid in the survival of HDV?
explanation: Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is an incomplete/defective virus. It requires HBV, to provide the envelope protein (HbsAg) to aid in its survival. Hepatitis D is called the delta virus. Two types of infection may occur: Co-infection - acute HDV and HBV infections occur simultaneously Super-infection - Delta viral infection occurs in a person already harboring HBV. This most often eads to chronic hepatitis Coinfection and superinfection can cause fulminant hepatitis. HBV vaccination is protective against HDV.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: In the year 1955, following sewage contamination of drinking water in New Delhi, an outbreak of jaundice ensued. Electron microscopy of fecal samples from the affected population revealed a virus resembling caliciviruses. Which of the following was the etiological agent?
explanation: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) resembles caliciviruses in morphology and physical characteristics. Hepatitis E is a non-enveloped virus with ssRNA genome Note: The largest HEV epidemic occurred in New Delhi in 1955-1956.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
Which of the following is false about viral hepatitis?
Anti LKM-3 antibody is associated with hepatitis B infection
options: Anti-LKM1 antibodies are associated with hepatitis C infection
IgM anti-HAV antibody appears during the late incubation period
Enterically transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis is caused by hepatitis E virus
explanation: The anti-LKM-3 antibody is associated with hepatitis D infection, not hepatitis B. Anti–liver-kidney microsomal antibodies (anti-LKM) are many of several autoantibodies that are detected in the serum of patients with different types of acute or chronic liver disease. These antibodies are targeted against antigens of the cytochrome P450 system. They are also associated with chronic hepatitis C and autoimmune hepatitis. Option C: IgM anti-HAV antibody indicates current/recent infection. It appears during the late incubation period, peaks in 2-3 weeks, and disappears after 3-4 months. IgG denotes remote infection or immunity. It appears around the same time, peaks at 3-4 months, and persists for a long time. Option D: Hepatitis E infection was previously known as an epidemic or enterically transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis. It is transmitted by feco-oral route. HIV
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following subtypes of HIV is most common in India?
explanation: Subtype C of HIV is the most common in India. It causes more than 95% of HIV infections. Subtypes A and C are more readily transmitted by heterosexual contact than subtype B, which is mainly transmitted by homosexual contact and injections.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about HIV?
explanation: HIV is a thermolabile virus. It is readily inactivated by heating to 60 °C for 10 minutes and at 100 °C in seconds. At room temperature (20–25 °C) in the dried blood, it may survive for 1 week. Option A: HIV crosses the blood-brain barrier. It may cause encephalopathy leading to loss of higher functions, progressing to dementia. Option B: HIV is a spherical, enveloped virus. Its genome is composed of two copies of identical single-stranded positive-sense RNA. Option C: HIV is inactivated by treatment with 0.3% hydrogen peroxide, 50% ethanol, 35% isopropanol or 10% household bleach. A 2% solution of glutaraldehyde is effective for the disinfection of medical instruments.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is a nonstructural gene of HIV?
explanation: The tat gene (trans-activating gene) is a non-structural gene. HIV has structural and non-structural genes: Structural genes- •enes coding for structural protiens: gag- Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24 env- Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41 pol- Codes for enzymes: Polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease Non-structural and regulatory genes: tat- Trans-activating gene nef- Negative factor gene rev- Regulator of virus gene vif- Viral infectivity factor gene vpu- (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2) vpr- Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus LTR- Long terminal repeat sequences
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of HIV replication?
explanation: HIV replicates by the sequence RNA-DNA-RNA. The provirus initiates viral replication by directing the synthesis of viral RNA and other components. Hence, the sequence is RNA–ssDNA–dsDNA–RNA. HIV genome is composed of 2 single-stranded positive-sense RNA. When a virus infects a cell, the viral RNA is transcribed by the enzyme reverse transcriptase, first into single-stranded DNA and then to double-stranded DNA which is integrated into the host chromosome. Note: If the options include RNA-DNA-RNA and RNA-DNA-DNA-RNA then the latter would be the choice. The given image represents HIV replication
subject: Microbiology

question_text: As part of developing the public health policy on HIV in India, which of the following modes of transmission would you focus on the most?
explanation: Heterosexual transmission is the most common mode of transmission of HIV infection in developing countries such as India and African countries. In many Western countries, male-to-male sexual transmission is the dominant mode of transmission. Blood transfusion carries the highest risk per 10000 exposures of getting HIV from an infected person. However, it is not the most common mode of transmission.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 35-year-old bisexual man goes to an ICTC centre for counselling about HIV. Which of the following is false about HIV transmission?
options: Male-to-female HIV transmission has more risk of causing infection than female-to-male transmission
The risk of acquiring HIV with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is lower than that with penile-vaginal intercourse
The quantity of HIV-1 in plasma is a primary determinant of the risk of HIV-1 transmission
Male circumcision is associated with a lower risk of HIV acquisition for heterosexual men
explanation: The risk of HIV acquisition associated with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is relatively higher than that seen in penile-vaginal intercourse. This is because the rectal mucosal membrane is thin and fragile and anal intercourse is associated with microtrauma (rectal tears). The differences in transmission rates between men and women are because the vagina and cervix are exposed to semen for a longer duration, increasing the risk of transmission. However, the penis and urethral orifice are exposed relatively briefly to infected vaginal fluid, lowering the risk.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor occurs via which of these?
explanation: The specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor is by the envelope glycoprotein gp120. Option B - Cell fusion occurs via binding to gp41. Cell fusion is essential for infection to take place. Option C, D - Binding to CD4 receptor requires the participation of a co-receptor CXCR 4 for T cell tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A patient presents to you with a history of sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. HIV-antibody spot test was negative, however p24 antigen assay was positive. You explain to him that he is currently in the window period for HIV. Which of the
following statements would you use to explain the concept to him?
options: It is the time period between infection and onset of first symptoms
It is the time period between infection and detection of antibodies
It is the time period between exposure and onset of viral multiplication
It is the time period between exposure and appearance of symptoms
explanation: In the given scenario, the patient has experienced a high-risk exposure to HIV due to sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period. The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and PCR.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 41-year-old man was admitted for hernioplasty and initial investigations revealed that he is HIV-positive. He gives no history of contact and has no HIV-associated symptoms. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this phase of HIV infection?
options: Rapid decline of CD4 count is common
explanation: The given patient is in the latent period of HIV infection. During the latent phase of HIV infection, the CD4+ T cell count declines steadily and not rapidly. All patients infected with HIV pass through a phase of clinical latency during which they are asymptomatic. This can last for years. During the latent phase, patients show positive HIV antibody tests and they are infectious. There will be varying° of viral multiplication. Throughout the course of untreated infection and even during the stage of clinical latency, HIV is actively replicating or is sequestered in lymphoid tissues.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic requesting an HIV test. He had unprotected sexual contact with another man 3 weeks ago. Antibodies against which of the following will be detected first by ELISA or Western blot?
explanation: Antibodies against gp41 will be detected first by ELISA or Western blot. Antibodies to HIV usually appear within 3–6 weeks of primary infection. The appearance of HIV-binding antibodies occurs prior to the appearance of neutralizing antibodies. The only viral proteins that elicit neutralizing antibodies are the envelope proteins gp120 and gp41. The order of appearance of antibodies is as follows: Antibody to envelope gp41 > Antibodies to gag protein (p24 and p55) > Antibodies to envelope gp120 > Antibodies to gag protein p17 > Antibodies to pol gene products (p31 and p66). Note: The earliest antigen to appear in the blood following HIV infection is p24.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
You are an officer with the Center for Disease Control and are screening a high-risk population for HIV. Which of the following methods will you use as a screening tool?
Western blot
explanation: ELISA is most commonly used as a screening test for HIV. Screening tests possess high sensitivity but are not highly specific. ELISA is a simple, relatively inexpensive screening test. The most commonly used confirmatory test is Western blot. Western blot demonstrating antibodies to products of all three of the major genes of HIV (gag, pol, and env) is conclusive evidence of infection with HIV. It is considered positive if it shows antibodies against at least two of the following gene products: p24, gp41, gp120/160. Myxoviruses and Rhabdoviruses
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following RNA viruses has an 8 segmented genome with its site of replication being the nucleus?
explanation: Influenza virus has an 8 segmented genome. Its site of replication is the nucleus, unlike other RNA viruses. Influenza virus belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Most DNA viruses replicate in the nucleus, except pox. Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytoplasm, except retroviruses and orthomyxoviruses. Examples of segmented viruses (ARBO): Arenavirus (2 segments) Rotavirus (11 segments) Bunyavirus (3 segments) Orthomyxovirus (8 segments) The image below shows the segmented genome seen in the influenza virus (Orthomyxoviridae)
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A microbiologist working on influenza virus in a lab, observes reversal of hemagglutination. What is this phenomenon known as?
explanation: Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell surface. Influenza virus contains two surface antigens: Hemagglutinin (HA) - causes RBC agglutination; facilitates viral entry into cells Neuraminidase (NA) - an enzyme that destroys the receptor HA uses to bind to RBCs causing elution/reversal of hemagglutination. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift?
options: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
It doesn’t account for the periodic epidemics of influenza
The new antigens thus formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralise the new variants
explanation: Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure. It accounts for periodic epidemics. This property forms the basis for the development of annual influenza vaccines. Antigenic variation is a property of influenza viruses by which it alters the antigenic structure on its surface and thus avoids a host immune response. It is of two types - Antigenic shift and antigenic drift. Antigenic shift Antigenic drift Antigenic structure Abrupt, drastic change Gradual, sequential change Periodicity 10 - 20 years 2 - 3 years Epidemiological effect Pandemics and major epide mics Periodic epidemic and spora dic cases Genetic cause Large genetic re-assortment Point mutation Antibodies to predecessor str ains Do not neutralize the new va riant Neutralizes the new variant t o varying° Antigenic shift Antigenic drift Clinical relevance Animal-origin viruses infecti ng humans e.g. Swine flu, CO VID-19 Annual influenza vaccine dev elopmentCommon cold - Peo ple can get flu more than onc e
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication?
explanation: The given image shows the replication of influenza virus. Stages of replication: Attachment, penetration, uncoating- the virus is internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis Transcription and translation- Viral transcription occurs in the nucleus. The mRNAs are produced from viral nucleocapsids. Viral RNA replication- Viral genome replication is accomplished by the same virus-encoded polymerase proteins involved in transcription. Maturation- The virus matures by budding from the surface of the cell.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You receive multiple patients from a poultry farm presenting with fever, dyspnea, cold, and cough. You suspect an outbreak of Avian flu. Which of the following virus strains causes the same?
explanation: H5N1 is a strain of avian influenza. Transmission occurs only from birds (e.g. poultry). Recombination occurs in pigs. Human-to-human transmission is very rare. It causes flu-like symptoms and can cause severe respiratory illness. Option A: H1N1 causes swine flu Option C: H3N2 causes Hong Kong flu Option D: H2N2 caused a pandemic in 1957
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 4-year-old girl with a history of fever, rhinorrhea, sore throat, and myalgia presented with multiple episodes of vomiting and seizures. She was diagnosed with Reye's syndrome. Which of the following is incorrect about the most likely etiological agent?
options: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
5-12 years is a high risk group
explanation: The most likely etiological agent in the given case of Reye's syndrome is the influenza virus. Children <5-years, especially those <2-years of age are at the highest risk of serious complications related to influenza infection. Other high-risk groups for influenza include adults 60 years of age, persons with chronic diseases, persons who are immunocompromised. Option A: The virus is shed in respiratory secretions a day before the onset of illness and for 3-4 days thereafter. Option C: Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Option D: Secondary attack rate is 5-15%. Note: Reye's syndrome is precipitated by the interaction of a viral infection (such as influenza) with salicylates. Therefore, aspirin is not given to pediatric patients with influenza and influenza-like illness.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of headache and drowsiness since 2 days. He had a history of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, you see the following. Brudzinki's sign is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with fever, parotitis, headache, drowsiness, and positive Brudzinki's sign is suggestive of meningitis secondary to mumps. Mumps is caused by the mumps virus and is characterized by fever, bilateral or unilateral parotid swelling which may be tender. Parotitis can present with ear pain and difficulty in swallowing. It usually resolves in a week. Meningoencephalitis/aseptic meningitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. It can present with headache, neck stiffness, and drowsiness. Complications of mumps: Aseptic meningitis or meningoencephalitis Epididymo-orchitis- Usually unilateral. Seen in post-pubertal males Oophoritis Other complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis Note: Non-mumps parotitis can be caused by: Epstein-Barr virus - causes infectious mononucleosis Coxsackievirus - causes herpangina Parainfluenza virus - causes croup
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 9-month-old child is brought to the OPD for MMR vaccine. Which strain of mumps virus is used in the same?
explanation: The strain of mumps virus used in the MMR vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) is the Jeryl-Lynn strain. The virus is attenuated by serial passage in embryonated eggs and grown in chick embryo fibroblast culture. Note: The schedule of MMR vaccine as per the National Immunisation Schedule is from 9 completed months to 12 months. (can be given till 5 years of age).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A mother brings her 5-month-old baby to the casualty with complaints of fast breathing and poor feeding. She also gives a history of fever, cold, and cough for 3 days. On examination, nasal flaring and expiratory wheeze are present. Which of the following statements is false about the viral etiology of the same?
options: The cytopathic effect is syncytium formation
Ribavirin is the drug of choice
It is the most important cause of bronchiolitis
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiolitis caused by the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). Palivizumab is given for RSV prophylaxis in high-risk infants such as premature babies, immunocompromised infants, etc. Option A - The characteristic cytopathic effect is syncytium formation (multinucleated giant cell). Option B - Inhaled ribavirin is the drug of choice. Option D - RSV causes upper and lower respiratory tract infections in infants, and is the most common cause of bronchiolitis from ages 6 weeks to 6 months. It can cause pneumonia and tracheobronchitis and is common during winters and monsoon.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An unimmunized man presents with fever, malaise, and an erythematous rash starting from behind the ears and progressing to the face and trunk. Given below is an image of lymphoid tissue taken from this patient. What pathological finding do you see here?
explanation: Warthin-Finkeldey cells are seen here. These are multinucleate giant cells, which are found in the lymphoid tissues of patients with measles. The cytopathic effect of measles consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, as shown in the image below. Option B: Warthin-Starry stain is used to detect spirochetes and to stain H. pylori and B. henselae Option C: Langhans giant cells are seen in tuberculosis Option D: Aschoff giant cells are seen in rheumatic fever
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 3-year-old boy with no prior immunization history presents with fever, cough, and coryza. On examination of the buccal mucosa, you see the following. Which stage of the disease is this finding seen in?
explanation: The given image shows Koplik’s spots present in measles. They are seen during the prodromal phase of the illness. Koplik's spots are small bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite to the first and second lower molars and are pathognomonic of measles. They contain giant cells, cytoplasmic and intranuclear inclusions, and virion components. They can involve the entire buccal mucosa and fade as the maculopapular rash develops. Stages of measles: The natural history of measles has 3 stages as follows: Prodromal stage - It begins 10 days after infection and lasts until day 14. It consists of cough, coryza, redness of eyes, lacrimation, photophobia, vomiting, and diarrhea. Koplik's spots appear in this stage. Eruptive stage - A dusky, red maculopapular rash appears. It starts behind the ears spreads downwards to the trunk and lower extremities. Antibodies appear in this stage and are detectable by IgM ELISA. The symptoms such as fever and rash usually resolve spontaneously or go on to develop complications. Post-measles stage - Weakness and weight loss may persist. The infection may become chronic and cause secondary infections such as cancrum oris, candidiasis etc. The image below shows Koplik's spots The image below shows the characteristic maculopapular rash in measles
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested?
explanation: Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, viral disease. Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is virtually 100% fatal. Spread of rabies: Centripetal spread - The virus enters the peripheral neurons, it moves via retrograde fast axonal transport towards the spinal cord or brainstem a.k.a the central nervous system (CNS) at a speed of up to 250 mm/day. Once within CNS, it spreads quickly to other regions in the CNS through fast axonal transport. It infects neurons primarily, but may rarely infect astrocytes. Centrifugal spread - After CNS infection is established, it spreads along the sensory and autonomic nerves to: Salivary glands Adrenal glands Skin Rabies virus replicates in acinar cells of the salivary glands and is secreted in the saliva of rabid animals that serve as vectors.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 26-year-old pet-groomer was brought to the casualty with a history of breathlessness, excessive agitation, and restlessness. His bystanders give a history of progressive behavioral change and he had a fever, sore throat, and generalized weakness 1 month back. On examination, pulse was 100 bpm, SpO2 was 98% on room air. Which of the following samples will not be preferred to detect the etiological agent?
explanation: The given case scenario is highly suggestive of rabies. Corneal impression smears are not performed, as they are of low diagnostic yield. Laboratory diagnosis of rabies is performed by the following methods: Antigen detection - Direct immunofluorescence (IF) from specimens of : Skin biopsy from the nape of the neck including hair follicles. Rabies antigen is present in cutaneous nerves at the base of hair follicles. It is the most sensitive and specific test. Corneal smears were previously used. They are not used anymore as they are of low diagnostic yield. Viral isolation- Intracerebral inoculation in mice can be attempted from the brain, CSF, and saliva. Antibody demonstration from serum and CSF. Viral RNA detection by RT-PCR . Postmortem examination of brain tissue samples- demonstration of Negri bodies.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An officer of the Indian Forest Services is bitten by a rabid fox while on duty. Which of the following statements is true about the etiological agent?
options: The incubation period is 4 to 5 days
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of infection with the street form of rabies virus. Street rabies causes disease. All mammals are susceptible to rabies. Cattle, cats and foxes are highly susceptible, whereas dogs and humans have intermediate susceptibility. Differences between street rabies and fixed rabies: Street rabies Fixed rabies (produced by re peated passages) Causes disease Doesn't cause disease Produces Negri body Doesn't produce Negri body Affects salivary glands Doesn't affect salivary glands Incubation period- 3 mont hs Incubation period- 4-5 days
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 23-year-old man was brought to you with a history of fever, behavioral changes, and seizures. He is foaming at the mouth and is unable to ingest liquids. The patient was admitted to the ICU, however he died soon after. Post mortem brain samples showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given image showing Negri bodies and the case scenario of fever, neurological symptoms like seizures and altered sensorium, hydrophobia (due to painful muscle contractions during swallowing liquids), and hypersalivation are suggestive of encephalitic rabies. Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in rabies. The image below shows Negri bodies:
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Babes nodules are seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Babes nodules are seen in rabies. Mononuclear inflammatory infiltration in the leptomeninges, including microglial nodules are called Babes nodules. The most characteristic pathologic finding in rabies is the Negri body. These are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in brain neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. The image given below shows Negri bodies.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
Which of the following statements is false regarding rabies vaccination?
Bitten dog should be observed for a minimum of 10 days.
options: Four-dose regimen is given as 0.1ml intramuscularly on days 0, 3, 7 and 28.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis regimen consists of 3 doses.
The dose of human anti rabies immunoglobulin is 20 IU/kg.
explanation: According to the Updated Thai Red Cross Regimen (2-2-2-0-2) for post exposure prophylaxis, reconstituted rabies vaccine is given as follows: 0.1 ml intradermally Sites - two sites at the same visit. It is given in both the deltoids Schedule - Days 0, 3, 7, and 28 Healthy dogs, cats, or ferrets may be confined and observed for 10 days. The dosage of equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG) is 40 IU/kg while that of human anti-rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG) is 20 IU/kg body weight. PrEP regimens for individuals of all ages are as follows: Three intramuscular or intradermal vaccine doses on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. Arboviruses and Picorna Viruses
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which family does yellow fever virus belong to?
explanation: Yellow fever virus belongs to the family flaviviridae, which contains the genus Flavivirus. The important species under genus Flavivirus include: Yellow fever virus Dengue virus Japanese encephalitis virus Kyasanur forest disease virus West Nile encephalitis Zikavirus Note: Arbovirus is a term used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors. There is no family or order by the name arbovirus. The word arbovirus stands for ARthropod-BOrne virus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 10-year-old boy from Uttar Pradesh was rushed to the emergency department with a headache, fever, and blurred vision followed shortly by unresponsiveness to verbal commands. He is suspected to have viral encephalitis. Which of the following transmits this endemic disease?
explanation: Endemic viral encephalitis is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnuii. It is the leading cause of childhood neurological viral infection in India. In endemic areas such as North India, it typically affects children <15 years of age as by early adulthood, the majority of the population has protective immunity following natural exposure to the virus. Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts, while the amplifier hosts are pigs. It is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, and human infection is a tangential dead end.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?
options: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control
explanation: Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus. Option A: The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species. Option B: Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts. Option D: The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs. The image below shows the life cycle of the Japanese B encephalitis virus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A mother brings her 9-month-old child for vaccination against Japanese encephalitis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this vaccine?
options: Two doses are recommended at age 9 months and 18 months
Inactivated vero cell culture is given 4 weeks apart
Live vaccine SA 14-14-2 is administered intramuscularl
The live attenuated vaccine can be given to adolescents
explanation: Live SA 14-14-2 strain of Japanese encephalitis (JE) vaccine is administered subcutaneously. Types of JE Vaccines: SA 14-14-2 cell culture derive d vaccine Inactivated vero cell culture derived Kolar (Jenvac 82156 XY) Live attenuated Inactivated Route of administratio n Subcutaneous Intramuscular Intramuscul ar Dosage 2 doses 2 doses 2 doses Duration between dose s At ages 9months and 16-18 m onths 4 weeks apart 4 weeks apar t Ages 9 months, 16-18 months, ado lescents and non-immune ad ults up to 15 years up to 18 year s
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever. It presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in dengue appears as white islands on a red sea due to erythema with petechiae. The alternative name for dengue, breakbone fever, comes from the associated muscle and joint pains. Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies. The treatment of dengue is supportive with hydration taking top priority.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 35-year-old wildlife photographer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia. On examination, you notice gingival bleeds and conjunctival hemorrhages. He recently visited a forest in Karnataka that has a large population of monkeys. Which of these is the vector for the suspected disease?
explanation: The given case scenario with exposure to monkeys, fever, myalgia, headache, conjunctival hemorrhage and gingival bleeds is suggestive of Kyasanur forest disease (KFD), which is transmitted by ticks (Haemophysalis spinigera). It is endemic to the forests of Karnataka and Kerala. The clinical features include: Fever Headache Conjunctivitis Myalgia Meningoencephalitis Hemorrhagic symptoms- hemorrhages in skin, mucosa and gastrointestinal bleeds. The case fatality rate is about 5 percent. Monkeys are amplifier hosts, rodents are reservoirs and humans are incidental hosts. A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A middle-aged man presents with delirium, fever, jaundice, and a hemorrhagic diathesis. The patient is agitated and has had no urine output in the last 6 hours. On investigation, there is azotemia and elevated liver enzymes. A viral disease with the vector shown below is suspected. Which of the following inclusion bodies may be seen?
explanation: The image shows the Aedes aegypti mosquito and the clinical scenario with hepatic and renal dysfunction with delirium points towards a diagnosis of yellow fever. Torres bodies are amorphous eosinophilic nuclear inclusions associated with yellow fever, a disease caused by the Flavivirus. Inclusion bodies are structures with distinct sizes and shapes that are seen in virus-infected cells under light microscopy. Note: Dengue hemorrhagic fever can be a differential diagnosis, but there are no inclusion bodies seen in dengue.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the duration of validity of 17D vaccination?
explanation: 17D vaccine (yellow fever vaccine) is valid for a lifetime, beginning 10 days after vaccination. According to the amendment in 2016 to International Health Regulations 2005, the validity of the related international certificate of vaccination against yellow fever has been changed from ten (10) years to the lifespan of the person (traveler) vaccinated. It is a live-attenuated vaccine derived from the 'Asibi strain', administered subcutaneously. Immunity after a single dose is long-lasting and provides lifetime protection. It is thermolabile. Vaccination is compulsory for travel to and from endemic areas. In India, 17D is manufactured at the Central Research Institute, Kasauli.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A pest control technician with a history of fever, vomiting, hematuria, and decreased urine output was diagnosed with hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome. Which of the following statements is false about the causative virus?
options: Hantaviruses are the natural pathogens of rodents
Transmission primarily occurs by Culex mosquitoes
Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome presents with pulmonary edema
explanation: Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) is caused by Hantaviruses. They are rodent-borne viruses that are transmitted by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. They are the natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and voles. HFRS presents with acute kidney injury, hemorrhages, fever, and circulatory collapse. Hantaviruses can also cause Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. Note: In Aug 2016, The International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV), has renamed and moved the genus Hantavirus to Orthohantavirus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An epidemic of paralytic poliomyelitis occurs in a non-immune population. Which among the following strains of poliovirus is the most common cause of this?
explanation: Type 1 poliovirus is the most common cause of epidemics in populations. Poliovirus strains have been classified into 3 types: Type 1- most common and causes most of the epidemics. Type 2- endemic infections. Type 3- epidemics but rarer than type 1. Immunity is type-specific. Note :- Type 2 is declared eradicated in September, 2015 and Type 3 is declared eradicated in October, 2019
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrics OPD with a history of lower-limb paralysis and the following deformity. Which of the following will be the most common form of presentation of this illness?
explanation: The given case scenario with a history of lower limb paralysis and deformity is suggestive of poliomyelitis. The given image shows deformity of the right lower limb, namely hyperextension at the knee joint and muscle wasting. Inapparent infection is the most common (90-95%) presentation of polio. Only seroconversion occurs without any clinical manifestations. Option B: Abortive poliomyelitis is associated with primary viremia and presents as fever, headache, sore throat, and malaise lasting for 1-5 days. Option C: Paralytic poliomyelitis occurs following minor illness, characterized by biphasic fever with headache, stiff neck, and flaccid paralysis. Option D: In non-paralytic poliomyelitis, the disease does not progress beyond the stage of aseptic meningitis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 20-year-old unimmunized patient presents to you with complaints of weakness of lower limbs, inability to pass urine, and fever, for 3 days. His stool samples were sent to the district lab to confirm the diagnosis. Which region of the spinal cord will primarily be affected in these cases?
explanation: The given case scenario of fever, lower limb paralysis, urinary retention, and stool samples being sent for diagnosis, is suggestive of paralytic polio. The anterior horn cells of the spinal cord are primarily affected, causing acute flaccid paralysis. Posterior horns and intermediate columns/lateral horns may also be involved to some extent. In the central nervous system, the virus multiplies selectively in the neurons and destroys them. The earliest change is the degeneration of Nissl bodies (chromatolysis). Nuclear changes follow. Note: Fecal samples of all cases of acute flaccid paralysis are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72 hours of collection at 4–8°C or frozen at -20°C. This is known as the reverse cold chain and is done as a part of gold standard polio surveillance/acute flaccid paralysis surveillance (AFP surveillance).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding vaccination against polio?
options: Sabin type has the live attenuated virus
OPV should not be administered to immunocompromised persons
Salk vaccine is associated with mutations that lead to reversal of virulence
Both OPV and IPV induce humoral Ig™
explanation: Salk type is the killed vaccine, hence there is no risk of mutation that can lead to a reversal of virulence. There are two types of vaccines for polio - IPV (inactivated poliovirus vaccine) and OPV (oral poliovirus vaccine).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following strains of poliovirus have been eradicated worldwide?
explanation: Type 2 and 3 have been eradicated worldwide. Type 2: In September 2015, WHO declared the eradication of the wild type 2 poliovirus strain. In India, the last type 2 infection was detected in 1999. Type 3: It has not been detected anywhere in the world since November 2012. On World Polio Day in October 2019, the type 3 virus was declared to be eradicated worldwide. The only circulating strain is type 1.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 68-year-old woman presented with acute chest pain which was stabbing type in nature. The pain is spasmodic and associated with fever spikes. There's an outbreak of coxsackievirus B in her community. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given case scenario with stabbing type chest pain which is spasmodic in nature, associated with fever spikes, and history of an outbreak of coxsackievirus B is suggestive of Bornholm disease or epidemic pleurodynia. Symptoms include paroxysms of acute pleuritic chest pain associated with fever spikes. Involved muscles are tender. Chest X-ray is usually normal. Most cases occur during epidemics of coxsackievirus B. The disease is named after the Danish island of Bornholm where early cases occurred. The treatment is non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents or hot fomentation of the involved muscles. Other diseases associated with coxsackievirus B: Neonatal myocarditis and pericarditis Juvenile diabetes mellitus Orchitis Severe disseminated congenital infection- hepatitis, meningoencephalitis, adrenocortical involvement
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, fever, and vomiting. On examination, you observe the following. He is diagnosed with herpangina. Which group of viruses causes the same?
explanation: The given image shows palatal ulcers in herpangina. It is caused by the coxsackievirus A, a large subgroup of the enteroviruses. Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by grayish- white papulovesicular lesions on an erythematous base that ulcerate. These are present on: Soft palate Anterior pillars of tonsils Uvula Posterior oropharynx It is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackievirus A infection in children, but it can also be caused by coxsackievirus B, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71. Treatment is usually only supportive, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease?
explanation: The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks. Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents. Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus: Aseptic meningitis associated with a maculopapular rash. Herpangina Minor respiratory infections
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 60-year-old presented with eye pain, watering of eyes, and increased sensitivity to light. On examination, you see the following. Which of the following viruses can cause this condition?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (AHC) caused mainly by Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A24 variant (CA24v). It is characterized by sudden swelling, congestion, and watering of the eyes. Subconjunctival hemorrhages are a characteristic feature and corneal involvement may occur transiently. There is no treatment currently available. The disease is self limiting, and resolves within a five to seven-day period. Note: Acute follicular conjunctivitis is caused by Adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, 7 and 11.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A 42-year-old woman presented with fever, joint pains, and headache. Chik sign (image given below) is present on the patient's nose. Which of the following vectors transmits the etiological agent?

Culex tritaeniorhynchus
explanation: The given case scenario with fever, joint pain, headache, and Chik sign is suggestive of chikungunya which is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. Chikungunya presents with sudden onset of fever, crippling joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1–6 days. Nose pigmentation is striking in cases of Chikungunya fever and is termed as Chik sign No animal reservoir has been identified. Note: Although Chikungunya is transmitted by both Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, A.Aegypti is considered primary vector of transmission for Chikungunya. Miscellaneous Viruses - Rubella, Coronaviruses, Prions, Rotavirus, Filovirus, Zika Virus and Nipah Virus
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A newborn baby has a characteristic rash as shown below. On examination, bilateral pearly white nuclear cataracts are noted, and a continuous murmur is auscultated. What family does the virus implicated in this syndrome belong to?
explanation: The clinical scenario of bilateral nuclear cataracts, blueberry muffin rash (image), and patent ductus arteriosus(murmur) suggest congenital rubella syndrome. Rubella virus belongs to the family Matonaviridae. Rubella virus previously belonged to family Togaviridae, but has been recently changed to family Matonaviridae by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of viruses (ICTV), making it the sole genus under the family Matonaviridae. Option A: Rhabdoviridae includes Rabies virus. Option B: Filoviridae includes Marburg virus and Ebola virus. Option D: Calciviridae includes Norwalk agent.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A brain biopsy done at the time of autopsy shows spongiform encephalopathy. Which of the following is unlikely to be the diagnosis?
explanation: Spongiform encephalopathy is a feature of prion disease. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a prion disease. SSPE is a rare and chronic form of progressive brain inflammation caused by a persistent infection with the measles virus. Slow virus diseases are characterized by a long asymptomatic period, often months or years in duration, between the introduction of the infectious agent and the appearance of clinical illness. Examples: AIDS, Kuru, CJD, SSPE, PML CJD, Kuru, and mad cow disease are classified under slow virus diseases which are caused by prions.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which strain of the Ebola virus has the highest case fatality rate?
explanation: The Zaire strain has a case fatality rate of 90% There are five identified Ebola virus strains, four of which are known to cause disease in humans: Ebola virus (Zaire ebolavirus) Sudan virus (Sudan ebolavirus) Taï Forest virus (Taï Forest ebolavirus) Bundibugyo virus (Bundibugyo ebolavirus). The fifth, Reston virus (Reston ebolavirus), has caused disease in nonhuman primates, but not in humans. The Bundibugyo ebolavirus, Zaire ebolavirus, and Sudan ebolavirus have been associated with large outbreaks in Africa. The strain that caused the 2014–2016 West African outbreak belongs to the Zaire ebolavirus species.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is a leading cause of diarrheal death in children?
explanation: Rotavirus is a leading cause of diarrheal death among children in the developing world. Rotavirus infections occur in most children below the age of 5 years and are most frequent between 6-24 months of age. Neonatal infections are common but are often asymptomatic or mild. Vaccines for rotavirus: RotaTeq and Rotarix, given orally. Note: Viruses that can cause diarrhoea in children include: Rotavirus (most common) Norwalk virus Adenovirus- types 40 and 41 Astrovirus Coronavirus Sapovirus The image below shows an electron micrograph image of the Rotavirus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An 18-year-old went on an exchange program to Singapore. An adventurous eater, she tried clams and oysters on a cruise ship. 2 days later, she developed fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. What is the causative agent?
explanation: The clinical scenario describes a case of Norwalk infection. It is the most common cause of diarrhea in older children and adults. They occur in group settings such as banquet halls, cruise ships, dormitories, and campgrounds, where outbreak sources are usually contaminated food and/or water. Potential sources of contaminated food include shellfish such as clams and oysters, which are contaminated by water. Clinical features are nausea, vomiting, watery diarrhea, abdominal pain. Symptoms of gastroenteritis develop 12 to 48 hours after being exposed to norovirus. The image below is an electron micrograph of Norovirus (Norwalk virus).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 70-year-old lady with recent onset, progressive dementia comes with myoclonus. The brain imaging is shown below. What biochemical component is responsible for this disease?
explanation: The clinical features and imaging suggest a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease(CJD), caused by prions. Prions are composed of protein. These are infectious protein particles that lack any nucleic acid. They are filterable like viruses but are resistant to agents of sterilization. Prion proteins have two isoforms: PrPSc is the prion protein that causes disease. PrPc is the normal prion protein, found in human cells. Prions cause diseases such as CJD, Kuru, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's. Laboratory diagnosis of prion diseases: Measurement of PrPSc by immunoassa Brain MRI Brain biops Stress protein 14-3-3 Sequencing PRNP gene Abnormal EEG
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 32-year-old lady is admitted to the ICU with COVID-19. Which of the following statements is false regarding the organism causing it?
options: These viruses have club-shaped peplomers on their surface
It acts by binding to ACE1 and TMPRSS4 receptors
explanation: The coronavirus spike protein binds to the ACE2 and TMPRSS2 receptors to enter the human cells. Coronaviruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses having club or petal-shaped peplomers. Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface. It spreads through coughing, sneezing, and close personal contact such as touching the mouth, nose. The virus is highly mutable and so vaccine prophylaxis for all strains is difficult. Coronaviruses cause upper respiratory tract infections, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), and Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (MERS). They spread by inhalation of the virus present in droplets or aerosols of respiratory secretions of the patients. Basic protective measures against the new coronavirus: (SARS-CoV-2) Wash your hands frequently for at least 20 seconds. Maintain social distancing- Maintain at least 1 meter distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth Practice respiratory hygiene- cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when ou cough or sneeze, then dispose of the used tissue immediately. If you have fever, cough, and difficulty breathing, seek medical care earl Stay informed and follow the advice given by your healthcare provider
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A person who comes in contact with a case of coronavirus (COVID- 19) needs to be followed up for .
explanation: A person who comes in contact with a coronavirus(COVID-19) case (confirmed or probable) needs to be followed up for apperance of symptoms of coronavirus for the maximum incubation period of 14 days. Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment recommended for COVID-19. People with COVID-19 should receive supportive care to help relieve symptoms. For severe cases, treatment should include care to support vital organ functions. Basic protective measures against the new coronavirus: (SARS CoV 2) Wash your hands frequently for atleast 20 seconds. Maintain social distancing- Maintain at least 1 metre distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth Practice respiratory hygiene- cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when ou cough or sneeze, then dispose of the used tissue immediately. If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical care earl Stay informed and follow advice given by your healthcare provider
subject: Microbiology

question_text: In a patient undergoing testing for SARS-CoV, a FELUDA test is done. Which of the following statements is false about this technology?
options: It is the acronym for FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assa
Based on CRISPR gene editing technolog
It is slower than RT PCR in detecting SARS-CoV2
It uses CAS-9 protein to bind to the viral signature
explanation: FELUDA is faster than RT-PCR in detecting SARS-CoV2. FELUDA (FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay) is a newly approved method based on CRISPR gene-editing technology to identify and target the genetic material of SARS-CoV2. The CRISPR technology uses a highly specific CAS9 protein to find and bind to the target Covid signature. This is then coupled with paper-strip chemistry to elicit a visual readout on a paper strip. It is a very affordable, sensitive (96%), and specific (98%) strip test which can detect viral genetic material within 45 minutes.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral haemorrhagic fevers was found in India?
explanation: Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever, is caused by Nairovirus species. It is zoonotic in origin with ticks as vectors. The outbreak was caused due to person-to-person transmission in hospitals.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test, 1 month after taking the MMR vaccine. At the time of receiving the vaccine, she had been advised to avoid conception. What advice do you give her now?
options: Low risk; termination of pregnancy may be considered
High risk of anomalies; serious consideration for termination
explanation: In this case scenario, the doctor should advise the patient to wait and watch. The vaccine should not be administered during pregnancy. If pregnancy occurs within 28 days of immunization, the patient should be counseled on the theoretical risks for the fetus. Studies of over 200 women who had been inadvertently immunized with rubella vaccine during pregnancy showed that none of their offspring developed congenital rubella syndrome. Therefore, termination of pregnancy is probably not warranted.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: While working at a WHO outreach post in Africa, you conduct an educational program about the Zika virus. What family does this virus belong to?
explanation: Zika virus belongs to the family Flaviviridae. It is classified by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV): Family: Flaviviridae Genus: Flavivirus Species: Zika virus Zika virus is an RNA virus that is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito bite and by sexual contact. It causes microcephaly and is associated with Guillain-Barré syndrome.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Zika virus is transmitted by:
explanation: Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome. The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following features do not support a diagnosis of Zika fever?
explanation: A petechial rash is not a primary feature of Zika virus infection. Though petechiae may rarely appear in Zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC case definition of Zika virus disease. Petechial rash points towards a diagnosis of dengue fever while a maculopapular rash suggests a Zika virus disease. Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and malaise. A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations. The complications of Zika virus are: Guillain-Barre syndrome Fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is-
explanation: The transplacental transmission of Zika virus given in the image causes microcephaly. The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an infected pregnant mother to her child. Zika virus is a mosquito-borne Flavivirus mainly transmitted through Aedes aegypti. Symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. Fever Rash Conjunctivitis Muscle and joint pain Malaise Headache In pregnancy- congenital Zika syndrome or microcephal The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis. NCDC Delhi and the National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Tropical spastic paraparesis is caused by:
explanation: is the causative agent of the neurodegenerative disorder HTLV-1-associated myelopathy or tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP). The condition resembles multiple sclerosis and is associated with progressive weakness of legs and lower body. The patients develop spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, hyperreflexia, ankle clonus, and extensor plantar response. The disease progresses slowly and takes the form of thoracic myelopathy. Other conditions caused by HTLV-1 include: Adult T-cell leukemias and lymphomas (ATL) Uveitis Infective dermatitis Arthritis Sjo■gren’s syndrome
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
What family does the Nipah virus belong to?
Paramyxoviridae
explanation: Nipah virus belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae. Togaviridae contains chikungunya virus. Flaviviridae contains yellow fever virus, dengue virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, hepatitis C virus, Zika virus Bunyaviridae contains sandfly fever virus, hantaviruses. Superficial and Systemic Mycoses
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is a component of the fungal cell wall?
explanation: Chitin is a component of the fungal cell wall. General characteristics of Fungi: They are unicellular/multicellular eukaryotes. The cell wall contains chitin, glucan, mannan and other polysaccharides. The cytoplasmic membrane contains ergosterol. They possess true nuclei with the nuclear membrane and paired chromosomes. They divide sexually, asexually or by both. Raymond Sabouraud is known as the Father of Mycology.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is a yeast?
explanation: Cryptococcus is a yeast. Option A: Candida is a yeast-like fungus. Option C: Fusarium is a mold/filamentous fungus. Option D: Talaromyces is a dimorphic fungus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
explanation: Sporangiospore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore. Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation: Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group. Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and other sub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it. Class Sexual spore Asexual spore Glomerulomycetes Oospores, Zygospo res Sporangiospo res Ascomycetes Ascospores Conidia Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Conidia Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromy cetes) Yet to be identified Conidia
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following fungal spores are formed by condensation of the hyphal elements?
explanation: Arthrospores are asexual spores that are formed along the mycelium/hyphae by segmentation and condensation of hyphae. Arthrospores are commonly formed by dermatophytes, especially those belonging to the genus Trichophyton. They are also formed by dimorphic fungi like Coccidiodes sp.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance suggest pityriasis versicolor. Pityriasis versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas. The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance. Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks. The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolour over the chest. Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements about dermatophytes is true?
explanation: Microsporum infects only skin and hair, not nails. Dermatophytes include 3 genera: Microsporum: It infects only hair and skin (not nails). The species included in this genus are- M. gypseum M. canis M. nanum. Epidermophyton: It infects only skin and nails (not hair). E. floccosum is the only species in this genus. Trichophyton: It infects skin, hair, and nails. The species falling under this genus are- T. rubrum T. mentagrophytes T. tonsurans T. schoenleinii T. violaceum
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 23-year-old-lady came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of hair loss and the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft as shown. There is no associated pruritis of the scalp. Which of the following could be the most probable causative agent?
explanation: The presence firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft is suggestive of black piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Piedraia hortae. Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types: Black piedra: It is characterized by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. Hair becomes brittle and breaks easily leading to complains of hair loss. It is caused by Piedraia hortae. White piedra: It is characterized by soft, white or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii. Management involves shaving or cutting off the affected hair along with topical antifungals.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of discoloration of his toenail for the past 4 months as shown in the image below. Which pathogen most commonly causes this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of onychomycosis and the pathogen most commonly causing this condition is Trichophyton rubrum. Diabetes increases the risk of onychomycosis. Onychomycosis refers to nail infections caused by fungi. It can be due to dermatophytes, non-dermatophytic moulds, and candida. Tinea unguium refers to nail infections caused by dermatophytes. This condition may affect toenails or fingernails, but toenail infections are particularly common. The following photomicrograph of the nail segment in KOH shows T. rubrum fungal hyphae invading nail cells. The following image is of a lactophenol cotton blue(LPCB) mount showing pyriform shaped microconidia on the hyphae of T. rubrum.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
explanation: Sporothrix schenckii causes infection followed by traumatic inoculation into the skin. It is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection. This is usually further followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes as shown in the image below. Subcutaneous mycoses are usually caused by traumatic inoculation of the causative fungus. question_text: Which of the following is false about the most commonly used culture media for growing fungi?
explanation: Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) is the most commonly used culture media for growing fungi. It does not contain taurocholate. It consists of antibiotics like gentamicin or chloramphenicol to inhibit the contaminant bacteria and also cycloheximide to inhibit the growth of saprophytic fungi. It has an acidic pH of 5.4. Media used in mycology can be classified as: Specific media- SDA agar Czapek-Dox medium Birdseed agar Cornmeal agar Non-specific media- Blood agar Brain heart infusion agar
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presented with multiple ulcerative eruptions along the lymphatics of his hand. A tissue biopsy was taken and sent for culture. Microscopic examination of the organism cultured is shown in the image. Identify the organism.
explanation: The presence of multiple ulcerative eruptions along the lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It is a thermally dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation. The lesions occur following traumatic inoculation of the fungus. A granulomatous nodule is first formed at the site of inoculation that may progress to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. The infection can spread via lymphatic channels from the skin and subcutaneous tissue to the lymph nodes resulting in formation of secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes. This condition is known as lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. This disease is commonly encountered among gardeners, forest workers and manual labourers. Clinical presentation of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis:
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A farmer developed multiple ulcerative nodules along the lymphatics following a rose thorn prick a week ago. Microscopic finding of the skin biopsy is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows an asteroid body which is characteristically seen in a case of sporotrichosis. Asteroid bodies are formed due to the deposition of the immune complexes around the yeast cell. It consists of a central rounded or oval basophilic, cigar-shaped yeast cell surrounded peripherally by eosinophilic radiations. Formation of such structures is called the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon. Note: Asteroid bodies are also seen in sarcoidosis. Those are irregular, star-shaped inclusions seen in multinucleate giant cells.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis. Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics. Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies. question_text: A middle-aged man from south India presented to the OPD with a swelling in his left foot that is unresponsive to antibiotics. On examination, multiple discharging sinuses were noted. The discharge contained brown granules that were soft in consistency. Which of the following is ikely the causative agent?
explanation: A swelling with multiple discharging sinuses with brown granules that is unresponsive to the antibiotics is suggestive of eumycetoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis. Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It can be divided into three types- eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis. Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources. Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible. It results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging these grains or granules. Laboratory Diagnosis: A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic. B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi. Treatment: The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma on the other hand, responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole. Option A: Actinomadura madurae causes actinomycetoma which would respond to antibiotics. Option B: Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis which is characterised by lesions along the route of lymphatics. Option C: Fonsecaea pedrosoi causes chromoblastomycosis which would not have discharging sinuses.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus?
explanation: Pneumocystis jirovecii is a yeast-like fungus and not a dimorphic fungus. Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C). Examples of dimorphic fungi include: Blastomyces dermatitidis Coccidioides immitis Paracoccidioides brasiliensis Talaromyces marneffei Sporothrix schenckii Histoplasma capsulatum Coccidioides posadasii
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 54-year-old man had presented to the clinic with a history of chronic cough. His chest X-ray showed a mass in the left lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the mass was done and findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical history and the presence of tiny yeast forms within macrophages are suggestive of Histoplasmosis which is also called Darling's disease. Other names of this condition include Cave's disease and Ohio disease. The causative agent is a dimorphic fungus called Histoplasma capsulatum. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia. After inhalation, the conidia develop into yeast cells and are engulfed by alveolar macrophages. Within macrophages, the yeasts may disseminate to reticuloendothelial tissues, such as the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes. Biopsy reveals tiny (2-4 microns) oval-shaped yeast cells inside macrophages. On culture and microscopy, tuberculate macroconidia and hyaline septate mold with microconidia are seen. It is treated using azole antifungals.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 7-year-old boy with a recent history of travel to South America was brought to the hospita with fever, enlarged lymph nodes and multiple skin lesions on his face. Tissue sample from the lesion shows the following findings under microscopy. Which of the following is the most ikely causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical history and the characteristic pilot's wheel appearance on culture(image) is suggestive of paracoccidioidomycosis caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It is also called Lutz mycosis/ South American blastomycosis. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus that causes a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes. On culture, yeast form is seen at 37° C and the mycelial form at 25° C. Microscopy of tissue sample reveals thick walled, round, yeast cells with numerous buds attached to each other circumferentially giving the classic mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance. Most infections are asymptomatic and few individuals with acute disease present with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and skin lesions. The below image shows skin lesions in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis. Treatment: Mild/moderate disease: Itraconazole Severe disease: Amphotericin B for 2-3weeks followed by Itraconazole.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 50-year-old male presents with low-grade fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He had a history of recent travel to North America. Chest X-Ray reveals consolidation in the right lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 37°C shows thick-walled, arge (7-20 µ), round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with pulmonary and cutaneous involvement along with a history of travel to North America and the characteristic culture findings suggests the diagnosis of Blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces dermitidis. Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially, in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and so is also called North Amerian Blastomycosis. The causative organism is a thermally dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in the soil. Blastomycosis can present in three forms: Pulmonary disease: Presents with cough, sputum production, chest pain, and fever Hilar lymphadenopathy may be present Focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation may occur. Resembles TB and Histoplasmosis Cutaneous disease: Involvement of face and exposed parts of the skin Skin lesion: ulcerated verrucous granulomas with an advancing border and central scarring. The border is filled with microabscesses and has a sharp, sloping edge. (image in stem) Disseminated disease: Multiple skin lesions are the most common presentation Highly fata Genitourinary tract (especially prostate) is frequently involved Bone involvement resembles chronic osteomyelitis. It can be diagnosed based on culture findings. Characterictic findings include the presence of thick-walled round yeast cell with a single broad-based bud when cultured at 37°C. (figure of 8 appearance) Treatment: Localised mild/moderate disease - Itraconazole (6 months) Disseminated/ severe disease - Amphotericin B
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A middle-aged man residing in a rural area presents with psychosis, ataxia and convulsions. On further inquiry, you find out there is history of similar complaints in the family members who recently consumed food prepared with grains as shown in the image. What is the poisoning is most likely due to?
explanation: The given clinical vignette and the presence of dark coloured ergot growing on the wheat as shown in the image are suggestive of ergotism due to Claviceps purpurea Mycotic poisoning is of two types: Mycetism and Mycotoxicosis Mycetism: The fungus itself causes toxic effects. Examples: Claviceps  Ergot poisoning Coprine  coprine poisoning Inocybe  muscarine poisoning Mycotoxicosis: Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects. Examples: Aflatoxins: These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus. Fusarium toxins Citrinin toxin was first isolated from Penicillium citrinum.
subject: Microbiology

The below given image shows result of hair perforation test. The organism likely to show below given appearance is

Trichophyton rubrum
explanation: Image shows surface erosion of shaft caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes. Hair perforation test: Done to differentiate Trichophyton rubrum from mentagrophytes. Few strands of human hair are placed in a petridish with 20 ml of distilled water and autoclaved. Few drops of sterile 10% yeast extract and a few fragments of the test fungus are added to the hair strands. Incubated at 250C for 2-3 weeks. Hair is removed and examined microscopically in a lactophenol cotton blue stained wet preparation. T.mentagrophytes causes surface erosion of the shaft resulting in wedge shaped appearance of the shaft. Opportunistic Mycoses

question_text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus?
explanation: Mucicarmine stain is used in the identification of cryptococcus. Mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:
