question_text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding Cryptococcus neoformans?
options: It most commonly causes meningitis in AIDS patients
There are 3 serological types based on capsular polysaccharide
Niger seed agar is used to demonstrate melanin production
explanation: Pathogenic varieties of cryptococcus including C. neoformans and C. gattii are laccase positive. They also have ability to grow at 37° C and these factors are used to differentiate them from non-pathogenic cryptococci. Cryptococci have been classified into 5 serotypes (A, B, C, D, and AD) based on their capsular polysaccharide: Three serotypes fall under Cryptococcus neoformans - A(var. grubii), D(var. neoformans), and AD(a hybrid of serotypes A and D). Although serotype AD is very similar to serotypes A and D, the isolates still comprise a discrete group that can be distinguished. The serotypes B and C are now considered a different species - Cryptococcus gattii. Niger seed agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolation of Cryptococcus neoformans from clinical specimens. C. neoformans and C. gattii produces brown colonies on this medium due to the formation of melanin. Melanin is produced by laccase using caffeic acid as the substrate. The following image shows pigmented colonies of C. gattii growing on niger seed agar. Cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, is an opportunistic infection seen in individuals with AIDS. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this condition.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms cannot be grown on any culture media?
explanation: Rhinosporidium seeberi and Pneumocystis jirovecii are non-cultivable organisms and cannot be grown on any culture media. Another example of a non-cultivable fungus is Lacazia loboi. It causes Jorge Lobo's disease which is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis. Rhizopus oryzae is a mold which is easily cultivable on SDA. Dimorphic fungi like Histoplasma capsulatum and Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis are identified based on their colony morphology on SDA. Note: Recently, molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that Rhinosporidium is an aquatic protistan parasite. Infections due to Rhinosporidium have been classified under infections due to Protozoa under the ICD 11.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The findings of microscopic examination of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. Which is the most probable causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical picture and the GMS stained smear showing the black-colored cysts resembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. Chest X-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or with diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS. Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) and pentamidine isethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients having AIDS. The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A middle-aged immunocompromised patient presents with complaints of pain during swallowing. She describes it as a burning sensation that radiates to her back every time she swallows. Oral examination reveals creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mount microscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. Identify the organism.
explanation: The given clinical scenario of odynophagia, creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wet mount microscopy showing budding yeasts with pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasis caused by Candida albicans. It is an opportunistic infection commonly seen in immunocompromised states like AIDS, diabetes etc. Treatment includes topical azoles or nystatin.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The following test is positive for identification of
explanation: The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans. Unlike other species of candida, yeast cells of Candida albicans will begin to form germ tubes after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 35-year-old HIV positive■ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis. Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans. It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics. It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole. Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue. Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions. Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Galactomannan in serum is seen in:
explanation: The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive (deep-seated) mycoses caused by Aspergillus species. Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus. It can be detected in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage by ELISA for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children. This test is especially useful in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients or patients with hematologic malignancies. Other diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis are: A positive culture from the affected organ Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores Halo sign on CT scan
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain.
explanation: The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45o) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species. Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidial structures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides are arranged in basipetal chains. The following image shows the lactophenol cotton blue solution (LPCB) mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles. Option A: Mucor produces nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium. Option B: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores. Option D: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years. She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
explanation: The given clinical picture and the microscopic appearance is suggestive of fungal rhinosinusitis. The most probable causative organism is Aspergillus fumigatus. It is commonly involved in paranasal sinus mycoses (fungal sinusitis). The disease has been described to have four types: allergic non-invasive invasive fulminant A possible fifth type called non-invasive destructive type may also exist. Zygomycetes like mucor and rhizopus are the common agents in fulminant type of fungal sinusitis. The characteristic microscopic appearance of Aspergillus fumigatus: The vesicle is conical. Phialides are arranged in a single row. Conidia arise from the upper third of the vesicle and are hyaline. Option B: Aspergillus flavus appears as follows: The vesicle is globular. Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline. Option C: Aspergillus niger appear as follows: The vesicle is globular shaped. Phialides are in two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black. Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum appear as follows: Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores(brush or broom appearance).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
explanation: Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium. The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:  1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except?
explanation: The  1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis. This condition is usually diagnosed based on clinical features and culture. The test detects the presence of (1-3)--d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi. It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of 80 pg/mL is considered a positive result. F ngi that do not contain BDG in their cell walls include Cryptococcus neoformans Zygomycetes like rhizopus and mucor Blastomyces dermatitidis Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by zygomycetes, which do not contain (1-3)--d-glucan, and hence, the  1-3 glucan assay cannot be used for its diagnosis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis ?
explanation: Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis. Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A 68-year-old post-COVID-19 patient presented with a black, foul-smelling nasal discharge and blurred vision. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass eroding the septum and hard palate was visualised. Lactophenol cotton blue mount from the culture is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

It is a fatal condition
options: Iron administration to patients with active infection should be avoided
Posaconazole can be used to treat it
Pulmonary form is the most common
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the LPCB mount showing aseptate hyphae branching at right-angles is strongly suggestive of mucormycosis. Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. Pulmonary mucormycosis is the second most common form. Mucormycosis is an invasive disease caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The disease is often characterized by hyphae growing in and around the blood vessels. It can turn fatal on cerebral involvement and development of speticemia. Risk factors for the infection include: Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis). Elevated levels of free iron. Defects in phagocytic function. Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation. Treatment of choice is Amphotericin-B. Posaconazole can be used as an alternative drug. General Parasitology
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 9-year-old child infected with Toxocara canis is diagnosed to have visceral larva migrans. It is an example of .
explanation: Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting a human is an example of an aberrant parasite. It is defined as a parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further. Parasites can be classified as: Ectoparasites - inhabit only the body surface of the host without penetrating the tissue. The term infestation is often used for parasitization. e.g., lice, ticks, and mites. Endoparasite - lives within the body of the host and causes infection. Endoparasites are further classified as follows: Obligate parasites - cannot exist without a host. e.g., Toxoplasma gondii and Plasmodium. Facultative parasites - exist as either parasitic or free-living forms. e.g., Naegleria fowleri. Accidental parasites - infects an unusual host. e.g., Echinococcus granulosus infects man Aberrant/Wandering parasites - infects a host where they cannot develop further. e.g., Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting humans.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following refers to a host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development?
explanation: A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is referred to as the paratenic host. For example, in the lifecycle of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), humans are the definitive host. The first intermediate host is cyclops and the second is small freshwater fish. If the small freshwater fish with the plerocercoid larva get eaten by a larger fish, the larva survives in the larger fish. This makes the larger fish a paratenic host. Host is an organism that harbors the parasite and provides nourishment and shelter to it. It is relatively larger than the parasite. Types of hosts: Definitive host - harbors stages of sexual reproduction of the parasite. Intermediate host - harbors stages of asexual multiplication of the parasite. Paratenic host - harbors only the larval stage of the parasite which remains viable without further development. Reservoir host - harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other susceptible hosts, especially in endemic areas. Accidental host - harbors a parasite that is not usually found in the host.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 46-year-old farmer came to the clinic with cough and chest pain for one week and fatigue for a month. He was diagnosed to have a hydatid cyst in his right lung. Which of the following classes does the causative organism of this disease belong to?
explanation: The causative organism of hydatid disease is Echinococcus granulosus and it belongs to the class cestodes. It is a tape-like, segmented worm. It infects man accidentally, giving rise to hydatid cysts. The image below shows the classification of parasites. Note: Zoonoses refers to diseases caused by zoonotic organisms. It is not a class of organisms.

question_text: Which of the following is the smallest cestode infecting humans?
explanation: The smallest cestode infecting humans is Hymenolepis nana. Option A: Diphyllobothrium latum is the longest cestode infecting man. Option C: Heterophyes heterophyes is the smallest trematode infecting man. Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode infecting man. Also, Fasciolopsis buski is the largest trematode infecting humans.

question_text: Which of the following parasites has a direct life cycle?
explanation: Enterobius vermicularis has a direct life cycle. Parasite requiring a single host to complete its development is said to have a direct life cycle. question_text: Match the following:
explanation: The correct answer is option B. A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly is likely suffering from Kala-azar caused by Leishmania donovani. Its intermediate host is sandfly. A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema is likely suffering from lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. Its intermediate host is the culex mosquito. question_text: An entomologist who had recently visited Mexico presented to the OPD with fever, fatigue, and an alleged history of contact with the insect given in the image. Which of the following diseases is it a biological vector for?
explanation: The image shows reduviid bug which is the biological vector for the transmission of Chagas disease. Acute Chagas disease can present as fever with fatigue and a subcutaneous swelling known as a chagoma. It may lead to fatal myocarditis. Biological vectors not only help in the transfer of parasites but the parasites undergo development or multiplication in their body as well. They are also called true vectors. Examples of biological vectors are: Mosquito - Malaria, filariasis Sandfly - Kala-azar Tsetse fly - Sleeping sickness Reduviid bugs - Chagas disease Ticks - Babesiosis
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Autoinfection is not seen with which of the following parasites?
explanation: Autoinfection is not seen in infection with Ascaris lumbricoides. Autoinfection refers to either of the following: Reinfection by microbes or parasitic organisms that are present on or within the body. It is also known as internal reinfection. e.g., Strongyloides. Self-infection by direct contact with a contagious agent, as with parasite eggs in the infectious state transmitted by fingernails. e.g., Pinworm. The following are the parasites causing autoinfection (mnemonic: CHEST.C) Cryptosporidium parvum Hymenolepis nana Enterobius vermicularis Strongyloides stercoralis Taenia solium Capillaria philippinensis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A microbiologist is doing research about antigenic variations in parasites. Which of the following parasites will exhibit this phenomenon?
explanation: Trypanosoma brucei exhibits antigenic variation within the host. This genetic switch protects them from antibodies. These trypanosomes exhibit unique antigenic variations of their glycoproteins. There is a cyclical fluctuation in the trypanosomes occurring in the blood of infected vertebrates after every 7–10 days. Parasites exhibiting antigenic variation include: Trypanosoma brucei gambiense Trypanosome brucei rhodesiense Plasmodium spp. Giardia lamblia The following image shows Trypanosoma brucei. The following image shows Plasmodium spp. The following image shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

question_text: You order a peripheral blood film examination while evaluating a patient with pyrexia of unknown origin. Which of the following organisms cannot be detected by this investigation?
explanation: Stool examination is useful for the detection of Giardia lamblia, not peripheral blood film examination. Examination of blood is of vital importance for demonstrating parasites that circulate in blood vessels. Examples of parasites found in the peripheral blood film: Protozoa Nematodes Plasmodium spp.Babesia spp. Trypanosoma spp.Leishmani a spp. WuchereriabancroftiBrugia malayiLoa loaMansonella sp p.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed?
explanation: The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii cannot be done using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. It is done mainly by serology, which shows a rise in the titer of specific antibodies to C. burnetii. Microorganisms such as Histoplasma, Leishmania, Toxoplasma, and Pneumocystis can also be detected with Giemsa, and in gastric tissues, Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) appear thin and distinctly blue. Giemsa’s stain is frequently used for diagnostic purposes in haematology to differentiate the nuclear and cytoplasmic morphology of platelets, RBCs, WBCs, and parasites.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient has presented to the PHC with fever and chills. You order a rapid diagnostic test to detect HRP-2 antigen. Which of the following diseases is it used to diagnose?
explanation: HRP-2 antigen detection is used in the diagnosis of malaria. Malaria antigens detected by the rapid immunochromatographic test are: pLDH - positivity is seen in all Plasmodium species HRP-2 - positivity is specific for P. falciparum The below image shows rapid diagnostic test (RDT) kit for malaria.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: In a patient with a positive Casoni's skin test, which of the following infections will you suspect?
explanation: Casoni’s skin test is done in patients with hydatid disease. It is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction (type I). This test is abandoned now due to non-specificity and has been supplemented by serological tests.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient presented to the OPD with cough, chest pain, and expectoration of rusty colored sputum. He is diagnosed to have an oriental lung fluke infection. Which of the following parasites is implicated here?
explanation: Paragonimus westermani is commonly known as oriental lung fluke or Japanese lung fluke. It causes a pulmonary syndrome characterised by cough, chest pain and hemoptysis. Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue. The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs. Treatment: Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice. The following image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani, the oriental lung fluke.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A college student from Mangalore comes to the OPD with intermittent fever, headache, and chills for 1 week. She gives a history of malaria 1 year back for which she had received treatment. Which of the following species you would expect to see in the peripheral smear of this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malaria relapse and it is caused by Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale species. In case of P.vivax and P.ovale, two kinds of sporozoites are seen. Some multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts while others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites (resting forms). These dormant forms may get activated and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing true clinical relapse. It usually occurs after 6 to 12 months of complete cure from the disease. In case of P.falciparum and P.malariae, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen. In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A middle-aged woman comes to the clinic with abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and weight loss. Stool examination revealed bile-stained eggs. Which of the following organisms may not be implicated in this case?
explanation: Enterobius vermicularis eggs are non-bile stained and the others are bile stained. Enterobiasis commonly occurs in young children and is characterised by anal pruritus. The worm may migrate up to the uterus, fallopian tubes and into the peritoneum in adult women. This can lead to: Chronic salpingitis Cervicitis Peritonitis Recurrent urinary tract infections.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
You are examining a wet mount stool sample of a patient with diarrhea. As the eggs are not visible, you concentrate the sample using the saturated salt solution technique. Which of the following eggs will not float in this technique?
Trichuris tricuhria
explanation: The eggs of Strongyloides stercoralis will not float in a saturated salt solution. Concentration methods are used when the parasites in stool are scanty and difficult to identify in routine stool examination. It is of 2 types: Floatation methods- the feces are suspended in a solution of high specific gravity and eggs will float up. e.g. saturated salt solution technique, zinc sulfate centrifugal floatation technique. Sedimentation Methods - the feces are suspended in a solution with low specific gravity and eggs will sediment at the bottom. e.g. formol-ether sedimentation technique. Protozoology - Amoebae, Ciliates & Flagellates
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
The life cycle given below is of which of the following:

E. vermicularis
explanation: The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica. Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no animal reservoir. The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate to the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break down to form flask-shaped ulcer. The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the feces. Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external environment and are responsible for transmission. The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver. Note: The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be non-pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non-invasive diarrhea.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 40-year-old man is diagnosed to have amoebic dysentery. Which of the following is the infective form of the protozoan causing this disease?
explanation: The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica causing amoebic dysentery. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days. The following are the characteristic features of various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica: The trophozoite is found only in tissues. Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance. The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance. Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility. The below image shows trophozoite form. The precystic stage has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars. It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst. The cystic stage has a mature cyst with 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. Chromatid bars disappear. The below image shows cystic form.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of abdominal pain and 6 episodes of passing foul-smelling dark stool mixed with mucus and blood streaks. There is no history of fever and tenesmus. On examination, vitals are stable and localized tenderness is present in the right iliac fossa. Which of the following is most likely to cause this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amoebic dysentery and the causative agent is Entamoeba histolytica. Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis: Acute intestinal amebiasis- dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. Chronic amebiasis- low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. The amoebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region. A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon. The most appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole. Option A - Giardia is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence. Option C - Campylobacter presents with fever, pain, and watery diarrhea. The stool contains leucocytes and blood. Option D - Shigella causes bacillary dysentery which is characterised by fever and generalised abdominal tenderness.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You received a stool sample of a patient suspected to have dysentery in the microbiology lab. On microscopy, you observe the structures shown in the image. What other findings you will expect to see in this stool sample?
options: RBCs as discrete or in rouleaux
explanation: The given image is showing erythrophagocytosis (trophozoite with ingested RBCs) and this in the stool sample of a patient with features of dysentery is indicative of amoebic dysentery. The other stool microscopic finding seen in amoebic dysentery is Charcot-Leyden crystals. The ingested erythrocytes appear as dark inclusions. Erythrophagocytosis is the only characteristic that can be used to morphologically differentiate E. histolytica from the nonpathogenic entamoeba. Amoebic dysentery: Clinically, it is insidious in onset with localized abdominal tenderness. Tenesmus, toxicity, and fever are absent. Under microscopy, RBCs are clumped, yellowish-brown in color. Charcot-Leyden crystals and eosinophils are present. Charcot-Leyden crystals are diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile structures that may be seen in stool specimens under microscopy and represent breakdown products of eosinophils. The below image shows Charcot-Leyden crystals:
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient with abdominal pain and mucus in stool is diagnosed to have intestinal amoebiasis. Which of the following is the most common extraintestinal complication of this disease?
explanation: The most common extraintestinal complication of amoebiasis is hepatic amoebiasis. In intestinal amoebiasis, most of the trophozoites reach the liver. However, only a small portion of them actually lodge and multiply in the liver cells. Patients usually present with an enlarged, tender liver without detectable impairment of liver function called amoebic hepatitis. Few patients go on to develop amoebic liver abscess. The center of the abscess contains thick chocolate brown pus (anchovy sauce pus), which is made up of liquefied necrotic liver tissue. It is bacteriologically sterile and free of amoeba. The periphery is made up of nearly normal liver tissue containing invading amoeba. Complications and sequelae of intestinal amoebiasis: Fulminant amoebic colitis Toxic megacolon Perianal ulceration Amoeboma Extraintestinal amoebiasis Hepatic amoebiasis (most common)- Amoebic hepatitis and Amoebic liver abscess Amoebic appendicitis and peritonitis Pulmonary amoebiasis Cerebral amoebiasis Splenic abscess Cutaneous amoebiasis Genitourinary amoebiasis
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the casualty with complaints of nausea, vomiting and disorientation. His brother tells you they had recently gone on a camping trip where they had swum in a freshwater lake. On examination, Kernig's sign is positive. A spinal tap is performed and the findings of CSF wet mount microscopy are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing amoeboid trophozoite form with pseudopodia is suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. It is caused by Naegleria fowleri. It is also known as brain-eating amoeba. It occurs in 3 forms: cyst, amoeboid trophozoite and flagellate trophozoite forms. The infection usually follows swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. The amoebae invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges. Incubation period is 2 days to 2 weeks. Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B. Options B & D: Both Acanthamoeba and B.mandrillaris cause granulomatous amoebic meningoencephalitis which is a subacute condition. Option C: A. cantonensis is the most common cause of eosinophilic meningitis in Southeast Asia. It is a nematode(roundworm).
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A college student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and corneal ulcers following the use of contact lens. The saline mount preparation of the corneal scraping shows polygonal cysts. What would be the most probable cause?
explanation: The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba. Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is a free-living amoeba. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, ingestion of cysts, or directly through traumatized skin or eyes. It presents as two chronic conditions- acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis. Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis. The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following protozoan parasites is found in the lumen of the human small intestine?
explanation: Image 2 shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia, which is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the human small intestine. It lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum. Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but are present in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include: Isospora belli Cyclospora cayetanensis Cryptosporidium parvum Sarcocystis hominis Options A and C: Entamoeba histolytica and Balantidium coli are found in the human large intestine. Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Balantidium coli. The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. The histopathology of the ■duodenum is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the histopathology showing trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal wall is suggestive of giardiasis. Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans. Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food and is transmitted by the faeco-oral route. It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemic, or malnourished individuals. Clinical features: Diarrhea Fat malabsorption Dull epigastric pain Belching and flatulence Iron deficiency and growth stunting. Stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood. Detection of antigen by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test is also used in the diagnosis. Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates. Metronidazole/tinidazole/nitazoxanide are the first-line agents in the treatment. The image given below shows a magnified view of the pear-shaped trophozoites of Giardia lamblia.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient is undergoing the test depicted in the image given below. Which of the following diseases does it help to diagnose?
explanation: The given image depicts a string test or entero test and is used in the diagnosis of giardiasis. It is a useful method for obtaining the duodenal specimen in giardiasis. In this test, a coiled thread inside a small weighted gelatin capsule is swallowed by the patient, after attaching the free end of the thread in the cheek. The capsule passes through the stomach to the duodenum. After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and is shaken. The centrifuged deposit of the saline is then examined for giardia.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The findings of the microscopic examination of the wet mount preparation of stool of a patient with diarrhoea is shown below. Which of the following organisms will exhibit this type of motility?
explanation: The given wet mount preparation of stool shows organisms having falling leaf motility. It is exhibited by Giardia lamblia. The trophozoite is motile with a slow oscillation along its long axis resembling a falling leaf.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. The per speculum finding is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the causative organism of this disease?
options: It exists in cyst and trophozoite form
The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM or PEM
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the image showing strawberry cervix is suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection. It exists only in trophozoite form. Trichomonas vaginalis is the only protozoan with one stage in its life cycle ie., trophozoite form (no cyst stage is seen). It is an obligate parasite and cannot live without close association with vaginal, urethral or prostatic tissues. The common presentation of trichomoniasis is foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, itching, and dysuria. The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM (cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose) or PEM (plastic envelope medium). The treatment of choice is metronidazole. T. vaginalis infection in women may lead to infertility, preterm birth and low-birth-weight infants. In men, trichomoniasis has been also associated with infertility through inflammatory damage to the genitourinary tract or interference with sperm function. The below image shows the trophozoite form of Trichomonas vaginalis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 12-year-old child presented to you with fever, malaise, and weight loss. On examination, you notice the finding shown in the image. In which of the following conditions is this seen?
explanation: The given image shows posterior cervical lymphadenopathy which is called Winterbottom’s sign. It is seen in West African sleeping sickness. It is seen in stage I of West African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense. The table below shows diseases caused by various Trypanosoma species. Protozoa Disease Trypanosoma brucei gambie nse West African sleeping sicknes s Trypanosoma brucei rhodesi ense East African sleeping sicknes s Trypanosoma cruzi Chagas’ disease/South Ameri can trypanosomiasis

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Trypanosoma?
options: Tsetse fly is the vector for both T. rhodesiense and T. gambiense
Humans are the reservoir for T. rhodesiense
explanation: Humans are the reservoir for T. gambiense, not for T. rhodesiense. The table below shows characteristic differences between West African and East African trypanosomiasis. Parasites causing myocarditis include: Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense Trypanosoma cruzi Toxoplasma gondii Echinococcus granulosus Trichinella spiralis Characteristics West African trypanosomias is East African trypanosomiasi s Organism T. brucei gambiense T. brucei rhodesiense Vector Tsetse fly Tsetse fly Reservoir Humans Wild and domestic animals Course of diseas e Chronic Acute Parasitemia Low High Virulence Less More Characteristics West African trypanosomias is East African trypanosomiasi s Mortality Low High

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents to the OPD with fever and malaise for the past 4 months. On examination, the following ocular finding is noted along with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the image showing Romana's sign is suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by T. cruzi. Reduviid bugs are vectors for Chagas disease. Inoculation of T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of periocular tissues in the eye is called Romana’s sign. This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease that lasts for 1 to 4 months. The following image shows a patient with Romana's sign. Acute Chagas disease is also characterised by the presence of chagomas which are subcutaneous lesions occurring at the site of inoculation. Chronic Chagas disease is characterized by megaesophagus, megacolon, and myopathy. Shown below is an image of the Reduviid bug.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is used for the culture of Trypanosoma?
explanation: NNN (Novy, McNeal, and Nicolle) medium is used for the culture of Trypanosoma brucie and cruzie. It is also used for the culture of Leishmania. The other media used in the culture of Trypanosoma are Weinman's medium and Tobie's medium. Options B, C & D: Boeck and Drbohlav medium, Craig’s medium and NIH polygenic medium are used for the culture of E.histolytica.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Trypanosoma cruzi. T. cruzi is the causative organism of Chagas disease or South American trypanosomiasis. They are intracellular parasites. It passes its life cycle in two hosts- the definitive host is the man and the intermediate host (vector) is reduviid bug or triatomine bugs. Metacyclic trypomastigotes are the infective forms to the man that are found in feces of reduviid bugs. Transmission occurs when mucus membranes, conjunctiva, or wound on the surface of the skin are contaminated by feces of the bug. Inside the definitive host, the trypomastigotes differentiate into intracellular amastigotes. The amastigotes multiply by binary fission and differentiate into trypomastigotes, which are then released into the bloodstream. These are the infective stage for triatomine bug. No multiplication occurs in this stage. Inside the triatomine bug, the trypomastigotes are transformed into epimastigotes and then into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the hindgut which are excreted in feces. Note: Amastigote forms resemble the Leishmania spp. and hence they are frequently known as Leishmanial forms. They are found in muscular tissue, nervous tissue, and reticuloendothelial system.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Leishmania donovani. The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector/intermediate host is female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man. L. donovani exists in 2 forms: Amastigote form- in humans and other mammals Promastigote form- in the sandfly and artificial culture When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity. Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent. Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: You are performing the following diagnostic procedure in a patient having fever for the past 2 weeks to find the causative organism. Which disease are you most likely testing for?
explanation: The given image shows bone marrow aspiration and it is most commonly done to diagnose Kala-azar. The microscopic demonstration of amastigotes from bone marrow is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Kala-azar Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Other samples collected are peripheral blood, splenic aspirate, and enlarged lymph node. In kala-azar: Most common specimen collected for microscopy- bone marrow aspirate. Most sensitive method- splenic aspirate. Option B: Schistosomiasis is typically diagnosed by stool examination for parasite eggs. Option C: Toxoplasmosis is usually diagnosed based on serologic testing. Option D: Chagas disease is diagnosed by peripheral blood smear examination, culture and examination of aspirates from lymph nodes and chagoma.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
explanation: The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly. Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rod-like kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 15-year-old boy from Delhi presented to the OPD with the finding seen in the image. It is diagnosed to be an oriental sore. Which of the following causes this?
explanation: The given image shows cutaneous leishmaniasis and is caused by Leishmania tropica complex. It is also called oriental sore/Delhi boil/Bagdad boil/Aleppo button. It is seen mainly among children in endemic areas. Old world Leishmania tropica complex includes 3 species: L. tropica L. major L. aethiopica New world Leishmania tropica complex includes 3 species: L. mexicana complex L. braziliensis complex It begins as a raised papule that grows into a nodule which then ulcerates over some weeks. The margins of the ulcer are raised and indurated. The ulcer is usually painless unless secondary bacterial infection occurs.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A medicine resident is evaluating a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The stool wet mount finding is given below. What is the most likely causative organism?
explanation: The given image shows the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli. Living trophozoites/cysts are yellowish or greenish in color on wet mount. Balantidium coli occurs in two stages: Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over the entire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end is broad. At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, there is a small anal pore (cytopyge). Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar?
Rapid dipstick test
explanation: The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar. The following tests are used for the laboratory diagnosis of kala-azar: Rapid diagnostic tests - rK39 and dipstick test strip. Parasitological diagnosis - demonstration of LD bodies on microscopy is confirmatory Surveillance purposes - Aldehyde test of Napier Serological diagnosis - Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test Assessing immune status - Leishmanin (Montenegro) test Induration of  5 mm is considered positive Usually becomes positive 4-6 weeks after onset of cutaneous leishmaniasis Protozoology - Sporozoa
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
explanation: The given clinical history and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum. Falciparum malaria infects both young and mature erythrocytes. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) seen in RBCs are common and they resemble stereo headphones in appearance. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole. There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. Hypnozoites are not present in P. falciparum infection. The peripheral smear finding of P. falciparum malaria are: Multiple ring form Accole form Absent schizont Banana shaped gametocytes Maurer's dots The below image shows banana shaped gametocyte:
subject: Microbiology

question_text: During your rural posting, a patient presents with a high fever and chills. Malaria is endemic in the area so you order a peripheral smear. While examining the peripheral blood smear, you note that the schizont stage is not seen. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
explanation: The schizont stage is usually not seen in the peripheral smear of individuals having Plasmodium falciparum malaria. A mature schizont contains merozoites and hemozoin. This will burst to release merozoites into circulation. The merozoites invade fresh erythrocytes, in which they go through the same process of development called erythrocytic schizogony or merogony. After the ring form is formed in peripheral blood, the remaining RBC cycle of falciparum occurs in the capillaries of the brain and other internal organs. Hence only the ring form is seen in the peripheral smear. However, for other Plasmodium species, all erythrocytic stages occur in peripheral blood vessels. The below image shows the life cycle of Plasmodium spp.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. has the longest incubation period?
explanation: Plasmodium malariae has the longest incubation period of 28 days. The incubation period is the interval between the infective mosquito bite and the first appearance of clinical symptoms. The average incubation periods for Plasmodium species are: P. vivax: 8-31 days (14 days) P. falciparum: 8-14 days (12 days) P. ovale: 8-31days (14 days) P. malariae: 18-40 days (28 days) Note: The pre-patent period is the interval between the entry of the parasites into the host and the time when they first become detectable in blood.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. mainly affects the old RBCs?
explanation: Plasmodium malaria mainly affects the old RBCs. Options A and D- P. vivax and P. ovale infect young RBCs and reticulocytes. Option B- P. falciparum infects RBCs of all ages. The degree of parasitization is not heavy for P. vivax and P. malariae while very high intensity of parasitization is seen in infection with P. falciparum.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A microbiologist is examining the slide shown in the following image under the microscope. Which of the following is false regarding this?
options: 'B' is used for determining the species
'A' is air dried rapidly and stained with one of the Romanowsky stains
For 'B' to be considered negative, at least 200 oil immersion fields should be examine
explanation: In the given image 'A' is a thin smear and 'B' is a thick smear. The thin smear is used for determining the species, not the thick smear. The two types of smears are prepared from the peripheral blood are: Thin smear– It is used for detecting the parasites and determining the species. They are air-drie rapidly and stained with Romanowsky stains. Thick smear– It is more sensitive and examined under oil immersion microscope. It is more suitable for the rapid detection of malarial parasites. Species identification is difficult. It is recommended that 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a thick film is declare negative. The image below shows the thin and thick smears.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past 3 days. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding the diagnostic methods used to detect the condition he is likely suffering from?
options: Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for peripheral smear examination
HRP-2 antigen test is done for detection of P.vivax
Acridine orange dye is used in quantitative buffy coat metho
Rapid diagnostic tests have lesser sensitivity than microscopy
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing ring forms are suggestive of P. falciparum malaria. HRP-2 antigen detection used in rapid diagnostic tests for malaria is specific for P. falciparum. Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya (JSB) stain is routinely used in India to stain peripheral blood smears for the diagnosis of malaria. Acridine orange dye is used in the quantitative buffy coat (QBC) method of diagnosis which provides better yield compared to peripheral smears. Rapid diagnostic tests are based on the detection of antigens using immunochromatographic methods. They are less sensitive than microscopy and also cannot differentiate between species except P. falciparum. The 2 antigens detected are: pLDH (parasite lactate dehydrogenase)- pan malarial antigen HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein 2)- specific for P.falciparum.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 50-year-old man with a 5-day history of fever is brought to the casualty by his son after an episode of seizures. He is diagnosed with malignant tertian malaria. Which of the following complications will you not expect to see in this patient?
explanation: Metabolic acidosis (and not alkalosis) is a complication of malignant tertain malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum. Complications of falciparum malaria include: Metabolic acidosis Cerebral malaria Algid malaria Septicemic malaria Blackwater fever Pulmonary edema Acute renal failure Hypoglycemia Hyperpyrexia Severe anemia Shock
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 24-year-old patient presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and weakness for 5 days. He gives a history of blood transfusion 4 months back. The microscopic examination of the thin blood smear is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
explanation: The given clinical history and the microscopy showing Maltese crosses or tetrads are suggestive of babesiosis caused by Babesia microti. The definitive host for babesia are ixodid ticks. Man is an incidental, dead-end host. On microscopic examination, babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani. The below image shows Maltese cross appearance of Babesia microti.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition?
explanation: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye. Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added. If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result). If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope. This is considered to be a negative result. The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyzoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific. It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Toxoplasma gondii?
options: Oocysts are formed within the intermediate host
The tachyzoites inside the tissue cyst can be reactivated on immunosuppression
explanation: Human toxoplasmosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted by cats. Toxoplasma gondii has two types of life cycles: Enteric cycle Exoenteric cycle The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts such as cats. Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc. Both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur within the mucosal epithelial cells of the small intestine of the cat. The tachyzoites and tissue cyst represent stages in asexual multiplication, while the oocyst is formed by sexual reproduction. All three forms, tachyzoites, tissue cyst, and oocyst occur in the definitive host. Only the asexual forms, tachyzoites, and tissue cysts are present in the intermediate host. Tachyzoites continue to multiply and spread locally by the lymphatic system and blood, while the bradyzoites multiply slowly inside the tissue cyst. The dormant bradyzoites inside the cyst may be reactivated on immune suppression causing renewed infection in the host. The below image shows the life cycle of Toxoplasma gondii.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An HIV positive pregnant woman was brought to the ER after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. CECT was done which showed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the cerebral lesions was done and the image is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for her treatment?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasma bradyzoites which are encased in cysts are suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Spiramycin is the drug of choice during pregnancy. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in HIV +ve patients and usually occurs when CD4+ T cell counts <100/L. It appears as ring enhancing lesions on contrast enhanced CT. Calcification may also be seen in old lesions. Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against toxoplasma. IIF (indirect immunofluorescence), IHA (indirect heamagglutination), and CFT (complement fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. Dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately. Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A Kinyoun-positive oocyst (25 m) isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea is shown in the image. What is the likely organism implicated here?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. Kinyoun-positive oocysts with the size of 25 m in the image are formed by Cystoisospora. Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host: The below image shows oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis in the modified acid-fast stain. question_text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago came with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample subjected to Kinyoun staining revealed 4-6 µm structures as shown below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?
options: It is an obligate intracellular organism
Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
Metronidazole is the drug of choice
explanation: The given clinical scenario with Kinyoun stain positive oocysts of size 4-6 µm is suggestive of cryptosporidiosis. The oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool. Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite and implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are C. hominis and C. parvum. The infective form is the oocyst excreted in the patient's feces, which can be acquired through drinking or during recreational water activities. The oocysts are immediately infectious (unlike isospora oocysts, which require maturation), and may cause autoinfection or be implicated in person-to-person transmission. Because of their small size (4-5micron), they is difficult to see using routine staining. Hence acid-fast/Kinyoun's stain is used. Once ingested, the 4 sporozoites are released from the cyst and attach to the small intestinal mucosa. It causes crampy abdominal pain and non-inflammatory watery diarrhea. Treatment is mainly supportive, though nitazoxanide has been FDA approved for use in cryptosporidium infection. explanation: The below image shows trophozoites of Trichomonas vaginalis with flagella. question_text: Which of the following cestodes requires only one host?
explanation: Hymenolepis nana requires only one host for its development. Man serves as the host for H. nana. Usually, cestodes complete their life cycle in 2 different hosts except: Hymenolepis requires only 1 host, man. Diphyllobothrium requires 3 hosts Parasite requiring a single host to complete its development is said to have a direct life cycle. Parasites having a direct life cycle are: Protozoa Helminths Entamoeba histolyticaGiardi a lambliaTrichomonas vagina lisBalantidium coliCryptospo ridium parvumCyclospora ca yetanensisIsospora belliMicr osporidia. question_text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the last 4 days. Stool microscopy is shown below. The eggs present in the stool float in a saturated solution of salt. Which of the following can you use to treat her?
explanation: The given clinical history and the egg seen on stool microscopy are suggestive of infection with Hymenolepis nana. A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice. The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated salt solution and are non-bile stained. Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children and is usually asymptomatic. In heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response. The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulosae. Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection. The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include: Epilepsy Increased intracranial tension Hydrocephalus Psychiatric disturbances Meningoencephalitis Transient paresis Behavioral disorders Aphasia Visual disturbances. The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are: Scolex within a cyst Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement Nodular calcifications Focal enhancing lesions Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space. Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis. Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 42-year-old man presented to the ER with complains of abdominal discomfort, indigestion, nausea and diarrhea after consuming measly pork. Stool examination reveals round eggs as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the causative organism?
options: Eggs are not infective to man
The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution
explanation: Development of the given symptoms following the consumption of measly pork is suggestive of intestinal taeniasis caused by Taenia solium (pork tapeworm). The eggs of Taenia solium do not float in the saturated salt solution. The eggs of T. solium are infective to man and pigs. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to man. The adult worm of Taenia solium is usually 2-3 meters long and the scolex has dagger-shaped hooks. Man is the definitive host. The intermediate host is usually pig, but occasionally it can be man. The below image shows the life cycle of T. solium.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following?
explanation: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canids which are its definitive hosts. The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel, and man. Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end). Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces. Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenic hosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause a condition called sparagnosis. The image below shows the life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver?
explanation: Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver. E. multilocularis leads to formation of a multilocular hydatid cyst, most commonly affecting the liver. It presents as multiple small cysts in the liver. Note: Echinococcus granulosus causes a hollow fluid-filled unilocular cyst in the liver. The CT below shows water lily sign, which is seen in the hydatid disease of the lung. It is caused by Echinococcus granulosus. The water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall giving the apparance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a water lily. It is classically visualised on plain radiographs (mainly chest X-ray) when the collapsed membranes are calcified but may be seen on ultrasound, CT, or MRI.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: While examining a patient with right upper quadrant pain, you note the abdomen is soft with localised tenderness present. CT abdomen findings are given below. Based on these findings, you post the patient for a PAIR procedure. Which of the following is not used in this procedure?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and CT findings are suggestive of hydatid disease of the liver. Hypotonic saline is not used as a scolicidal agent for the PAIR procedure (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, and Re-aspiration) which is the treatment of choice in the early stages of this condition. Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa. In PAIR the steps involved are: USG or CT guided puncture of the cyst Aspiration of the cyst fluid Injection of scolicidal agent Re-aspiration of fluid after 5 minutes The following agents can be used as scolicidal agents: The below image depicts the PAIR procedure.
