question_text: A 24-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a history of progressive breathlessness and cough for 3 months. A chest X-ray was done which showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the right lung. Wedge resection of the lesion was done and the histopathology image is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the histological slide showing the hydatid cyst are suggestive of infection with Echinococcus granulosus. The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers: Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response. Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material. Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices. The clinical features of hydatid disease of lung are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis and chest pain. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole. The below image shows the histology of hydatid cyst.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms does the given life cycle belong to?
explanation: This is the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum. It is also known as fish tapeworm or broad tapeworm. The 3 hosts of Diphyllobothrium latum are: Definitive host- man, dog, and cat. First intermediate host- freshwater crustacean Second intermediate host- freshwater fish. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex. The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called oncosphere.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 35-year-old woman presented to you with complaints of tingling and numbness in her legs. On examination, her hands appear as shown in the image, ankle reflex was absent and Romberg's test was positive. Which of the following is most likely implicated in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with cutaneous hyperpigmentation and features of subacute combined degeneration are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. This can be caused by Diphyllobothrium latum. The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to vitamin B12 deficiency. This can also lead to megaloblastic anemia (Bothriocephalus anemia). In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurological features of vitamin B12 deficiency like: Tingling and numbness Bilateral lower limb weakness Bilateral hypertonia Sensory ataxia (Romberg's positive) Absent deep tendon reflexes. It is treated with parenteral vitamin B12 supplementation.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms most commonly causes Katayama fever?
explanation: Among the given options, Katayama fever is most commonly caused by Schistosoma mansoni. It is an immune complex mediated disease caused by antibodies to the schistosomulae, adult worms, and eggs. This acute illness consists of fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and allergic manifestations. The diagnosis is by the demonstration of the eggs in feces. Praziquantel is effective in the treatment. Glucocorticoids are given to suppress hypersensitivity reactions. Instances of Katayama fever are rarer in infections with Schistosoma haematobium compared to S. mansoni. *Note: Katayama fever is most commonly caused by S. japonicum and S. mansoni. But, among the given options, S. mansoni is the most common cause of Katayama fever.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, intermittent abdominal pain, and burning micturition. He gives a history of swimming in a freshwater lake 10 days back. Urine microscopy shows the following. Which of the following is the causative agent?
options: Schistosoma species cannot be determined based on egg
explanation: The given clinical picture and image showing an egg that is non-operculated with the terminal spine at one pole are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma hematobium. Species differentiation of schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine as follows: Terminal spine- Schistosoma hematobium Lateral spine- Schistosoma mansoni Rudimentary lateral spine- Schistosoma japonicum The image below shows egg of Schistosoma mansoni. Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein. Adult worms of S. japonicum live in the superior mesenteric vein draining the ileocecal region. They are also seen in the intrahepatic portal venules and hemorrhoidal plexus of veins. The image below shows an egg of Schistosoma japonicum. Adult worms of S. hematobium live in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins. The below image shows the life cycle of S.hematobium:
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 50-year-old fisherman presented with complaints of blood in the urine. A diagnostic cystoscopy was done and the microscopic view of the biopsied specimen is given below. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder. It is associated with Schistosoma hematobium infection. Chronic schistosomiasis presents as painless hematuria, dysuria, and proteinuria. Fibrosis may cause obstructive uropathies like hydronephrosis and hydroureter. It has been associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Such malignancy is detected in a younger age group as compared to transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. The following parasites cause malignancies: Schistosoma hematobium- bladder carcinoma Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini- bile duct carcinoma
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Identify the parasite from the given life cycle.
explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Fasciola hepatica. Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals. Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults. The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation. Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle. Most infections are asymptomatic. Halzoun is a painful pharyngitis caused by the presence of adult flukes on the posterior pharyngeal wall after eating raw sheep liver. Obstructive jaundice can occur months or years later. Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following organisms does the given life cycle belong to?
explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Clonorchis sinensis. It causes clonorchiasis (Asian liver fluke infection). The hosts for Clonorchis sinensis are: Definitive host- humans First intermediate host- snai Second intermediate host- fish Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae). In the duodenum, metacercaria will undergo excystation and migrate to bile ducts to develop into adult worms. The eggs containing miracidia are excreted in human feces which are then ingested by snails. Miracidium hatches out in the midgut of the snail. Inside the snail, sporocyst develops into 1st and 2nd generation redia and then to cercariae. The cercariae now penetrate the fish and develop into metacercaria (infective form). Chronic clonorchiasis is strongly associated with cholangiocarcinoma.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea is given below. Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?
explanation: The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in the stool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection. The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain an immature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution. The following are the parasites with operculated eggs: Fasciola hepatica Fasciolopsis buski Fasciola gigantica Paragonimus westermani Opisthorchis felineus Clonorchis sinensis Gastrodiscoides hominis Diphyllobothrium latum Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale are non-operculated.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A 23-year-old patient has a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organism?
Fasciola buski
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani. Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue. The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs. Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice. Helminthology - Nematodes
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following parasites is ovoviviparous?
explanation: Strongyloides stercoralis is an ovoviviparous parasite. Nematodes are classified as follows: Oviparous - lay eggs: Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria Segmented eggs: Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus Eggs containing larva: Enterobius vermicularis Viviparous - produce larvae. e.g., Trichinella spiralis, Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi Ovoviviparous – lay eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch immediately. e.g., Strongyloides stercoralis
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below.
explanation: The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis. The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection. The rhabditiform larva can be seen on microscopic examination of stool.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 24-year-old patient presented with complaints of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 1 week. The stool microscopy revealed the following. What is the appropriate treatment for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy showing the rhabditiform larva of S. stercoralis are suggestive of strongyloidiasis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition would be ivermectin. Strongyloidiasis is caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of perianal itching which is worse in the night. The scotch tape method demonstrates eggs as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely causative agent?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of perianal itching and the scotch tape microscopy showing the eggs are suggestive of infestation with pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis). The eggs of pinworm are plano-convex in shape, colorless, non-bile stained, and float in the saturated salt solution. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent. Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and the scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens. The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod, at one end of which a piece of transparent cellophane is attached with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. It is returned to the test tube and sent to the laboratory. The cellophane piece is detached, spread over a glass side, and examined microscopically. The image given below shows the NIH swab. In scotch tape method, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with sticky side down. Then a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope. The below image shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by■ the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
explanation: The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm). The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are: Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless. They float in the saturated salt solution. It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown. They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection. In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss. In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia. Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm. Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A college student came to the OPD with fever and muscle aches. He tells you he had consumed smoked pork at a party 2 weeks back. Following this, he had developed abdominal cramps and diarrhea which had resolved on their own. CBC revealed eosinophilia and the muscle biopsy showed the following finding. What is the causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and muscle biopsy showing larvae are suggestive of trichinellosis. It is caused by Trichinella spiralis. Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever and myalgia. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months. Detection of spiral larva in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy. Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are: T. solium T. cruzi (amastigote) The image below shows Trichinella spiralis larvae within the muscle.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: In a patient with a positive Bachman intradermal test, which of the following infections will you suspect?
explanation: Bachman intradermal test is used for the diagnosis of trichinellosis. In this test, 1:5,000 or 1:10,000 dilution of the trichinella larval antigen is injected intradermally. An erythematous wheal appears in positive cases within 15-20 minutes. The test remains positive for years after infection.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Identify the organism shown in this image.
explanation: The given image shows the Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). It is the most common of human helminths and is distributed worldwide. Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum). The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine. The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends, the anterior end being more pointed than the posterior. Man is the natural host. There is no intermediate host. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces containing eggs of ascaris. The eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A 9- year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever and colicky abdominal pain. An erect X-ray abdomen showed multiple air-fluid levels. Stool examination revealed the following egg. Which of the following is false about the organism causing this condition?
options: Egg containing L1 larva is infective
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of ascariasis caused by Ascaris lumbricoides. Embryonated egg containing the L3 larva is the infective form. Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host. The infection is acquired via the consumption of food or water contaminated with eggs. The eggs hatch after reaching the duodenum to release the larvae. These penetrate the intestinal mucosa and enter the portal vessels. From the liver, larvae reach the systemic circulation, lungs and then reach the small intestine to produce symptoms. Clinical features: Due to the migrating larvae: Fever Dry cough Asthmatic wheezing Loeffler's syndrome Due to the adult worm: Asymptomatic Nutritional effects - protein-energy malnutrition, Vitamin A deficiency Toxic effects - urticaria, angioedema due to hypersensitivity Mechanical effects - colicky abdominal pain, volvulus, and intestinal obstruction Ectopic ascariasis - acute biliary obstruction, pancreatitis, and obstructive appendicitis. The life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides is given below.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: What is the most common cause for visceral larva migrans?
explanation: The most common cause for visceral larva migrans is Toxocara canis. It occurs most commonly in children and presents as fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pneumonitis. Larva migrans is generally seen when human infection occurs with nonhuman species of nematodes. It can be classified into cutaneous or visceral types, depending on whether the larval migration takes place in the skin or in deeper tissues. Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae that are acquired via the oral route. Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae (most commonly Ancylostoma braziliense) that are acquired via skin penetration. Patients having visceral larva migrans may develop neurological disturbances (neural larva migrans) and endophthalmitis (ophthalmic larva migrans). Differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans: Cutaneous larva migrans Visceral larva migrans Tissue involved Skin Various organs of the body li ke the liver, lungs, and eyes Infecting Organis m Mostly by non-human nemat odes Mostly by non-human nemat odes (mainly by dog and cat) Portal of Entry Penetration of skin Ingestion of infected eggs Eosinophilia Mild Persistent high Serodiagnosis Not developed Well developed Treatment Thiabendazole Diethylcarbamazine and pred nisolone
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A middle-aged woman comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness for the past 3 months. She is diagnosed to have microcytic hypochromic anemia. The stool microscopy reveals the following. What is the most probable causative agent?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of iron deficiency anemia and the stool microscopy showing the egg is suggestive of infection by Ancylostoma duodenale. Eggs of both Ancylostoma duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator americanus (new world hookworm) are identical. The hookworm eggs are oval or elliptical in shape, colorless, and non-bile stained. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. The ovum is segmented with 4 to 8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and eggshell. Eggs float in the saturated salt solution. Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin or subcutaneous tissue. The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss. The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenale and 0.03 mL with Necator americanus.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A patient presented to the OPD with dry cough, low-grade fever and wheezing. He is diagnosed with Loeffler’s syndrome. Which of the following parasites does not cause this?
explanation: Loeffler's syndrome is an eosinophilic inflammation of the lung caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis and Necator americanus. Enterobius vermicularis does not cause Loeffler’s syndrome. It is associated with pneumonia characterized by dry cough, low-grade fever, wheezing, urticaria, and eosinophilia. Parasites causing Loeffler’s syndrome are: Migrating larva of: Ascaris lumbricoides Strongyloides stercoralis Ancylostoma duodenale Necator americanus Echinococcus granulosus Cryptosporidium parvum Eggs of Paragonimus westermani Entamoeba histolytica Trichomonas tenax

question_text: A 27-year-old woman had gone on a trek in the Amazon rainforest. A month later she presented to the OPD with the following lesion which was painful and pruritic. Her systemic examination was normal. Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing serpiginous skin lesions are suggestive of cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption or ground itch. This is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense. Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they are unable to penetrate the basement membrane of the human skin. It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry and serpiginous tracks in the epidermis. The symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient’s return from a tropical or endemic country. The larval track progresses at approximately 1 cm/h with cutaneous lesions only progressing a few millimeters to a few centimeters daily. Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features. The treatment includes: Thiabendazole topical application Albendazole 400mg/day X 3 days or Ivermectin 200mcg/kg single dose stat The differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans are: Note: A rapidly moving lesion (10cm/hr) produced by Strongyloides stercoralis is known as larva currens (running larva). It occurs as an otherwise asymptomatic lesion in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised, hyper-infestation syndrome occurs with paralytic ileus and secondary Gram-negative sepsis. question_text: Which the following filarial worms are non-pathogenic to humans?
explanation: Mansonella ozzardi is generally non-pathogenic to humans. Option A: Onchocerca volvulus infection may manifest as skin nodules or onchocercoma which are formed as a result of fibroblastic reaction around adult worms deep in the subcutaneous tissues. Microfilariae cause lesions in the skin and eyes. Options B and C: In lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria and Brugia), the typical manifestations are caused by the adult worms blocking lymph nodes and vessels. Microfilaria (larval form) are responsible for allergic manifestations seen in occult filariasis.

question_text: A 55-year-old man came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of his legs. On examination, you note bilateral non-pitting edema of the lower limbs with thickening of the overlying skin. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis). The best next step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 10 pm and 4 am) in India. Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. Elephantiasis is a delayed sequel to repeated lymphangitis, obstruction, and lymphedema. Repeated leakage of lymph into tissues first results in lymphedema, then to elephantiasis. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. Option A: PCR is negative in chronic filariasis. Options B & D: Lymphangiography and lymphoscintigraphy may be used to demonstrate abnormal lymphatic urinary fistula leading to chyluria in chronic filariasis.

question_text: A child from Bihar is brought to the AIIMS ER with a high-grade fever. On examination, bilaterally enlarged, tender inguinal lymph nodes are present. The peripheral smear examination finding is shown in the image. What is the most likely causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of infection with Brugia malayi. Acute infection may manifest as acute adenolymphangitis which is characterized by high fever, lymphatic inflammation (lymphangitis and lymphadenitis) and transient local edema. The most commonly affected lymph nodes are inguinal nodes followed by axillary nodes which become enlarged, painful and tender. The following are the characteristic features of microfilaria of Brugia malayi: Smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti. Shows kinks and secondary curves. Cephalic space is longer. Carries double stylets at the anterior end. Nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films. Tail tip carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal. The below image shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

question_text: A patient from Kerala has presented to your OPD with fever. A magnified view of peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding the organism seen?
options: DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day
Second stage filariform larva is the infective form
Microfilaria is the major diagnostic form
Filarial stage of adult worms are responsible for disease
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. The third stage filariform larva is the infective form. Wuchereria bancrofti infection is usually asymptomatic. The symptoms are due to obstruction of lymphatics by the filarial stage of adult worms. The lymphatic vessels of the male genitalia are most commonly affected in bancroftian filariasis, producing episodic funiculitis, epididymitis, and orchitis. Adenolymphangitis of the extremities is less common. Hydrocele is the most common sign of chronic bancroftian filariasis, followed by lymphedema, elephantiasis, and chyluria. The swelling involves the whole leg, the whole arm, the scrotum, the vulva, or the breast. DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day. The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti. The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.

question_text: A 54-year-old farmer from Assam presented with the finding shown in the image. He had also developed a painless swelling in his elbow 2 years back which has gradually been increasing in size. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario and image showing sclerosing keratitis are suggestive of onchocerchiasis (river blindness). The drug of choice is ivermectin. It is caused by Onchocerca volvulus. It is also known as convoluted filaria or blinding filaria. The vector is blackfly (Simulium species) which breed in fast-flowing rivers, and therefore the disease is most common along the course of rivers. Hence, it is also called river blindness. The usual presentation is formation of a subcutaneous nodule or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like scalp, elbow, ribs, and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. The microfilaria in the eyes cause photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most severe manifestation is sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which causes blindness. It is the 2nd major infective cause of blindness in the world after trachoma. Suramin and diethylcarbamazine (DEC) were used earlier but are not used nowadays. DEC destroys microfilariae but usually causes Mazzotti reaction consisting of pruritus, rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, hypotension, and occasionally, eye damage. Note: Onchocerciasis is not endemic in India but sporadic cases have been reported from North-Eastern India.

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents to your clinic with photosensitivity, redness, and watering of the eyes for the last 2 days. She shows you this photo of a swelling in her hand that had arisen 2 weeks back but disappeared in just 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing Calabar swelling is suggestive of loiasis caused by Loa loa. Calabar swellings are temporary foci of inflammation that appear as Loa loa wanders through the subcutaneous tissues. They are up to 3 cm in size and are also called fugitive swellings because they disappear in a few days only to reappear elsewhere. Loa loa is transmitted by the bite of Chrysops species (deerflies). The infective form is the third stage microfilaria. After entry into human skin, it grows into an adult worm. The ocular manifestations occur when the worm reaches the subconjunctival tissue during its wanderings. They include: Granuloma in bulbar conjunctiva Painless edema of the eyelids Proptosis. The image below shows Calabar swelling. The image below shows a live, adult Loa loa in the anterior chamber of the eye.

question_text: Which of the following is also known as Weingarten syndrome?
explanation: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is also known as Weingarten syndrome. Tropical eosinophilia occurs as a result of hypersensitivity reaction to microfilarial antigens and not directly due to lymphatic involvement. It is a manifestation of occult filariasis (Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome). Clinical features of occult filariasis include massive eosinophilia and hepatosplenomegaly. Synonyms of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia include - Weingarten syndrome Pseudo-tuberculosis of the lung Eosinophilic pseudo-leukemia Tropical eosinophilic asthma Frimodt-Moller and Barton's syndrome

question_text: Which of the following is known as serpent worm?
explanation: Dracunculus medinensis is known as serpent worm. It is a viviparous nematode. This has been eradicated from India and all of the southeast Asian region in the year 2000.

question_text: While assessing the quality of drinking water in a village, you detect the presence of coliform bacilli by the multiple tube technique. Following this, you decide to perform the Eijkman test. What is this test also known as?
explanation: Eijkman test is also known as differential coliform test. Drinking water should be free of any pathogenic microorganisms. The presence of coliform bacteria in the water may indicate faecal pollution, while the detection of E.coli confirms it. The presumptive coliform test is done by the multiple tube technique. Following this, the Eijkman test is done to confirm the presence of E. coli. They can grow at 44°C (faecal thermotolerant bacilli), ferment lactose and cause indole and gas production. Option A: Presumptive coliform count detects the probable number of coliform bacilli in water. It can be positive due to the presence of organisms other than E.coli also. Option C: Colony counts provide an estimate of the general bacterial purity of water. Option D: Methylene blue reduction test is used to assess the bacterial contamination of milk.

question_text: Faecal contamination of a water source is suspected by the mayor of a municipal corporation. He asks you to test the water for evidence of recent contamination. The presence of which of the following organisms would suggest this?
explanation: Recent fecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (fecal streptococci). Clostridium perfringens may be present for a long duration. If it is present in water, it suggests that contamination is not recent. If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of fecal contamination. However, it is non-specific for suggesting the duration of the contamination.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following tests is not used for bacteriological examination of milk?
explanation: Pasteurization is not used for the bacteriological examination of milk. Pasteurization is the process of applying heat, to milk, for a specified period for the purpose of killing pathogenic bacteria. There are two methods: holder method and flash method. Option A: Methylene blue reduction test depends on the reduction of methylene blue by bacteria in milk when incubated at 37 °C in complete darkness. Option B: Resazurin test is similar to methylene blue reduction test, but the dye resazurin on reduction passes through a series of colour changes from blue to pink to colourless. The shade of colour after incubation with milk for a particular period of time depends on the degree of contamination. Option C: Phosphatase test is used to check whether milk has been pasteurised. Positive test after pasteurisation of milk shows contamination after pasteurisation.

question_text: The following image depicts:
explanation: The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology. The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology: Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies. When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production. Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth. The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture. Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

question_text: Which of the following statements about hybridoma is false?
options: Specific antibody-producing cells are integrated with myeloma cells.
Myeloma cells using salvage pathway grow well in HAT medium.
Aminopterin, a folate antagonist, inhibits de novo pathway.
HGPRTase and thymidylate synthetase are required for salvage pathway.
explanation: Aminopterin is a folate antagonist present in the HAT medium that inhibits the de novo pathway of nucleotide synthesis. Since myeloma cells cannot use the salvage pathway for nucleotide synthesis due to the lack of HGPRTase enzyme, they cannot survive in the HAT medium. Hybridoma technology is a method for producing large numbers of identical antibodies (monoclonal antibodies). Hybridomas are somatic cell hybrids produced by fusing the antibody-forming spleen cells with myeloma cells. The resultant hybrid thus has both the antibody-producing ability of the B-cell and the ability to multiply indefinitely of the myeloma. The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology: Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies. When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production. Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth. The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture. Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

question_text: Which of the following is both a diffusion and a dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity?
explanation: Epsilometer (E-test) is both a diffusion and a dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity. It is a quantitative technique for determining the antimicrobial susceptibility (AST) and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) in µg/mL of gram-negative and gram-positive aerobic bacteria. The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows: Diffusion methods: Kirby–Bauer method, Stokes method Dilution methods: Tube dilution method, Agar dilution method Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)
subject: Microbiology

question_text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied?
explanation: The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method. To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive). Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by: Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E–test (Epsilometer) The image below shows Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following methods of antibiotic susceptibility testing cannot be used to calculate the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug?
explanation: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cannot be calculated using Kirby-Bauer's disk diffusion method and Stokes disk diffusion method as they are semi-quantitative methods. MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism. Methods to determine MIC include: Tube dilution method Agar dilution method E-test method
subject: Microbiology

question_text: A microbiologist is about to run a polymerase chain reaction assay on the serum of a patient suspected to have Q fever. He wishes to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. Which of the following types of PCR should he perform?
explanation: Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can be used to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. Types of PCR: Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR. Real-time PCR- This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR) Multiplex PCR- Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking?
explanation: The hemagglutination test is not based on the principle of antibody marking. When antibodies bind to antigens on the surface of red blood cells, the resultant clumping reaction is referred to as hemagglutination. It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing. The image below shows hemagglutination. In ELISA, radioimmunoassay and immunofluorescence, the antigens or antibodies are labeled or marked with enzymes, fluorescent dyes, etc. Note: If no hemagglutination occurs it means the patient’s serum has anti-haemagglutinin antibodies that bind to hemagglutinin and prevent the clumping reaction. This hemagglutination inhibition reaction is a method of detection of viruses and antiviral-antibodies and is used to make a diagnosis of influenza.
subject: Microbiology

question_text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections?
explanation: Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However, it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it’s high sensitivity and specificity. The screening tests for UTI are as follows: Wet mount examination- It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine. Leukocyte esterase test- It is a rapid and cheaper method and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine. Nitrate reduction test (Griess test)- Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli gives a positive result. Catalase test- E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result. Quantitative Culture: Standardized loop technique Pour plate method
subject: Microbiology

question_text: The CLED medium is preferred over MacConkey agar for the culture of organisms in case of UTI because:
options: It promotes the growth of candida, streptococcus and staphylococcus
It differentiates between lactose-fermenting and non-lactose fermenting bacteria
It promotes the growth of pseudomonas
explanation: CLED (Cysteine lactose electrolyte-deficient) medium is preferred over MacConkey agar for the culture of organisms involved in urinary tract infections because it is less inhibitory and promotes the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except  hemolytic streptococcus) and candida. It is used as an alternative to the combination of blood agar and MacConkey agar, for the processing of urine specimens. CLED medium is not similar to blood agar in the fact that it can prevent swarming of proteus. It is similar to MacConkey agar in that it differentiates between lactose fermenters and non-fermenters.
subject: Microbiology

question_text:
A patient who had been receiving ceftazidime and amikacin via central venous line for a week suddenly spiked a fever. Blood culture is positive for a vancomycin-resistant,
catalase-negative organism whose Gram-stained image is given below. Identify the organism.
explanation: From the given case scenario and image we can deduce that the most likely organism involved is Enterococcus faecalis. The image shows gram-positive cocci in chains, that are described as catalase negative. This helps rule out Staphylocococcus aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococcus. Streptococcus viridans is usually sensitive to penicillin and vancomycin hence it is ruled out. The mechanism of vancomycin resistance seen in E. faecalis is the alteration of the D-alanyl–D-alanine chain in the cell wall.

explanation: The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography. The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen.
